=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've always enjoyed Hanabi, but it's taken awhile for me to really warm up to it. It's still never been one of my favorites, but I think I can appreciate this tense, collaborative game on its own terms. 

You and all the other players are trying to lay down all the cards 1-5 in five different colors on the table. You're trying to do it before you run out of cards to draw or before you use up your three mistakes. Only catch? You're the only one that can't see your own hand. Everyone holds their hands outwards, and throughout the game you must use turns to give hints to other players. Based on the info they get from hints, they assemble some knowledge of their own hands and can play the proper cards on the table.

Though this is described as a group game, I actually prefer it two-player with my wife. We're still shockingly horrible at it (our best score is an 18 or 19) and may never beat it. With two player, you have fewer cards 'safe' in players hands so it's much more likely you discard a necessary card than when you play with more players. 

You can control how hard this game is by how strict you are about hints and passing on information -- my wife is always trying to sneak in extra information in her hints. Many people like to play this as a perfect information game (they write down every time they receive a hint, for example), but I think that detracts from the fun of it.

The fun is not in the logic puzzle, but in the logic puzzle combined with a few fallible human brains -- now that's a game I can get behind! There are few co-op games that are more unique or more engaging than Hanabi -- this is great fun in a tiny package, well worth the $10 it goes for! The brain burning puzzle exercises your brain nicely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Custom-made.  Hanabi is the Japanese word for "firework," but it literally translates to "fire flower."  So I drew some flowers that look like they were made with fire, and printed them onto cards.  Kudos to the designers of this game for one of the most novel mechanics I've seen in board games.  Since there are limits on how you can communicate in this game, it's best played with people who aren't hell-bent on winning, but rather who want to have fun while they play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Co-op.  The selling point of this game is the unique limited knowledge element, where everybody can see your hand except you.  It's a bit of a gimmick, and really just an okay game that requires players to agree on a strict set of rules (and have a good memory) to have any chance of winning.

RATING: 6
An ingenious game-mechanic, but the crinkles need ironing out. The rules on how much you can communicate between players are deliberately left ambiguous, but this creates discord between players. What constitutes cheating here? And the goal of scoring your own personal high-score is fine if you play repeatedly with the same group, but pretty meaningless if you play occasionally with different people. All in all, an odd package, but undeniably a very clever concept.

RATING: 8
This is like a good collaborative version of go fish where you work together with other players to put together a firework display through deducing what fireworks are in your hand by asking specifically defined and limited questions from other players and then playing the right suits in the right sequence in the central tableau. I purchased the deluxe version with ceramic tiles. This is a huge upgrade to the game. I love the tactile feel of the tiles and how much easier it is to handle them than the cards.

My rating was going to be 10, but the game has a little issue. It's too difficult to follow the rules and don't give extra information while talking, and playing in complete silence would be just boring.

RATING: 9
I love this game, along with the Cookie Jar microgame. Self-hidden information is interesting! I'm a big fan of small box games. I enjoy guessing mitigated by probability.

Best feature: Co-op and you can cheat by talking.

Worst feature: Hard to reach an agreed convention while taking "no-talk/no-hints" rule seriously. I also hang out with friends so that I can converse with them.

Edit: I have almost no desire to play this game, since I am much more of a Competitive "Destroy your stuff" player. Still, a good couples task

Destroyed in 10/17 house fire.

RATING: 8
A very fun game! It works well with two players, but I think a higher score can be earned if there are more players because you can see more cards. It is a little tricky to keep track of what you have in your hand. I used how I told the cards and the card's back designs (rotating them, etc.) as a strategy to help me remember what cards I have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Давно хотел написать отзыв, но, видимо, так и не соберусь уже. 

После десятой партии (спустя полгода плотного увлечения настольными играми) жена сказала, что из всех коробок в наших шкафах "Ханаби" - самая правильная, представляющая из себя ровно то, что она ждала от настольных игр в принципе: общение и взаимодействие. Полное ощущение, что ты посредством карт играешь именно с другим человеком, а не пользуешься человеком как каким-то квази-AI, чтобы сыграть в игру (неважно, с кем). При игре на двоих ты будто бы завязываешь себе глаза, доверяешь свою судьбу напарнику, а он берёт тебя за руку и осторожно ведёт через минное поле. Ни с чем не сравнимые впечатления.

Ещё один интересный эффект не затронут в обзоре. Периодически в ходе игры возникает мощная иллюзия того, что ты всё идеально просчитал, и у твоего напарника есть только один-единственный верный ход (на который ты ему и намекаешь своей меткой подсказкой). На самом же деле, конечно, твой мозг отфильтровал часть информации, о другой части не догадывается, а у напарника, глядящего в твои карты, может быть вообще иное видение ситуации. В такие моменты очень легко могут возникнуть разочарования и конфликты, особенно если каждый из вас совершенно уверен в своих аналитических способностях. Видел, как на реддите игру называют divorce fireworks ;)

В общем, "Ханаби" - обоюдоострый скальпель, которым, при осторожном обращении можно добраться до самой души человеческих отношений. 


Ниже старые заметки.
поначалу сложно запоминать, что у тебя в руке (особенно, если напарник долго думает над ходом), карты в руке от напряжения гнутся, лучше иметь какую-то подставочку под них. 

Лида в итоге взяла блокнот с карандашом, записывать известные данные :)
я вроде справился и так, но пару раз забывал, что мне говорили. игра довольно весёлая, будем пробовать ещё. 

в комплекте сразу идёт дополение, которое добавляет радужный фейерверк, у которого все карты в одном экземпляре.

на BGG не указано, что есть русская версия (Lifestyle Boardgames Ltd). карты гнутся, края крошатся. очень хочется перейти на делюксовую версию. возможно, купим (и покрасим ;) набор домино.

долго дискутировали с Лидой, можно ли строить стратегию на порядке называния карт. в правилах этого нет, Лида считает такой подход нечестным.

BGG: твоя задача как умелого игрока в "Ханаби" - научиться действовать максимально предсказуемо во всевозможных ситуациях.

reddit: чувак на реддите идёт с девушкой на игротеку на первое свидание (она уже ходила туда сама), просит посоветовать подходящую игру.
некоторые упоминают "Ханаби". другие комментируют: By Hanabi, do you mean divorce fireworks? %)
https://www.reddit.com/r/boardgames/comments/3bqwlh/first_date_tonight_in_a_board_game_cafe/csp175d

в комплекте идёт мини-дополнение с шестым, радужным фейерверком (в локализации каждая карта только в одном экземпляре, что сужает число вариантов игры с этим дополнением). Лида шутит, что наш брак ещё недостаточно крепок для игры с ним ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Incredibly elegant rule set in a coop game. To consistent score well you need a very complex analysis of what any communication (given or received) might mean and the risks and potential side effects of any suboptimal move you might accidentally encourage.

RATING: 1
This is a firework bridge. You have to have a group that has set up conventions, absolutely arbitrary conventions like the leftmost card is the newest and so on and if i don't clue you that's because in fact i need you to play your unclued #3 card and you must know that because i clued the 5th card of the 4th player last 7 turns (almost not kidding), then this group has to bost he has the most logical set of conventions ever devised in the history of logical science (it is not, it is only arbitrary and cheating IMHO) and called this hyper-finesse and then you drink tea in Melbourne and are very happy being in the Commonwealth of good logical bridge..erhmm.. sorry... Hanabi players. Better to throw the cards over and rearrange the suites by hand, more fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cooperative game with a remarkable theme (that doesn't affect game play) and interesting twist.  You are trying to put on a great Japanese fireworks show, which means you must set off the explosives/play cards in a certain order, but you aren't able to see your own hand.  Other players can help you make a choice of which card to play, but they can only offer limited information.  It's easy to explain and fun to play, especially the first game where you really have no idea what to do with your cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hanabi—named for the Japanese word for "fireworks"—is a cooperative game in which players try to create the perfect fireworks show by placing the cards on the table in the right order. (In Japanese, hanabi is written as 花火; these are the ideograms flower and fire, respectively.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've had some success introducing Hanabi to new gamers. I like that it's unique and draws people in because of the way it looks. But the group dynamic determines a lot about how fun the game will be. It's also a little tough to decide how to "fine tune" the several possible variants.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros
- Cool "holding cards outward" mechanic
- Have to listen to clues given and more importantly, the clues NOT given
- Deduction on what's left for the cards with what people have by elimination 
- Getting into the mind of your teammates to think what they'd think
- Taking a chance and playing a card is terrifying
- Applauding when someone discards the right card
- Yelling at someone they discard the wrong card
- Making fun of someone who keeps forgetting the clues given to him/her

Cons
- You kind of can't talk about the game while playing the game since anything you say off handed can be a clue of some sort

RATING: 6
Absolutely brilliant and nail-biting blind deduction/puzzle/co-op/make-you-sweat game.  How do the help tokens run out quickly?!  For a "get the highest score" game, it's so utterly gripping.  I've only played it at two players, and I can't begin to imagine the tension with more.  I think that implication is necessary to do well, but it has to be done without breaking the spirit of the rules. 

That said, it can fall flat easily if players either try too hard at additional communication or don't do very well as a meta group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Hanabi is a very fun deduction card game that's easy to teach and creates plenty of those high-five moments only few cooperative games successfully do. That said, after a certain amount of sessions the general playstyle tends to become quite formulaic when playing with the same people over and over again. Hence for my first couple of sessions I'd rate this game an 8 or even higher, but the more I played the more I realized that this is the type of game that leaves a strong first impression and after that it never manages to impress as much anymore. Still a good game that gets occasionally played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great light-weight cooperative game.

The limits on communication and knowledge do a great job of addressing the problem of one player dominating a cooperative game and telling everyone else what to do.  You can talk some strategy between games, but otherwise all players need to make their own decisions each turn -- and each turn is important.

If there's a weakness, it's that the goal of the game isn't too exciting.  You're trying to get as many points as possible, so it lacks the tension of other cooperative game as to whether you'll pull off a victory or not.

RATING: 7
Interesting logical deduction cooperative game in which players work together to solve a puzzle with partial information. Challenging and definitely a brain burner. Somewhat stressful because you don't want to make the wrong move when the others are counting on you.

The end game scoring is a little bland, since you never technically lose. Sometimes, it's just impossible to get a perfect score if both copies of a low card are at the bottom of the deck. Also, a little bit of accidental cheating can go on.

RATING: 7
I really enjoy this game but you have to be aware of who you are playing with.  If you are playing with someone who wants a definitive win or lose condition they could ruin the fun for you because this game is about putting on the best fireworks show and even if you sucked at playing it you still put on a fireworks display.  Here are the basics.  Total cooperative game.  You have cards numbered 1-5.  You will never know what you have in your hand though seeing as you don't look at it.  It is held out to show the other players.  You need to create the stacks of colors starting with 1 and going up to five but if you misplay three times the fireworks show goes off.  The more cards you get down before this happens the better the show.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
How difficult can it be to play, in ascending order, cards numbered from 1 to 5?  Pretty hard indeed when you don't get to look at your own cards, and clues to other players are limited to number or color, but not both!

A co-op card game with simple rules yet pretty deep gameplay, Hanabi requires a dedicated group to bring out all its nuances.  The more you play it, the better you become.  And since information isn't shared by all the players, it side-steps the "alpha gamer" syndrome of most co-op games.

Simply love the tight play, where you have to decide whether to give a clue, discard, or play.  And if you decide a clue must be given, then you have to decide to whom, and what clue will be most productive.

Tough with two players, better with three and more.

Simple, elegant, clever, and fast.  There simply isn't much more a game needs to be!  (A bit dry theme-wise.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Usually I'd be a little more hesitant on giving such a simple game a high score but this one deserves it.  It's incredibly easy to learn and teach but will make your brain explode while playing.  Love it.

RATING: 6.53

This is a great game for a get together with friends. The one caveat is that tempers can flare a little in this game if people feel like you are forgetting or screwing up the clues, so don't play this with overly hostile or sensitive players.

Update: I still think this is a good game, but it really hasn't had much longevity with us. It seemed to get played out pretty quickly, so that drops its rating in my eyes.

RATING: 8.75
A really strong co-operative game that is about memory and deduction...I think it's particularly great because the rules leave a lot to be decided on in terms of how much "table talk" is allowed and of what type, meaning you can sort of fine tune the difficulty with house rules to your liking. Game too easy? Stop allowing a specific type of table talk or - if necessary - add in a rainbow suit variant. Granted that impreciseness is exactly why some may really dislike the game, but it totally works for me.

RATING: 2.5
I played this today with my 14 year-old daughter.  I wanted to like this game more, but ended up giving it a 6.  My daughter gave it a 7, so we split the difference.  I enjoyed the tension of the game, but I didn't find it particularly challenging.  The first 2 games we played, we didn't light the fuse at all.  We then tried variant A, and I screwed up a couple of times leading to the fuse burning down halfway.  Still, my daughter and I were enough in-sync from the get-go that we picked up easily on each other's information clues, making the game somewhat rote.

I'm willing to try it again with more people, and also try some of the other variants.

RATING: 9
I firmly believe that this game is at its best, both in terms of challenge and enjoyment, when played with others who aim for the "purity of experience".  That is, where the transmission of information is limited to straight delivery of the clues.  People who play this game with a careless or, worse, intentional [i]nudge-nudge[/i], [i]wink-wink[/i] style reduce the experience to that of mediocre filler.

I rate it a 9 in the former case and a 5 in the latter.

RATING: 7
Very impressive design. Small card game with an unusual amount of depth. You can play it with cards, tiles, or online (BGA). Personally, I find tiles to be superior over cards (easier to work with). Online still works but removes the memorization component; some gamers will like that but I personally feel memorization is a skill. Furthermore, without the memorization aspect... you start to feel the randomness more.

RATING: 7.5
Great little puzzle game for 2-5 players. Players play against the game but with it's small size and portability I could see playing multiple games in a setting or storing it in a bag for unplanned gaming opportunities.

Very light and easy to teach with novelty of players not being able to look at their own hands and relying on clues and clear communication from the team to decide their best moves. I could see players getting more strategic with clues upon multiple games and quickly learning from mistakes made with clues/timing in earlier games.

light, fast, portable, social, challenging and family friendly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A very simple cooperative game of unbelievable genius: everybody can see all the cards held by every player except himself, and must give clues to the others so they can deduct when they can play or discard a card.
The goal is making 5 straight "fireworks", one for each suit, before the game ends (because players made three mistakes, or deck runs out).
This sounds very simple, and it is as far as rules are concerned, but this game has so many levels of deduction and communication that is amazingly difficult to play well.
A true little gem, and the best Bauza I've played so far!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Such a great game deserved a gorgeous edition with a collector's feel, and thankfully after winning the SdJ it got it!
The wooden box is a bit oversized, but it's quite classy. The mah-Jong style cards are definitely great to look at and play with!
It's costly, but I like it...

RATING: 7
An interesting game where you are not allowed to see your cards. Information about what you have is revealed by the other players who can only do one of the 3 actions,

a. Tell a clue, either color or numbers about the cards.
b. Play a card.
c. Discard a card.

So far with 2 plays we managed to score 20, 23. Good game to play.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The "hold your cards backwards" mechanism is very special and needs to get used to it. Half the game it feels wrong how you hold them :)

During the game you receive hints from other players and are free to rearrange your cards (4 or 5) as you like. You now need to remember the received clues about your cards - like card numbers (1-5) and card colours (red, green, blue, white or yellow).
Furthermore you need to pay attention which player received which clues about their cards because you don't want to repeat what is already known (or should be at least) because the amount of clues is very limited.

It's amazing how such a small game tests your ability to memorise that limited amount of information. It certainly is more brain-y than I expected it to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
(updated comment) The cardplay in this game is really compelling, and provides a great shared puzzle to solve with any particular group of people. I do find the 'firework' scoring mechanism to be abstract and the notion of chasing a high score to be unrewarding. These thoughts have only really crystallised in my mind after playing "Beyond Baker Street", which uses a similar card mechanism, but layers on theme, a good setting and a scalable challenge where you can definitely win or lose the game!

RATING: 8
(3-5 Players, 30 min) A card game about a crew of fireworks pyrotechnicians with a terrible hangover. The show's about to start and none of the rockets are in place. This would be an easy task but no one can see what's right in front of them and it's hard to hear! You'll need to pay attention to the clues your team gives you about the fireworks in your hand because you can't look at them yourself. Make too many mistakes and the show is over.

RATING: 7
Played
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
First Play: From the outset I must say I am yet to play a coop game that I like but this game had a buzz so I thought I should try it out.

From the off, the game needs a card rack for each person to enable you to use your hands for other things. We improvised bent frames from a previously punched game. Next after some clues had been given an obvious code evolved that if someone stated that a player had a certain colour, that they 'should' lay it. After that the logic was tissue thin. If a player was in the dark about their hand then they had irrelevant or high-ish cards. Throughout I was struggling to find a game but became increasingly of the opinion I was playing 4 person patience.

At game end the deck ran out and we achieved a score but there was no sense of playing well or badly, just a sense of futility. Again I am amazed that people rave about this when I can see no game at all. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting, cooperative card game where players can see everyone's hand other than their own.  On your turn you can play a card, give a clue (if there are any clue tokens available), or discard a card (and receive a clue token).  The goal is to play cards in increasing order 1-5 in each of 5 colors.  Your score is based on your successfully played cards.

RATING: 9
It's a difficult game to play. Not because of any mechanics or implements, but wrapping your head around all of the potential strategies and conveying them to others without inadvertently cheating is quite a challenge! But, this might be the best co-op made yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game shouldn't work. I have no idea why it does. I mean all we're doing is trying to play 25 cards down on the table in order. You're restricted on your clues, so you can never say everything you want. Add into that the fact that there is no real win condition, just a beat-your-best-score system, and I thought I might hate it! How unbelievably wrong I was! It's cooperative and puzzley, so I was naturally inclined to like it on those 2 counts. I love trying to communicate with such limited clues, and it's equally fun on the receiving end of those clues. "If I tell him that's a 3, will he realize it's the blue 3 we need?", or on the other side, "He just told me those are both 3s, should I assume they are both the blues we need?" Now even with all this good deep think, it could still get knocked down a peg because it has that annoyance of no real win condition. Yet somehow it makes you hold onto that hope that next time might be the time you'll hit that perfect score. I am simply amazed that I am so deeply enthralled with this game, and find myself with the desire to keep trying again and again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I want to like this game more than I do.  Two-player games are great for taxing your memory but they can also be very frustrating (unless you just don't care how your display turns out).  Four-player games offer less information, resulting in more discarding or taking of chances.  

Either way (large group or small), the game can be enjoyable.  But of all the casual card games we own (Bohnanza, Timeline, For Sale, Star Fluxx, Boss Monster), this makes it out the least.

Update: Included in a trade.  Just didn't get played much and my wife wasn't a fan of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The design is fine, but I now actively despise the "game between the game", or metagame, when you try to guess what people intend with their clues. Each group forms their own "language", for lack of a better term, in which a clue in a certain context takes on a meaning that to that group becomes obvious. But for someone joining that group, with less experience, a lot of frustration develops. "Obvious" clues are misinterpreted, to the incredulity of the existing members.

Team games and partnership games with hidden information and limits on communication cause this frustration. An experienced player often cannot understand why a certain move was made, putting the teammate on the defensive. "Why did you make THAT move?!" I don't know, okay, it was the best move I could think of based on the limited information available TO ME, which don't forget is different than the information you have. Questioning why I did a move when the alternative is "obvious", you may not realise, is in fact a criticism, no matter how nicely it's said -- and I don't need that in a game I thought I was playing for fun.

Don't suggest it's the fault of the people I'm playing with. My friends are awesome in almost every game we play. But not every game encourages these experiences.

I will not play this game again, if I have any say in the matter.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2013: Gift of Guy M. Great little co-op game, original and I think unique. Refreshing to see a game so fast, full of meaningful decisions and yet co-operative in a really different way. Can't wait to make my wed night game group play it to see how it plays with four.

EDIT Oct '17: Played it at a work board game night and  my colleagues' instant enjoyment really drove the game up again in my estimation. It's so easy to teach, but it's challenging and its intervention into mechanical design is really revolutionary.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One slip can cost you points and time.  It doesn't overstay it's welcome at all, either.  Looking forward to trying again.

RATING: 8

What I don't like about coops is the sense that other people make your decisions for you, and that's much less fun.

RATING: 5
I don't really like it that much.  I never feel like I get to do much on my turn as I'm limited to playing a card or giving a clue.  When I play card, I pretty much feel like I'm just guessing which one is the best.  Maybe we just haven't figured out how to best give clues.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
An interesting and somewhat stressful cooperative deduction game. In general, I'm not find of the "you can say anything but the exact name of the card" mechanic; however, it works okay here. There is a certain amount of educated guessing in this game, which can be stressful if playing with people who are taking the game too seriously. Hanabi is certainly not in my top tier of deduction games, but it's not bad.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Unique coop card game which turns your hand around so you can't see your cards but everyone else can. You need to work as a team to give the right clues to each other to progress. Quite puzzly in some respects, but the sweetness here is in the interaction, the moments of teeth-grinding frustration when your 'obvious' clue is picked up the wring way and heart in the mouth moments as another player decides which card to discard. Great fun, really happy with this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Different.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
3 plays:

I love this game for its elegant balance of simplicity and depth. Although the rules seem a bit fiddly at first (and, typically, the instructions are very confusingly written), groups I've introduced it to enjoy it once it's up and running. Then, it's a great game for a smart group who wants to enjoy themselves. 

Intense, but not frustrating because of its cooperative nature. Tends towards some slow analysis paralysis--a group of players who don't play a lot of games made take a long time--but again that's mitigated by cooperation; you don't feel that you must take as long as the previous player to keep up. 

Definitely requires a good level of skill and abstract thinking. Expands and contracts easily from 2-8 players. 

The last group of adults I introduced to the game felt so-so about it.

RATING: 7
Es un juego de deducción, similar al cinquillo, pero tiene la novedad de que cada jugador ve las cartas de los demás, pero no las propias y tiene que pasarles información dandoles pistas. El jugador puede escoger entre dar una pista, jugar una carta o descartar. El descarte permite además recuperar pistas que son limitadas para todos los jugadores (creo que 8). Hay que formar 5 palos numerados del 1 al 5.

RATING: 8
I really get a kick out of this game, which is very light and very easy for new players to pick up. It perhaps lacks the excitement and replayability of a truly great game (every game of Hanabi tends to feel about the same). Every once in a while, though, this is a fun way to spend twenty minutes. It is quite challenging--in about 10 Hanabi games (usually with 3 players), I have never come that close to a perfect game. As always, I really enjoy the cooperative aspect. (I'm someone who loves the strategy and sociability of board games, but who is a deeply uncompetitive person!)

A seemingly simple-to-play coop game that requires players to become more thoughtful in the way they communicate, with a deduction element similar to the Espionage 2-player game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A simple and innovative concept for a cooperative game. 

I love games where you have to communicate through game elements (like the hints in this game) but that always creates the problem where you are basically supposed to have no table talk at all. It's very difficult if everybody is chatting, not to give any extra clues to the other players. Even when you're quiet, you can give clues with (maybe unintentional) mimics. Cheating a little bit like this doesn't really hurt the game though, maybe it's even the most fun part catching the little hints or seeing how another player doesn't catch one. It makes the game easier, but it's still challenging to score well.

I'm not sure if it has a high replay value though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Terrific cooperative game where you can see everyone's cards but your own. The group tries to build piles of cards from 1 to 5 in each of five colors. Since you can't see your own cards you must give clues to your partners in the form of telling how many are of a particular color or number. Players must pick up on subtle clues (perhaps you didn't receive a clue because none of your cards are playable) and synthesize the information that moves around the table in order to complete the challenge before them.

Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cool little Co-Op filler.

Hanabi is a really cool game with just a small deck of cards and a few tokens. You try to reach a certain amount of points...meh...but it's really difficult. And that's what elevates the game: relatively high difficulty for such a simple game and a very short playtime.
You just reached less then half of the points? Well let's try again.

Cool game, high quality cards and high portability for just under 5€? Perfect.

After 49 plays we finally scored a perfect game.

RATING: N/A
Abacuspeil Deluxe Edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My favorite cooperative game.

I don't usually like coops - when I play games, I want to do as well as possible.  In a coop, that often involves too much discussion and pre-planning that makes turns long and unfun.  Hanabi solves this problem entirely by restricting the ways in which you are allowed to communicate.  Other games, like Space Alert, have solved this problem with time constraints - while I love Space Alert, Hanabi is just more elegant.

There are also fun information-theoretic considerations, here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This controlled information sharing, and the lack of knowledge in regards to your own cards, results in possibly the most cooperative game I've ever played. Not only can you not tell others what to do, but you have to rely on the information others give you in order to play your cards.

This game involves a lot of learning about your play partners. Some people tell you you have a red card so that you'll play it, some people tell you so that you'll dump it. Some people throw away the first card to the left, some the first card to the right. We don't talk about our reasons for communication and we discover them during play, although I suppose the game could be made easier by discussing strategies before play starts.

You have to trust your play partners. They told you about a particular card and not about another? You have to trust that they gave you the most important information first.

You also have to learn how to use the red tokens. There are three and you get the same score with zero, one, or two of them used, so having zero of them used, might indicate something you threw away that you should have tried to play.

You have to learn how to use the blue tokens. There are only so many of them and getting down to one often puts you in a nasty pattern of discarding good cards because you can't keep each other informed. You have to maximize the information you give the other players so that by combining the informations they get, they can learn about their hand with as few tokens used as possible.

You have to keep track of the discards to know what's safe to lose, and to figure out what you have in your hand.

You have to learn to prioritize what you need to tell your partners. Ideally they'll know their entire hand, but since that's impossible, what do they need to know first, and what can you afford to never tell them about?

The game is easy to learn, but hard to master. My best game to date? 24. And even if we ever get the game of 25, the perfect game, there's still the advanced game after that. This game has plenty of replayability.

Having played the game online, I can testify to two things, one, playing the game without having the remember anything and without having to worry about what others remember, is a lot more fun because you can then make very clever clue gives. Two, it is so much more fun to play the game with people you know.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another one of those games that I love more than my typical gaming group (my family). Deductive masterpiece. Much better than Sleuth or Code.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.6
interesting game. nice co-op play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This makes the act of trying to communicate with your friends and turns it into a game. If that doesn't sound fun to you, you probably won't enjoy this. But I enjoy it quite a bit.

This is one of the first co-op games I've played that doesn't feel like it might as well just be a solo game. I wouldn't quite call this a brain burner - but certainly it could go that direction if you let yourself think about all the possible implications of everything you/your teammates do - I just think of it as having a pleasant puzzley feel. The rules and goals are simple, but there's a LOT to think about.

It's funny how you can psych yourself out just by trying to figure out how to give out information, or double-guess everything people do trying to gleam some extra meaning from their plays.

Luck is obviously a factor, so I appreciate that it's beat-your-highscore rather than pass/fail. The difference between playing well and playing poorly is a matter of skill, but the difference between playing a good game and a perfect one is a matter of luck.

I could see how some people might see the system as easily broken by coming up with conventions and agreeing to them as a group, but that goes against the spirit of the game.

Since it is a puzzley kind of game this might not have the staying power of other fillers, but definitely one of the more unique and interesting games you can play while it lasts.

Update: YES! FINALLY! Perfect score! (Without rainbows)

Current High Score with Rainbows: 25. 8/27/2015

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hanabi is such a brilliantly designed game that you wonder why it wasn't invented before 2010! It's a coop, but unlike many coops where you can play them solo, this one needs 2-5 players. The reason is that you're giving clues to each other about which cards you have in your hand - and the catch is that you're holding your cards outwards, so you cannot see them yourself, but everybody else can! This is truly a unique game, and the fact that I've played it more than a 100 times says a lot as that's rare for me!

The rules are simple and the gameplay is easy to understand as well, but not easy to play well... You need to be inside each other's heads when giving clues if you want to win (well, that is score the maximum of 25 points at least; "winning" is very easy, but getting 25 points is not)! It's so hard to give great clues, and you can only hope to win if you do give some clues that tell more than just the thing you're actually saying... It takes many plays to refine how you give and receive clues, and of course that also requires the same group of people. This can lead to some group think (which way to discard from etc.), but I haven't found it too much of a problem. If anything, it's actually even more "annoying" when playing with new players who don't understand your obviously great clues... ;) 

There is almost nothing more satisfying than finally getting those damn 25 points! I've only done it 10 times, but a couple of times it's been very close as well, and you can see that you get better each time. 

The theme isn't that interesting, but I don't care as I see it purely as an abstract game, at which it excels! Oh, I do have to mention that, like almost everybody else, we play it that you can ask "what do you remember" before giving a clue; not that you are allowed to confirm what they're saying, so if they're way off you have to give a clue, but in order for the game not to rely too much on memory and, more importantly, on what you think the other persons are still remembering... I think it's way more fun played this way, but ymmv.

In any case, it's a great game that I can never see myself getting rid of!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.4
Good little game. The tin it comes in sucks. The tin is a terrible terrible tin. The bits fall out everywhere and all sorts. The actual game is an interesting one in that it is a very thoughtful game (as in, you need to think a lot) but with the odd bashful comment or slip of tounge, the whole thing can come crashing down. Once you get the players to agree that there is a certain way TOO play this game, and a certain way to NOT play this game, that's where the game loses some of its charm. Try not to formalise it too much and it will repay you with a fun 45 minutes in thanks.

[b]AVOID THE RULES[/b] ([COLOR=#FF0000][b]A V[/b][/COLOR]ideo [COLOR=#FF0000][b]O[/b][/COLOR]f [COLOR=#FF0000][b]I[/b][/COLOR]nstruction & [COLOR=#FF0000][b]D[/b][/COLOR]emonstration [COLOR=#0000FF][b]T[/b][/COLOR]hat [COLOR=#0000FF][b]H[/b][/COLOR]elps [COLOR=#0000FF][b]E[/b][/COLOR]ase [COLOR=#FF0000][b]R[/b][/COLOR]ule [COLOR=#FF0000][b]U[/b][/COLOR]nderstanding & [COLOR=#FF0000][b]L[/b][/COLOR]earning - [COLOR=#FF0000][b]E[/b][/COLOR]asy [COLOR=#FF0000][b]S[/b][/COLOR]tart!)

[u]BGG:[/u] http://boardgamegeek.com/video/40178/hanabi/hanabi-avoid-the-rules-by-connect-more
[u]YouTube:[/u] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LOWPO8wF3AI

[thing=98778][/thing] is a [b]cooperative card game [/b]. Players work together to place five suites/colors of cards in ascending numerical order from 1-5 (without repeating or skipping any numbers). Cards are held so that they are only visible to the other players; players do know their own cards! In this way, typical card game mechanics such as [b]hand management[/b] and [b]set collection[/b] become a cooperative affair, which introduces a unique and highly engaging level of [b]deduction, memory[/b], and [b]press your luck[/b] elements into the game. 

On his/her turn a player may give a numerical OR a color clue to another player, play a card, or discard a card. Constant evaluation and adjustment to communication styles, cooperative team work, a sharp memory, and a little luck are required to win.

******************************************
When looking for a great game to introduce people to the board game hobby I have a few guidelines that I usually stick to:

1. Game must have short instruction time. You need to be playing quick, before they lose interest.

2. The game should play in a short time period as well. I always want to give them the opportunity to ask to play again, or an exit point if it simply was not for them.

3. Social interaction. The game must be interactive and engage people socially. If there are any 'take that' mechanics/interactions in the game, they should be light hearted.

4. Something readily available. Everyone (who enjoyed it) always wants to know where they can find this new game because you hear things like, "we should take this to your parent's cabin next weekend", or "that would be great for Christmas," or whatever...

5. I solved #4 by usually just leaving the game with them to keep. So, the game has to be relatively cheap. My goal is to introduce the non-gamers to the game, but let them become gamers in their own time. Hard to do that if they don't have a (good) game available to do so!

6. # of people. Usually you are pretty safe with a 4 player game. 

[b]Hanabi![/b] is an awesome game for all of the above reasons!

RATING: 6
Innovative co-op.  Different than everything else I own.  Nice deduction mechanisms too.  It is almost a social experiment to see how groups of players teach each other and learn from each other how to get as much information as possible out of one clue.  It can lose its luster when players cheat (you have a one here and HERE), but even those observations are fascinating to watch unfold.

RATING: 6.5
I just don't play this that often because you have to find juuust the right group to make it work. As it turns out, that perfect group for me was a group of Aspie teenagers. We had a lot of fun being overly literal with the rules and finding all sorts of ways to edge the line and arguably break the rules...well sometimes blatantly and horribly. What's not fun--when people are way too focused on following the rules to the T. What's also not fun--when people cheat and push those boundaries non-stop. Basically, you have to know that this game comes with blurry rules that are hard to enforce consistently. The game is decidedly cooperative but in a different and (can be!) fun way. The ability to roll with the unique flow of the game is central to having an enjoyable experience. For me, I have had a couple of really fun games and a few more meh type of games.

RATING: 6

Hmm  already feels like been there done that but it was addictive while I was chasing a top score.
This game is addictive but unsatisfying - especially when it takes way too long to play and once you start you don't play anything else.
I will not likely play again.

RATING: 10
Hanabi really did surprise me: The game looks rather dull and after reading the rules I almost had it written off as yet another slightly boring cooperative game. I was wrong. Well, the game still looks dull and of course the theme is as arbitrary as it can ever get. But I have A LOT of fun playing this game! It feels like some sort of multiplayer "Master Mind" and I've always been a fan of this kind of deduction games. I do however need a notepad to make a scrib sheet about my own cards as the game progresses - because I hate "Memory" as much as I like "Master Mind". Also you should be warned that playing this game will inevitably lead to a discussion about what is considered cheating the game. But as the rules put it: As long as you're having fun playing the game, you're doing it right. Update: And now I officially like a "Spiel des Jahres", who'd have thought of that ever happening again? (This is for the ABACUSSPIELE (2012) edition.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hanabi is likely going to be the only SdJ-winning game I own after the SdJ went 'soft' (which happened after the Torres disaster). It is beautiful as well as intruiging how such a simple change—card reversal—coupled to strict hint procedures can create such good tension between the players.

That said, I'm going to be a little conservative with the rating as I susect that once the players have worked out a good hint strategy (which would only involve making use of the time a card entered one's hand—it makes sense to keep track of this although no verbal clues whatsoever are exchanged) it becomes all a rather formulaic procedure to see if the formulae can solve the particular state of the card deck. It still isn't easy to get a perfect score then, and your memory mustn't fail... but still proceeding according to a fixed formula. If such a convention is not adopted, or the players do not make use of time information, then the game is more lax, and more fun to play with non-gamers. It is for those circumstances, to see people learn what is needed, that I award the game the rate I gave it. Once it is 'solved', you can deduct 1 point from the rate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Hanabi is the Rubik`s cube of the gaming world. Delightfully different and most people will at first glance think it`s an easy game to solve. Unfortunatly this game suffers from the human condition known as the inflated ego. Any person with a normal sense of self esteem will say "How hard can it be to reach a legendary score?" and then proceed to cheat through their teeth to prove that it`s not unsolvable. With kids/teenagers this type of behavior is frowned upon and accepted. In grown ups it becomes down right embarrassing. My definition of a good co-op includes the communication that ensues while players discuss different options available to them as a team. Hanabi is tooooo restricted in this respect. It was a pleasant diversion , but not something
with a lasting appeal , unless players can somehow play by the real rules: "No subliminal messages or exaggerated
facial expressions permitted". Experienced "Bridge" players will understand the dilemma this game faces.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Cooperative
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Despite some missteps in our first play, I could see the interesting game underneath.  In the age of cooperative games, this is unique with its deductive element.

Very simply, the group is trying to play as many cards in each of 5 colors in order.  But you can't look at your own cards, and other players have to sacrifice a play to give out a clue - and you only get so many of those.  Clues can only be of two types - which of your cards are a color, or which are a number.

Incredibly tough, but hard to not want another go when you've finished a play.  I'll give it a try again soon, I'm sure.

REVISED: The more we play, the more I enjoy it.  This is a game that's as serious as the group wants to make it, which is a good scalable factor in party games.

RATING: 8
Antoine Bauza at it again. This guy always impresses me on how different his games are. Hanabi is a fantastic value for the $10ish dollar mark. I was surprised at how much tension can develop from such a simple to explain game. Note I said simple to explain, the execution is much harder. We have yet to build all 5 displays but seem to get better with each play. Always fun to play with someone new because they don't have the past experience or know why/how you give the clues. I have yet to play it with a larger group but I bet it would be fun. We play it at lunch at work because it is fairly quick, instant setup and full of game for such a small package.

RATING: 6

What Are My Cards Again?/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A co-operative game that, through hidden information and heavy limitations on the passing of information, actually requires the unique perspectives of multiple players. This, in my limited experience, is rare: all other co-op games I've played have effectively been solitaire games played by multiple people at once.

The game itself is fairly simple, and the outcome will be heavily influenced by the players' level of restrictions on communication, vocal reasoning, reminders of previous clues, and discarding conventions: 'no passing information outside clue actions' can be very broadly interpreted. 

The random order of the deck can doom some games: there are some combinations that are impossible to do well with (all the 1s at the bottom would be an extreme but technically possible example). The caprices of the deck, and the difficulty of policing communication, make it difficult to judge the extent to which an improvement in performance is down to skill.

Hanabi is nonetheless a very fun, short and light game that offers some challenge, no matter what level of strictness a group settles on (as long as they're consistent).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is a great filler game that can take over a game night.  Rewards multiple plays with the same group.  Highly frustrating game when your partners misinterpret clues you give them or forget about previous clues you gave them.  Always devastating to get cut off from completing a certain number.  There's also a serious amount of deduction in this game which means paying attention to everyone's hand and what is in the discard pile is a must for giving good clues or figuring out what color that 5 is in your hand!  Highly recommend this game to everyone.

RATING: 8
this game... far better at 3 players than at any other player count!

it's like therapy. a cooperative game where no player has all the information. to get better scores, you have to trust each other more! which means that you will have to relinquish control to the other players, and trust that they will make good decisions. because they know the one thing that you don't (which is also the one thing that you want to know more than anything): they know what cards you hold.

this game builds so many good things on the inside. make sure you play this gem!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
HANABI

SUMMARY:
It's Team Co-op Solitaire where you are the only one who doesn't know what your cards are.

PROS:
• Hanabi is super-easy to learn. There are not that many rules to get confused by.
• The "Indian Poker" mechanic, whereby everyone knows your cards except for you, is fantastically executed. Just going through the rules with new players is enough to get people interested in playing the game, because the mechanic is generally unheard of outside of the "Who Am I?" game.
• The game can be changed to accommodate many different levels of difficulty. It can be made more easy by adding additional Note Tokens, or by adding the Rainbow cards as "Wild" cards. On the other end of the spectrum, it can be made increasingly more difficult by removing Note Tokens, by adding the Rainbow cards as a sixth suit, or by adding the Rainbow cards as a sixth suit with the rule that they need to be described as belonging to any other color (meaning it is very difficult to tell if the "Red" card you are about to play is not actually a Rainbow). The difficulty can be enforcing the level of table-talk that can go on — for example, banning (or permitting) the emphasis people place on their hints ("You have a two HEEEERE... and here") or on the faces people are allowed to make as someone begins to play a card.
• The atmosphere around the table is incredibly tense. There are literally not enough Hint Tokens to get a complete picture of what you have in your hand. Almost every play you make will be based on trust, and the ability of the group to give time-appropriate hints ("Why would you tell me I have a two if you didn't want me to play it now??"). It's hard to describe how exciting such a simple little card game can be.
• There is a lot of strategy to be had, thanks to the fact that your group will burn through Hint Tokens very quickly. You will want to prioritize telling your teammates what cards to play soon (that red-4 we are waiting to play now), the cards they must never discard (all the 5's), and which cards are safe to discard in exchange for more Hint Tokens (in the late game, these will be low-level cards). This is not a simple game with only one "correct" move.
• Unlike other cooperative games, Hanabi prevents "quarterbacking" from occurring, whereby one player dictates to all the others what the "best" move to make is. Since everyone only has partial information, true cooperation is a must.

CONS:
• I found the artwork to be a little lackluster in all of the Hanabi versions released (with the exception of Hanabi Deluxe, which has minimalistic designs on their brick-like dominoes). The art itself is not bad... but it is very repetitive, as the same temple drawing is present at the base of every single card, front and back — I get what they were going for, but I feel like the individual card designs could be far more beautiful and do not live up to their full potential.
• The designers decided to make the sets of fireworks always at around the same size on the card (so Red-2 has two very large fireworks, while Red-5 has 5 smaller-sized fireworks), and this can make it harder to use the artwork to tell how much the card is worth. People tend to use only the numbers in the corner.
• Probably the worst design decision (in the Abacusspiele version, at least) are the colors used for Green/Blue. In dim lighting, they are nearly identical. This is remedied by the fact that each suit is represented by a unique character under the numbers, in addition to its unique color. However, the green really needs to be just a few shades brighter.
• Hanabi is an abstract game... basically any theme could be applied to it, and it could even be played with regular playing cards. This, in and of itself, is not a bad thing — however, it appears that the designers WANTED to give the game a theme (of sorts) by having us impress a crowd of onlookers at a Japanese palace... so I do not feel like it is unwarranted for me to say that the theme they applied isn't done in a very cohesive manner that makes the mechanics easier to grasp for new players. So... we are building a fireworks show, but for some reason only our friends know the colors of the fireworks we are holding? What exactly are we doing, from a thematic perspective? It is not explained in the rulebook.
• The box (for the Abacusspiele version, at least) is at least twice the size it needs to be. Half of the box fits all of the cards, while the 12 tokens go in the rest of the box. So jostling the box mixes up all the tokens with the cards. I suggest you make some sort of insert or token-box to separate things. That said, the box is very small (the size of an Uno box), so it's not a big deal. However, the fact is that the game could very easily be adapted to a 72-card deck (with the tokens replaced by 12 cards) and this would make it significantly easier to transport.

CONCLUSION:
• Hanabi is surprisingly tense, and there is a lot of challenge even in the Basic game, without the addition of the Rainbow Cards.
• The many different game modesthat come in the box provides tons of replayability, and the fact that the variants are already included in the box (and are not some kind of "expansion" that needs to be bought separately) is greatly appreciated. Because the cards are simplistically designed, players can invent their own variants, or mix-and-match, to create even more difficult challenges.
• Some design decisions are a bit lacking, but it is certainly not an "ugly" game by any stretch of the imagination.
• This is an incredibly fun game for how small it is, and for its incredibly cheap price (less than $10) there is no reason not to have this on-hand for your next get-together.

★★★★★★★★★☆ 9/10

RATING: 5
Cooperative game of knowing how to give hints and how to interpret them. Tension from having a limited number of hints, and restrictions on how to give them. Players cannot see their own cards, only the cards of other players. On his turn, he can either play a card (and hope it is playable), discard a card (and reset one hint token), or give one hint to another player. 

Clever game, but requires too much skill in memory, of which I lack.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros:
- Great introduction to modern board and card games. Challenging for gamers but simple to teach and learn for newbies.

- Unique combination of hidden information and cooperation

- Plays relatively quickly.


Cons:
- No expansion and the only variant is adding an extra color to up the challenge which is good but that is pretty much it.

- Players must be mindful of accidental cheating by giving extra information through table talk.

- Memory element may not be to everyone's liking. Adjusting cards in hand can help.

- The colors are a bit hard to see in low lighting and the Japanese characters are not always the easiest to use for colorblind players.


The positives of this game as a gateway game to the hobby can't be understated. Fair price and compact packaging make this an easy on-the-go game as well.

Very taxing and challenging. Requires good teamwork skills.

RATING: 6
This is a decently fun cooperative card game that is quick and easy to teach. This would go great with families and friends who don't do much gaming. The only thing I don't like about the game is that, although it's cool that communication between players is limited, it's difficult to prevent non-verbal communication and other unintentional "giveaways" about what move to make (or not to make). It's not that big of a deal, but if you're bothered by ambiguous rules about what is and isn't acceptable in terms of rules or behavior, this may not be a game you would like.

RATING: 6
Nice little filer game.  Portable, and easy to play anywhere.  As a person who generally dislikes cooperative games, I can say that there is something enjoyable here.  A simple task of counting to 5 made difficult by reversing the way you hold your cards.  This game fixes my main gripe with coop: the experienced players tell the others what to do.  The rules to this game make that impossible.  Not a lot of replay value once you reach a high score, even with the multicolored cards added in.  Game can easily be broken by developing a system with other players, i.e. giving subtle clues without using the clue markers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After my first game, I couldn't decide whether I loved the game, or whether I hated it. It sure is stressful. After a few more plays, I can confirm that I love it. This is NOT a casual filler, despite it's size. It takes too long to play to be a true filler. It also requires constant attention. This is not one to play while you're trying to carry on a conversation. But I love the challenge.

RATING: 9
[12-19-2012 Rating: n.a. -> 9]
Right after reading the first review of Hanabi, I knew that I wanted to own this one and my plays confirmed my suspicion. Hanabi is a great co-op with a brilliantly simple mechanic based on deduction and limited communication. By restricting the communication, Bauza managed to elimate the typical "one player rules all" problem of so many co-ops. Everyone is involved throughout the whole game, facing difficult decisions every turn. In short: I do really, really like Hanabi.

But be warned: There are some people in my play group who are somewhat cluesless when we play Hanabi and, as a result, they don't enjoy it. But for the price that this game is sold, you can even risk a blind buy. Two thumbs up for Hanabi.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Personally, I prefer the square-shaped cards in this version more than the traditional rectangular-shaped cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My wife would rate this game a 10.  I have two problems with it that drop the score for me.  First, the amount of concentration required to play well is at odds with the weight of the game for me.  When I play a co-op I want a social experience with my friends and this game discourages casual conversation.  Second, it is group dependent.  For the best experience you want to have repeated plays with the same group and the game can be tanked by a single player not paying attention. Solid game but situational

The worst part about the game - it's very antisocial. Your communication is limited so you have to be in a very zen state of mind to play. Also people will get irritated at others for "bad plays or clues" but just play with a good group!

RATING: 7
I don't know why I have to make a seperate entry for Hanabi from Hanabi & Ikebana.  Strange.  In any case, Hanabi is a very fine game that is often made less fun by what people bring to it.  Played on its surface level, I really enjoy the "what can I tell everyone when" aspect.  However, once loaded down with conventions, conventions that truly do help you score more points, it just becomes a pointless exercise in memorization.  I much prefer to play the game cleanly and let the chips fall where they may.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players are working together to present a high scoring fireworks display.  Cooperative game where players are dealt out a hand of cards.  Cards are in five suits, numbered between 1 and 5.  On your turn you can either play a card (blindly) from your hand (you never see what you are holding); give a hint about another player's hand; or discard a card and draw a new one.  The amount of clues that can be given is controlled by flipping a token, which can only be flipped back when a card is discarded.  Playing a card to one of the five stacks successfully is what you want - you only get two chances to be incorrect before you lose the game.  Fun game, feels quite different, but very engaging.  A cooperative game that highlights the game play, and doesn't give any power to the loudest at the table.  I liked it.

The mechanics are awesome, and it is definitely worth some critical acclaim, but it feels really group dependent for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A very original mechanic, but honestly, not much fun.  This game is both very interactive yet not interactive at all because you really can’t just sit back and casually enjoy the game play with your fellow gamers.  Its a social game, yet you can’t be social during the game; you have to be focused and remain diligent the whole time which can create an uncomfortable atmosphere.   When it comes down to it, its just a memory game, that’s all.  
And almost every time we’ve played it in places without very bright lighting, there are serious problems with the colors and its hard to tell some cards apart.  Because I know Japanese, I sometimes had to rely on the kanji characters to tell the cards apart.    
I’ve found the game to be very divisive at game meets.  There are those people that want to play it over and over again, and those that despise it.  I could take it or leave it, but usually I’ll pass on playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Extremely unique game by Antoine Bauza of 7 Wonders fame. It provides a true coop experience without the alpha leader problem. It plays quick and reaches a variety of audiences.

[b]1.14.13 Update:[/b] This game is still a joy every time it comes out. I love the tension and anticipation of each play. The only downside is when varied experience levels mix. Nevertheless, my rating on this one may be taking a leap upward soon.

[b]7.22.13 Update:[/b] This game continues to provide an experience not found anywhere else. Ridiculously good. Rating goes up with no ceiling in sight.

[b]9.29.15 Update:[/b] Numerous more fun plays and this finally debuts on my top 10. Bam!

[b]Rating History:[/b]
< 12.31.12 ~ 8.00
7.22.13 = 8.50
9.29.15 = 9.00

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The game is all about getting the perfect score. When I first learned the game, I really don't get it why people lost to the game. I thought they lose because there did 3 mistakes (so game over) or it's just hard to figure out what card to play.

It turned out that the game is difficult due to the fact that the game ends before they could make the 5 groups of cards (to get perfect score).

Players get the idea of what cards/colours they're holding, it's just that they didn't have enough time to play it down.

So in summary, it's all about creating the 5 groups of cards in less number of turn, that's the key of the game. You waste your time, and boom the deck is finished, and you're only left with one more turn before the game completely ends.

[b]Status: Homebrewed. Project completed on May 2013[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.56
Challenging, cooperative, counter-intuitive card game. The goal is to build stacks of fireworks of different colours but the trick is that you can not see your own cards, only those of other players. By giving simple hints in turn order during limited number of rounds you work together to collect as many points as you can. 
It is slightly difficult in the beginning to stop looking at the card when you draw.
Also, game is not easy and it is not very sociable due to limited number of information you are allowed to give to each other, but it is still fun and rewording.

[b]Update:[/b] Playing with more serious players multiple times gives a really rewarding experience. Upgraded to 8.7 from 7.5
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Cooperative limited information optimization.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
fine family game. Build sets with the catch that only your team mates can see your hand and must spend limited resources to give you information on your cards. Cringe when a needed card gets discarded by mistake, rejoice when a blind play works out perfectly. Very light and a bit limited due to the communication rules.

RATING: 8
Az idei SdJ nyertes. Kis kártyás volta ellenére. Nos úgy gondolom megérdemelte kisebbsége ellenére nagy játék. Nem bonyolult, logikai, dedukciós játék. (Gyakorlatilag a modern kártyás Cluedo :-).) Gyors, kényelmes partik, mondjuk figyelni kell az elszólásokra, illetve a mondatokra, de kellemes játék. Mondjuk lehetett volna közepes dobozos is, ha adnak hozzá 5 db kártyatartót :-).
A partik fél óra alatt vannak még 5 fővel is. És mivel kis játék nem is drága. (Ellentétben pl. a 2 évvel ezelőtti nyertes a Kingdom Builderssel, ami nagy dobozos játékhoz képest is k* drága)
Szóval kezdőknek, illetve profiknak le- és bevezető játéknak tökéletes, igazából teljesen megfelel ennek a jelenlegi SdJ felfogásnak: gyors szórakoztató, egyszerű.

RATING: 7
It's weird to rate this so high given my own personal scale, but I want to give Hanabi a fair shake because it does exactly what I want it to do - provide a fun game that is highly accessible to non-gamers.  It took a long time to get this to any table, but the takers were my parents and they loved every moment of it.  For me, such a thing is incredibly precious as it allows me to share at least some aspect of this hobby with them.

It's a good game for those times where you're not really looking to commit to something long or deep - but are looking for a game nonetheless.

RATING: 6.9
whilst co-operative games would not rank amongst my favourites, contrary to popular belief, I will play them -- and this is one of the best, easy, to play and yet so difficult to master and complete -- what clues are the best -- can your colleagues pick up on your intelligent hints (and especially vice versa) -- hopefully no one will stay angry at each other at the conclusion (you gave me such a STUPID hint!) .. lovely artwork, but at times the differing colour cards tend to meld into one another -- make sure you play in absolute high lighting to distinguish colours

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What an elegant cooperative game with a very unique mechanism!  Players are trying to complete fireworks in the correct (numerical) sequence and color set.  The catch is that you hold your cards facing outwards so that you can see what everyone else has, but not your own hand.  The decision of which card to play or discard must be made with the information of what another player has (or hasn't) told you about the cards you are holding.  The rules are simple, but the game is tense and exciting.  The short play time and fun will have you wanting to replay it to best your previous scores.  Definitely recommended as a great filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is a card co-op that uses numbers and suits.  You'll have a hand of cards but you can't see your own cards, only the hand of cards the other players have.  The objective is play cards in sequential order for each of the 5 suits in the game (6 if you want to play hard mode) or as best as you can.  On your turn you choose between 1 of three options: give information to another player about their hand (which can be done sparingly), discard a card which allows you to give more information in future turns, and play a card which you need to do to win.  This is largely a memory game, but it's one of the few of that I actually enjoy.  Games are also quick and can be finished in about 20-ish minutes.  In the end it's leaving my collection because I don't like how it's usually pretty easy to "win" but extremely difficult to get get a perfect score... sick of always getting 20-ish.

Edit: Dropping the rating on this after having played Beyond Baker Street, which I consider a vastly superior product.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I learned this game last year (2012) at BGG.con. To me it was my favorite game I learned there. It plays out feeling a lot like the contract version of bridge, but it is much more then that. Best at four players, your work together to help each other make plays and avoid discarding vital cards. You know all the cards but your own, which makes it the best cooperative game I know (and the only one I like), avoiding a strong leader issue. The game presents itself as a constant logic problem where each player has a unique set of information.

Most people either love it or hate it. The game is incredibly deep, but beginners can play as well. Easy to learn, very hard to master. A lot of games just stop midway, so you can discuss the situation and how clues should have been given to handle it, which is awesome. The people who taught me, would write down situations that arose during to game to discuss afterwards.

If you feel the game is getting to easy (good luck), there are additional cards you can add to adjust the game play. All and all the game is great and pretty much infinitely re-playable.

After a few games, you learn to finesse plays and even bluff. Once you are really feeling good, you can try to play without table talk, or at least give shame tokens to people who might inadvertently give additional clues. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

RATING: 8
Hanabi presents one of the most interesting gaming experiences that i've had.  At first glance it is just a small deck of cards and some tokens but oh man there is a lot of game in that tiny box! Quarterbacking is eliminated since you can't really communicate which fixes the biggest flaw of co-op games! This game is really tough as well! I'm not usually a "beat your high score" kind of gamer but it is so satisfying when it happens in Hanabi!  The game also scales really well and is fun with any player count.  Oh, and it is super cheap!  Definitely a great buy!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Brilliant, cheap, ultra-portable short co-op.  This is best if you're going to play with the same group multiple times and have some conventions emerge to help you.  That said, it will still fascinate a thoughtful group of newbies even on their first play.

Bonus: this co-op can't be quarter-backed (i.e. one person cannot run the whole thing and boss the other players as to what their moves should be).  This is in part because the rules do not permit such communication, but is also because no one person has access to all of the information about the game state (until, perhaps, it can be deduced right at the end, when it's anyway too late).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Gift from my gorgeous Secret Santa
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I had heard this game was amazing and -- amazingly -- it lived up to its billing. A great coop that is easy to teach and enjoyable to play thanks to the tension created by the limited allowable communication. 

We don't play it as a memory game, we allow each other to be reminded of what we've been told and we splay the discarded cards out for people to see. So far that has worked great because it puts the emphasis on deduction and educated guesses rather than memory (which we all don't seem to be interested in here). Ultimately, though, it's a communication game where everyone is vying to see who can give and pick up on the subtlest of clues.

I knock a half point off its rating for the fact that it's not possible to play the game the exact same way among different groups of people. It's tough to adjudicate what is acceptable conversation, and once somebody says something inappropriate or accidentally sees one of their cards, there's no going back.

RATING: 5

I like playing with people about 3 times.  After that, the game's usually done.  I have yet to get a perfect score, and I'm okay with that.

RATING: 8

RATING: N/A
[b]Sold 7/9/2017[/b] - We picked up Beyond Baker Street a while ago, and I can't imagine wanting to play the nearly-themeless "try to get the best score you can" Hanabi instead of the defined win conditions of BBS.  The original idea in Hanabi was pretty nifty, but Beyond Baker Street took that and built more of a game on top of it.

Also, one of the things that I find most frustrating about Hanabi is that it often devolves into either memorizing a specific set of rules about how to give and interpret the clues, or people trying to slyly "cheat" the rules with wink wink, nudge nudge types of hints.  BBS suffers the same problem but at least there's a bit more game to it.

RATING: 7
Really interesting co-operative game where you don't know what you hold but can see others hands. 

Relatively simple mechanically you either play a card, discard a card and gain a time, or play a time and give someone else a piece of information.

Theme could have been anything really but fireworks do fit and the fuse as a timer is suitable thematic.

This is great with 3 players but I think would be too chaotic with more than 3 and a will avoid playing with 5. 

I like the addition of several varients in the box.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Elegant and simple. Really clever "little" cooperative game based on deduction and limited communication. I really like it and the really intense feeling that builds up during a successfull game (when somehow a kind of "bond" is created among the players). Might make for a great team-building tool, but...

... some people are, like, totally cluless in this kind of game. Can create akward situations.

Further, experience and especially common experience among a given group is important to beat the challenge; hence games grouping experienced players with newbies tend to be frustating for the formers (well, not if they play specifically to introduce the game to new players of course).

Overall, Hanabi is a very smart and fun little game that fills a void that we never knew was there : that of a short but challenging cooperative game. Further, it uses a very nice twist on the way that information is shared around the table and avoids the main drawback of classic coops : no "leader" can emerge. I like it a lot.

Tis'
March 2012
5 plays so far.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game that can be played at whatever depth the players want -- light and wonderfully maddening, or deep and subtle (and yes, this requires the players to agree and respect the spirit of the thing). The first thought I had after playing Hanabi for the first time was "how is it this game was not invented thousands of years ago?" Elegant, original, timeless.
An added note: Of course there is luck involved in even approaching a high score, but claiming there is more memory to the game than deduction suggests to me that those commenters weren't playing with the right group of people. The 'when' of a piece of information can be critical, and quite subtle if people are paying attention. If there's a criticism that hits home, it's about the difficulty of keeping players from divulging extra information, or at least being 'reasonable' about this sort of thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Pros
-innovative card game with hidden information
-promotes teamwork yet avoids alpha gamer problem and still makes you think
-fairly quick and simple game, supports variable number of players
-changeable difficulty levels, easy to implement variants

Cons
-requires a minimum number of players (I believe 3)
-some people might find it stressful
-game can be difficult for some groups
-game is somewhat vague on what you are and are not allowed to do in terms of giving information
-not an inherent flaw in the game, but players are expected to keep certain information secret, game can be ruined by someone who is not careful and says something
