=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is one of those games that's so simple and straightforward that you wonder how it didn't get invented 100 years ago.  Everyone has a hand of cards but they're held backwards so that you can't see your own, only everyone else's.  Then you work together giving each other clues about the colors and numbers on the cards so that they can be played in sequence to joint groups on the table.  I found this to be more fun than I thought it would be, but I don't think it will have the staying power that most other card games do.

The regular game is hard enough to get a perfect score in, but it also comes with some additional cards used for an advanced version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Unique cooperative card game in which players try to build straights in five different suits. The problem is that you get to see the hands of your fellow players but not your own. Players may however give a limited amount of hints to each other to help deduce the cards held.

Consequently it features a very strong memory element because you need to remember previous hints given and where you actually put those cards in your hand. It certainly is not a card game to play lightly and with only fleeting attention on the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Forget about the theme - it could deal with a shrubberies market or larches gardens. 

Cooperative card game with ultra-simple rules, short and funny to play, although it seems impossible to win if rules are strictly followed without personal interpretations, gestures or conventions between experienced players in the same group. Anyway, I like it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2014-03-03: Bauza's own comment nails the crux of it: how strictly you police the rules makes it easily adaptable to different groups of players. It's quick-playing, full of decisions*, extremely simple to teach, and has that vital component of being fun to play in public because it weirds people out that you're holding your hand round the wrong way. Cheap too.

*it can be frustrating those times you end up knowing nothing at all about your hand, of course, but I'm sure you can cope

EDIT, 2014-10-07: I admit, I've lost enthusiasm for this a bit since playing it for the 10x10 challenge. 8 -> 7.

RATING: 8
A much better game than I thought it would be. In fact it is enjoyable to play. Players do need to pay attention to all the hints given - not just their own. Also some conventions of play are needed if you are not to lose (e.g. fill from one side of your hand and discard from the other). The important thing is to not take the conventions as far as some partnership card games like Bridge (where I believe the bidding is just condoned cheating).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Many cooperative games feel like they artificially limit the sharing of information in an attempt to make them more difficult, but this one does it very naturally since it is the crux of the game.
Due to the severely limited information, it is amazing that what and when you are told information is almost equally important to the times you are given no information at all.

I am somewhat surprised to find that it plays better with fewer players (where players have more cards in hand) due to the limited information that can be shared between four or more players.

(24 plays)
First Impressions: 7

> 60 - Zacatrus Square L (80 x 80) N.SM ??
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
PROS:
-Se aprende a jugar enseguida
-Se puede graduar la dificultad (5 colores, 6 colores, 5 colores y multicolor y cambio en el número de cartas del sexto color)
-Se puede moldear en función del esfuerzo cognitivo que se quiera hacer (por ejemplo, puede hacerse válido recordar las pistas ya dadas)
-Cuenta con reglas avanzadas que mejoran el juego (uso de finesas, convenciones acerca de la posición de las cartas nuevas y antiguas, etc)
-Ocupa muy poco espacio
-Se monta y se recoge en unos segundos
-Sin efecto líder
-Adaptado para daltónicos, gracias a los símbolos que acompañan a los colores
-Cuenta con muchas versiones (caja normal, edición de bolsillo, lata cuadrada...)

CONTRAS:
-Es necesario enfundar las cartas, ya que si una de ellas se marca inutilizará el juego

-Los niños necesitarán un atril para poner las cartas y jugar con comodidad

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is my first review of a game because Hanabi deserves it.
Lets get the main con out of the way first.  My rating of 9.5 is because this game might (emphasis on might) have a lifespan after which I will no longer play it regularly. However, as an $8-10 game it has already surpassed my expectations by far and if I never played it again I would still be -extremely- happy with the purchase.
For clarity, my group plays this game strictly deductional, not memorization. If a clue has been given, that person can be given the information again. We try to remember on our own, but we aren't going to force the issue as long as the clue-giver remembers exactly what clue was given. This is especially helpful after playing 3 or 4 games in a row.
So, my story with Hanabi begins with an impulse buy at B&N. The wife and I played it a couple times, enjoyed it, got OK scores (16-18ish) and then shelved it for a while. We later got it out again when we needed a quick, easy closer game for game night, and from there it was magic.
We played one game, and a particularly excitable gamer in our group was determined that we would get 25, the max score.
I scoffed at this comment. We haven't even been close. We played a couple more games, and we were convinced that the cards must be in perfect order in the deck to achieve the max score. We even considered playing the game with all hands revealed just to see if it was possible (we didn't do it though, thankfully.)
Next game day, we get Hanabi out again. Obviously, we are missing something. The rules are very simple, but the game extremely deep and difficult, with clues given having effects on every player. We began to discover methods of play that allowed us to improve our score. 
My friend and I actually discussed how to beat hanabi through the week. I would go to bed, wake up at 3:30 in the morning with an idea, email my friend, and get an email back that morning with an idea he had. We were both constantly thinking about this game and how to beat it. 
After more game plays and additional "meta" rules, my friend and I are now able to achieve scores of 25 with some regularity.
This game has been a journey and a bonding experience like no other game I have ever played. The players involved are relying so much on every other player, that you actually feel like you must cooperate. This is team building at its absolute best.

Here's a semi-rant on angry alpha-male type players and their relation to Hanabi.
This game builds trust. Alpha male know-it-alls must take a chill pill and learn to trust their teammates. If you are this person, you will want to kill your partner the second they discard a card you told them was important. What you don't know is that they know you have the same card. And if you were so darn smart, you'd know that too. You'd also know that if they had been saving the card, and suddenly discarded it, it probably means you JUST picked the same card up. But you're too busy being mad that they discarded the card to think about the possible implications of that decision. 
The above rant is also an excellent indication of the type of "meta" rules and deduction that I believe Hanabi is all about.

Despite the fact that my group can now get 25 on a fairly regular basis, Hanabi did not end for us. No, not by far. The game comes with a 6th "multi" color firework card set. We play with only 1 of each numbered card of the multi-color set, raising the total possible score to 30. This is (I believe) the hardest version of the game, and we are still trying to work out the puzzle. Every game, even if we make a mistake early, is a deduction struggle to get the best possible score we can.

TL;DR
Hanabi is an awesome team building, trust building, easy to learn/hard to master game.
Find a group of people to regularly play with, KNOW that 25 is possible, and figure out how to do it!
Then, move on to the more advanced versions of the game, and try to do it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Enjoyed but seems a little thin on first night

RATING: 4
WAY to easy to ruin the game by accidentally putting your cards down the wrong way or looking at a card when you draw or a host of other flubs.  But in the end, it's just a weird Who-Am-I-group-Solitaire.  I like the subtlety of WHY someone gave you that particular information at that particular time, but in the end, it's just building a pile of numbered cards.  The box makes it sound exciting, "Race the Clock... Launch Your Rockets".  In play, there is minimal excitement, and I don't find myself caring if any of us screw up.  "Take Your Time... Play a Card".  Or don't.  On the flip side, this game can be VERY stressful to those who are sensitive to feeling like they have let the group down.  But that won't be me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players do not look at their own hand of cards but rather hold them up for all the other players to see. Players then give clues to which card a player should play to the table - cards need to be played in numerical order by colour - play a card out of order or one that has already been played and everyone loses.

A guessing/clue giving game with Ok components.

I am a little surprised at the love for this game - an Ok party game.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Elegantly solves the core problem that plagues most cooperative games by making the information exchange a core mechanic. (In most cooperative games, when players share enough information to play effectively a dominant analytical player will be able to tell everyone else what they need to do to win -- making the game less than cooperative. Some games try to solve this with traitors -- at which point they aren't really cooperative games anymore, frustrating levels of randomness, or clunky artificial restrictions -- which most players largely forget or ignore.)

The square cards in the "Second French Edition" are annoying because players (who can't see them) have to hold them in a specific orientation so their teammates can read them. New players have to continually be reminded to rotate the backs to a specific orientation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This is a wonderful game for people who like a challenge. We have tried to play it with a few different groups of people but generally, I find new players find it too stressful to be fun. My partner and I have played countless hours of this game together and still find it challenging and enjoyable. I think we've probably only ever played a perfect game once so the challenge doesn't lessen with time (at least not for us). Great to test communication and memory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Hanabi is a cooperative game of encoded communication, deduction, memory, and risk management. The players have to play their cards to the center of the table in a very specific order. But you must hold your cards so that everyone can see them except for you. As a group, you must figure out how to signal each other about which cards to play or discard. And there are very strict rules about what you are allowed to say, and when you are allowed to say it. You'll often feel like you don't have enough information to make a smart play. But that's what gives the game its wonderful tension. Hanabi is an absolutely brilliant game design, totally different from any other cooperative game on the market. The night I first cracked it out, we played seven times! The ultimate cooperative game for nerds? Probably

Mine is the early "Hanabi & Ikebana" version, and I do strongly prefer the rectangular to the square cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Tough game, fun though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
not a fun game for me. everyone else loves it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant concept which deconstructs the main mechanic of card games: you cannot see your own cards. Hilarity ensues. According to the rules you cannot convey any sort of information other the number and color of cards, but when playing with friends it's almost impossible not to bend the rules in one way or another. It doesn't matter, breaking the rules (or trying hard not to) is part of the fun.

RATING: 2
I can't decide if this is a 5 or a 1. The meta-game in my group was fine to a point, but then it's still all up to the deck. The challenge is then stretching the meta beyond a simple 'one command-one play' turn, but still feels like you're just following a pre-set rule. This game is more fun when you're figuring out what the meta should be, and then playing a few games to realize the meta at its full potential. Once you've done that, the game just becomes a process.

RATING: 7.5
I think I underrated this game initially. After 18 months not playing it, it hit the table and I forgot how good it is. The tension in this game is palpable. At least five times during the game, you are going to wish you were someone else and can give a certain clue or say a certain thing. And at least 2x during the game, it will come to your turn and you will have a) no information about your hand and b) no clues to give, forcing you to play a card or discard a card randomly. It doesn't get more fraught with tension than that.

RATING: 10

Plays very differently (but still well) with different player counts.  It's great to play "seriously" when people have enough skill, but can be a hoot when played with looser rules.

RATING: 7
This game turns set collection on it's ear. Everyone else knows your hand, but you don't, and you know everyone else's hand. The choices you have to make are agonizing and when you do choose, there is a collective cheer of approval, or a sigh of disappointment. Oh yeah, and it's freaking cooperative. Innovative and awesome!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Brief it may be, but don't call this awesome game "filler". Forget chrome, this is [i]pure, undiluted game[/i]. In this co-operative game, communication is key - you don't know what cards you have, and your team-mates must inform you, one piece of information at a time. Don't worry about the memory aspect: this is primarily a game of logic, communication, and laughter when someone messes up.  Memory plays a role, but it's also up to your team-mates not to over-burden you with information. It's wonderfully tense, full of cheers and groans as things go your way, or not. Hanabi is versatile as a Swiss Army Knife: it supports 2-5 players, and plays in  less than 30 minutes. Just get it, OK?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Call me unreconstructed but Hanabi lacks the 'take that-I win you lose' aggro that excites an old cardboard warrior like me.  This is an abstract co-op.  The theme extends only as far as the artwork on the box.  And strangely for a co-op table talk is limited.  To be fair, there are always a few amusing moments-sighs, groans, congratulations or recriminations, but it struggles for my love against a myriad of more enjoyable options.  Ask me if you want suggestions.
 
It would remain in a dusty corner of a cupboard if it wasn't for my teenage boys.  Despite all the paper capers that they could indulge in they want to play this.  And my wife likes it, so there!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A really nice twist on the co-op game concept that is so popular lately. Every player is dealt a hand of cards, but must hold them so that everyone but the owner can see them. Then, in turn, players either give clues or play cards. Doing well depends on giving clues well, but also remembering and figuring out what those clues mean. A really nice exercise in logic that doesn't last too long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
played once with 4 and once with 2. Didn't finish either game - not because we weren't having fun but because we didn't have enough time. Thought the game would be quicker than it turns out...very nice core concept - very good at pushing players to develop and adapt a way of communicating that will work within constraints. Essentially, it seems to me that it's about always thinking - why would it be important that i receive this information RIGHT NOW...given how limited the communication resource is - it should be considered precious and should be dwelled upon and given weight beyond the literal info signified. maybe it is an indication to discard - or to play ---and not knowing which is tense and cool.

RATING: 9
This is a fantastic game with 4 or 5 players. I have yet to play it with fewer. But, we had a blast playing this at the cabin. However, it is nearly impossible not to "cheat" at this game. It just happens when you are attempting to tell another player what kind of information they should give. It is a hilarious mix of you should tell THAT person something, and then THAT person will know more information, and should be able to play a card. But, then if THAT person plays it leaves the next person to discard, and I'm not so sure if that's such a great idea. This game just provides a great mix of strategy and hilarity. For less than $10 everyone should grab a copy.

RATING: 9
A fémdobozos kiadást vásároltuk meg és gyönyörű ez a kiadás: szép grafika, jó mínőség (a magyar szabály is).
Az évek alatt egyik kedvenccé nőtte ki magát. Nagyon tetszik, hogy csak a saját lapjaidat nem látod és a többiek által adott jelek, információk alapján hozol döntést, építed fel a tűzijátékot a "parasztok" részére.
Van, aki elpoénkodja a játékot és rengeteget szövegel, de ez nálam a komoly, inkább hallgass és gondolkodj el a nyomokon játék, így a megfelelő partnerekkel imádom. A végén majd nevetünk és átbeszéljük a fordulót.
Könnyen tanítható, de csak több játék után kapsz rá az ízére, mechanikájára. Minden elpocsékolt nyom nagy veszteség! :)

RATING: 7
Para mi Hanabi es el mejor juego de su autor Antoine Bauza. Un solitario colaborativo que cuenta con la deducción aparte del azar para intentar concluirlo con éxito.

Un juego que resulta muy divertido por el grado de confusión que los jugadores pueden sufrir y el riesgo que hay que correr.

Un juego muy de moda a finales de 2011 para terminar sesiones de juego o para probarlo con jugadores ocasionales.

----------

Hanabi por tamaño, precio y jugabilidad es de esos juegos que están destinados a formar parte de la lista de juegos de relleno para cualquier sesión Ludica.

RATING: 8
Yera, y tambien D.A

Filler en el que se tienen que completar cooperativamente varias colecciones de cartas (parecido a un solitario)... pero con una originalidad que lo cambia todo: 

cada jugador no ve sus cartas, ve las de los demas, y tiene que indicarles a los demas que cartas deben jugar... con unas limitaciones. 

a partir de ahi... un desafio a la memoria y al intelecto de los jugadores. y unas risas... dios mio. el mayor ataque de risa que me ha dado en un juego ha sido a Hanabi. 

Excelente y muy aconsejable filler. 

pd. en su primera edicion internacional, este juego venia junto con otro juego (este, competitivo) que utiliza la misma baraja de cartas y un numero mayor de tokens, llamado ikebana. Por algun motivo al cabo de los años ikebana desapareció, y la caja y las cartas fueron rediseñadas para emparejarlas tematicamente con Hanabi. 

pero sigue siendo posible, añadiendo unos cuantos tokens, jugar a "ikebana" usando la baraja de hanabi. :D

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the co op games where you really need each person to work together but at the same time, each person needs to be active and aware. What I mean is that, some co op games, you may have a role but other people can make decisions for you so sometimes it feels like the most vocal person is controlling the flow. However in Hanabi, you have to decide what clues to give, other players can hint suggestions but in the end its up to you. And it's so satisfying when things work out and very frustrating when it doesn't and everyone will have the same feeling at the end of the game "I reckon we can do better than that, lets try again!". Solid Co-Op game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've often said that co-op games aren't my favorite. There is a sense in which they must necessarily be either a pure puzzle, purely random, or somewhere in between. Hanabi answers that particular complaint by essentially being a puzzle, but hiding a different part of the information from each player. 

This is an inspired solution, and it also serves to eliminate any of the Alpha Dog problems that can plague other co-ops. Even if you see someone do something you think is dumb, it may not be, simply because you don't have all the information. 

Along those same lines, when someone plays a card that makes the team lose, it is never that player's fault. Rather, the rest of the team failed in their responsibility to give information to that player. This leads to very few "feel-bad" moments.

More than perhaps any other co-op, Hanabi rewards players who practice together and learn each others styles and conventions. It is brutally difficult to win, which makes it extremely satisfying when it happens. It's so quick-playing though, that an early loss simply leads to feelings of "let's give it another shot". 

Having the players hands backwards is such a simple change, so easy to understand, but with implications that are so deep. My favorite thing to do when explaining the game is to wait to tell players that their hands are backwards until very late in the explanation. The look on their faces is priceless. 

This game has tension, teamwork, accessibility, affordability, portability, and depth. Sure to be a classic for years to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic co-op game that is interesting and deep yet quite approachable. Worthy SdJ winner, highly recommended to pretty much everyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A cooperative card game, would have thought! Quite weird not to be able to look at your own cards. Tests your natural inclination to pick up a card and look at it. Almost makes you think you are playing Indian poker, though luckily you don't have to hold cards on your forehead and look like an idiot. Mind twister as you try to remember your teammates clues and hope you correctly interpret their intentions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Hanabi is a deceptively simple cooperative game which introduces an element which addresses the "alpha/leader" problem in a rather creative and effective manner - you can see everyone else's cards but your own. To make things more interesting, the primary resource in the game is hints so it becomes an impossibility to gather the perfect information required to implement such alpha/leader behaviour. As a result, the game becomes one of cooperation, memory, deduction, and calculated risk/reward. It's the perfect length for the type of game it is and doesn't overstay its welcome (if anything it understays and has you desiring more - a feature that designers should strive for more), is boiled down to its singular mechanism and not convoluted with unnecessary bells and whistles, and is aesthetically pleasing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
This was an earlier add to our collection and the mechanic of holding your cards so you can't see them was and still is mind-blowing. What an ingenious idea! It really forces good quality communication to get this co-op done well. It also plays fairly quickly with a lot of frustrating fun.

-The new aspect of using cards are welcome.

-Is this a theme after all? Because it feels so flat, it doesn't even there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(07/04/2014) Comment based on 5 plays.

Surprisingly simple, yet provocatively sophisticated Indian-poker-like cooperative card game, that plays quickly in about 20 minutes.

The players are dealt 4-5 cards, where the cards are ranked 1-5, in five different colored suits. Distribution of rank within each suit: 3x 1s, 2x 2s/3s/4s, and 1x 5. The objective is to play out cards in sequence from 1 to 5 in each of the suits.

Each player in turn has three options: 1) Give information about another player's hand (either point out exactly what cards have a specific rank, or specific color), 2) Play a card, that starts a new suit or plays in sequence with a started suit, or 3) Discard a card. In play or discard, the hand is refilled with a new card. What is especially interesting is that there are 8x timer chits. If giving info, a chit is consumed, while discarding, a chit is generated. If no chits are available, a player must either discard a card or attempt to sequence.

However, if a player plays a card out of sequence (you can only have one sequence for each of the five suits), a "fuse" chit is removed--three strikes and you're out!

This is a fascinating co-op, that does not suffer from the "alpha wolf" syndrome of a single experienced player hijacking the game, and telling everyone else how to play their roles. Instead, each player is an equal, and strict communication rules level the playing field. There is a sense of accomplishment when most of the fireworks go off in sequence, and a sense of failure when the team scores poorly, or if the three penalty chits are used up and the team scores zero points. Simple rules and components hide the fact that this is one fast, yet deep card game. It is a solid "7", with room to move up. It is definitely one of the "great" 20-minute fillers to come out in the last ten years.

(04/02/2015) Update after 20 plays. The game has fizzled with my group, who are mostly medium-to-heavy weight gamers, but still popular with any new player I introduce this game to. There is controversy about what constitutes cheating, but the game needs to be played strictly by the rules for it be great. Any winking, physical gesture, tonality, etc., is cheating, and spoils the fun. The greatness comes from pure deduction, based solely on the clues, the cards that you can see, and the discards. It is almost like Bridge, where it takes a lot of gray matter to figure out what cards you yourself have, and some creative thinking to give the maximum amount of information in the fewest clues. Of course, sometimes the order of the cards are against you, and no amount of intelligent or intuitive play will help. We also just found out that there is one other way to give a clue, which is indicating that a hand has none of a color or a rank--this method could finally allow us to get the elusive 25 points! Conventions, such as "I will put my newest card to my left, and discard first from my right most card," are perfectly acceptable, as such conventions will occur naturally in the course of many plays. However, the use of artificial "conventions", such as "you have no 5's" meaning that all of your cards are safe to discard, or that rearranging your hand during someone else's turn to signal, is in my opinion against the spirit of the game.

RATING: 5
A játékon könnyen lehet röhögni, de nehéz szabályosan játszani. Egyébként teljesen szabályosan valószínűleg egy unalmas memória kártya. De igazából éppen ezért nem is tetszett, nem vágyom rá, hogy többször játsszak vele. Indokolatlan a jelölése az év játéka díjra.

----
Most már meg is nyerte én pedig lejátszottam a második játékomat vele. Ez kevésbé volt szórakoztató inkább túl komoly. Egy kártyáról akkor tudsz biztosít, ha meg kapod mindkét információt róla (szín és szám) a játék nagy részében legfeljebb egy-két kártyádról van bármiféle információ, tehát inkább találgatunk. A lerakott, eldobott és a többiek lapjai segítségével a találgatáshoz ad támpontot. Ez viszont nem a könnyed. szórakoztató játékok ismertetője. 

-------
Mint minden partijáték, ez is társaságfüggő. Emelek a pontszámon egyet, de ez még mindig elég alacsony, mert nem ez a kedvenc partijátékom.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
"A game of trust and communication."

Co-op. You hold your cards backwards so you can see everyone's cards except your own. The goal is to play all five colors in order of #1-5.

Playing 5 player is tricky to play all cards and 2 player takes a different mindset, but the game can be fun with any player count. I always play with the mindset of "why was that clue given to that person at that time?". Usually the clue is to play the card, but sometimes it is a bluff or a finesse. Very fun stuff.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A cooperative card game where you hold your cards facing away from you and must play based on the limited info given by your fellow players or give one of your fellow players some limited info.  If you strictly follow the rules about table talk then this game avoids the usual problem of cooperative games where a dominant player makes all the decisions.  On the other hand it is hard to keep quiet.

RATING: 9
This is about as good as I could imagine a microgame getting. It's quick, interesting, challenging, and easy to teach. It tends to appeal to people who haven't yet been converted to the church of boardgames, and is a great gateway game. It is one of the few cooperative games that very effectively limits quarterbacking. Kudos to Bauza.

RATING: 4
Wholly unremarkable. Well, that isn't entirely true. It takes two game types I absolutely deplore, memory and deduction games, and puts them together into something I will probably try once or twice more before attempting a trade. But all told, this game is way too easy to convention or group think away the challenge. I suspect this game is only okay with a given group for the first play or two. After that, you would have put together too many rules of engagement for how and when to do what.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played this with a Hanabi veteran and two other newbies. It was fun the first time but I think it has very little replay value. If you play it strictly by the rules, it gets to be ritualistic because you are just solving a simple logic puzzle. If you play it in a social way it's good for a laugh, but since the puzzle is exactly the same every time, playing in the same group will also become ritualistic because you'll get to know each other too well. I think it's a fantastic game for kids because it's a logic puzzle that's all about cooperative problem solving. It's also a nice ice-breaking game for people you don't know well since it encourages you to talk to each other. It's just too simple and unvaried for adults who game together regularly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Cooperative card game where you can see everyones hand except your own.  As a rule I generally don't like cooperatives, but this is fast play, simple, some luck involved, and over fast (20 minutes).  English rules by RnR Games Inc in a nice small cardboard box.

Beyond Baker Street is a very similar game but with a much better theme linked to solving a crime.  Better than Hanabi, but not enough that I'd want to get it.

RATING: 6
Hanabi is a simple cooperative card game. The goal of the game is making beautiful fireworks. The main mechanics of Hanabi are memory and deduction. Players can provide limited chances of clues to each other. Players have to make set collections of card with climbing numbers. Hanabi is easy to learn and provides certain fun to every game participants.

RATING: 8.5

RATING: 9
Essen 2012
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Cooperative card game in which you don't know what cards you have been given, but must work it out based on clues given to you by the other players.  

It's a challenge (but also fun) to keep track of the knowledge that all the players have of their cards in order to properly give the 'hints' that are central to the game.  My problem with this game, however, is the human aspect of it:

It's far too easy to give (often accidental) clues about what card the other players should play, or to accidentally tell everyone what you can remember about what has been mentioned about your own cards.  The only proper way to avoid it is basically to sit in silence while playing, this (in my opinion) is not what games are about and it's a shame because this is a pretty solid little game.

Still would recommend this as a filler, not the best game for situations where active socialising is desired.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

Any game that can cause adults to act like children is a winner in my book, although it can sometimes turn into a cheat fest.

RATING: 7
Was really looking forward to this one from what I read about it but somehow it kinda of fell flat, and the other 3 players I played with wanted to abort so we did (they felt frustrated, maybe weren't in the right mood for this one which I think you need to be somewhat alert). I found it interesting especially the unique and unintuitive twist of not seeing your own cards however the game seemed a touch weird (but I think that came from us just trying to learn the "game"). 

When I read the rules I felt I was missing something, I doubled checked and checked questions on BGG and nope was not. I mean one turn you tell someone all their red cards, next turn someone else tells them they have two 3's and if one is red, it doesn't leave much deduction. However after playing I do see how better examples of deduction can come into play and it definitely seems from reading some of the comments we didn't get 'into' the game properly as such, so want to and will need to play again.

RATING: 6
15/08/'14. Met Grootva, Rik, Ward (9), Pepijn (6) en ik. Kaartspel waarbij je samen een zo groot mogelijk vuurwerk moet maken, door kaarten in volgorde 1-5 per kleur uit te spelen. Je ziet enkel de kaarten van de anderen, niet die van jezelf. In je beurt kan je ofwel 1) iemand een tip geven (kleur of cijfer van zijn kaarten), 2) een kaart wegleggen en een nieuwe trekken van de trekstapel, waardoor er een tip meer gegeven mag worden, of 3) een vuurwerkkaart uitspelen. Simpel, onderhoudend, gaat ook met jonge kinderen erbij.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hanabi is easy enough for new players to understand, but it really shines when playing with experienced players. The game is quite challenging, so it's all about learning how each player communicates using the limited language of the game.

It's a game I don't mind teaching, but I vastly prefer to play with veterans so we can make a run at (and perhaps eventually score) that elusive 25.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun and original co-op game. Avoids the loudest/dominant player tells everyone else what to do situation often prevalent in co-ops through players not knowing what their own cards are (just what the others hold), and through strict rules on what can be communicated by players to each other.

It's pretty simple, but every player must think for themselves about what information they give to the others, and pick up on the meaning behind the clues the others give.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2013 Spiel des Jahres Winner[/url][/b]

Hanabi, named for the Japanese word for fireworks, is a challenging cooperative game in which players try to create the perfect fireworks show by placing the cards on the table in the right order. Trouble is, it's dark out, so you can't really see what you are working with. Each player holds their cards so that only the other players can see them. They must give each other vital information and remember all the information received. Then use the information to choose which cards to play. Helping each other play the right cards at the right time is the key to creating an unforgettable show and avoid being booed by the audience.

Players:   2, 3, 4, 5
Time:      25 min
Mechanics:  [property=2023][/property], [property=1039][/property], [property=2040][/property], [property=2047][/property], [property=2004][/property]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Incredible game! A collaboration game the fits in your pocket. Every turn you ask yourself what's the best action to take to help your team: giving information to your teammates allowing them to play or to play your cards?
A must try... and a must have
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This game sounded fun... my wife and I played it and lost miserably as expected the first time... Then we played again and again... And lost miserably again and again. Every time we play this we loose miserably. In fairness I have only ever played this two player and my wife and I both wonder if it would play different with more players. I like hard challenging games, my wife and I think we're pity good at learning or adapting a strategy. This game has us stumped.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Tami's rating: 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2013-07-28 - This is a really interesting cooperative card game, with a decent tension level, and some great decisions. The token limit for hints gives you a constant feeling of trying to catch up. Very fun. That said, the scoring system (a bit like the golf tee jumping game at Cracker Barrel) is little... Scoring is a competitive thing. I think the game should simply be: lay out 5 colored straights, if you fail, you lose. The idea that you still win if you come up short, but you may get a lower score, is a little silly.

2017-11-06 - This is one of the few cooperative games in my collection, and it's great for playing with newer gamers. I'll probably only pull it off the shelf for them, though, so I'm lowering my rating from a 7.5 to a 6.

RATING: 7
Hanabi is an innovative concept for a game, and one that works well for a quick, light play. The group dynamics and decisions are what shine here. It can be prone to cold memorization, so it's best not to take it too seriously. It has that "let's play again and see if we can do even better" feel. A welcome, novel contribution to the hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Super challenging new game with a VERY unique dynamic: you don't see the cards in your hand, so you have to rely on hints from other players as to what to play… but there are only a limited number of hints available to do it. Runs fairly quick, requires you to keep track, all players need to participate fully… it's not very strategic or requiring luck, but controlled risk. It works tremendously well. A great starter game or night finisher.

BIG PLUS: intensity, ease of learning
PLUS: low cost, playing time sneaks up on you
MINUS: concentration required

RATING: 7
Brainburner! Have only played 2p so far, but that works well. UPDATE: Played with both 3 and 4 and it scales amazingly well. Still a brainburner, you will know less about your cards with more players, but the cards get cycled faster, so difficulty felt similar, only the focus changed a bit. Very good game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Co-op card game that comes in a small box, is cheap to purchase and has an innovative idea: reversing cards hold in hand. If playing very strict using just logic and deduction, you'll quickly run short on hints, even when hints have a high information density. So this game quickly turns into a game of exploiting meta game information; thereby increasing information density per hint. For example: "this is a 3", means "this is a 3 you can play", when the game is in a stage where there is just one color where a 3 can be played. The necessity to exploit meta game information to perform well reflects my rating for this game. As does the memory element in the game (no fun, chore!) and the impact of randomization in card order for final scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Stressful! Have never gotten a score of 20+.

RATING: 6
Éste es un cooperativo cortito donde los jugadores tienen que tratar de completar sets.

Tendreis que completar 5 sets de fuegos artificales en 5 colores distintos con cartas del 1 al 5, cada una de su número y color.

El problema es que cada jugador puede ver las cartas de los demás pero no las suyas propias. En ese punto es cuando el juego cooperativo tiene lugar, los jugadores deben ayudar a los otros dándoles pistas para poner en juego las cartas correctas. Estas pistas pueden ser sobre un color ó sobre un número pero no ambas a la vez.

Al final de la partida los jugadores ganarán puntos dependiendo de los sets que hayan completado.

Reglas sencillas, gran juego. Es impresionante cómo se puede olvidar prácticamente toda la información sobre tus cartas en sólo unos segundos. 
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2014
[/color][color=blue]
This a cooperative short game where players try to complete sets.

All of you will have to complete 5 fireworks sets in 5 different colours with cards form 1 to 5 one of each number and colour.

The point is each player can see the cards of the rest of the players but not his/her own cards. At that point is when cooperative game takes place, players should help the others to put down the right cards by providing them clues. These clues can be about a colour or about a number but not both at the same time.

At the end of the game players will score points depending of their complete sets.

Simple rules, great game. It's amazing how you can forget almost everything about your cards in only a few seconds. 
[/color]

RATING: 8
I love deduction games.  With two players, I find this to be a great brain burner.  The secret is the finesse.  New cards go in one side of your hand, discards go out the other side.  Then your partner knows which card you are getting ready to discard.  With that mevhsism, a 25 is posdible, but still very difficult.  Love the game, but you have to find someone who also loves deduction as much as you do, otherwise it's a bust.

RATING: 7

You are trying to play the five colors in sequence from 1 to 5. You have a limit on the number of clues you can give, but you can discard a card to gain another clue. This is a fun filler.

RATING: 9
I'm not a fan of cooperative games. But I love this game. It's probably the only coop that I enjoy. I've played quite a bit with my wife and it's pretty good two player, but 3+ is where it shines because there are all sorts of timing and bluffing clues you can give. This is a game that benefits from repeated plays with the same group. I highly recommend.

RATING: 2.5
I hate this game.  It is so easy to cheat and to have someone forget the information that someone told them.  You also have to have a system for communicating more information than you should, such as favoring the left most card that someone has when giving a clue.  I haven't had success without a system, but with it I feel like I'm just playing the game for everyone.  I always end up angry and no one has fun.  On the other hand, I think the game is very enjoyable on board game arena.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cooperative game, in which you see everyone's cards, except the ones, belonging to you. An interesting way to avoid alpha gamer. One of the most important aspect of the game is memory - to remember, about which cards and what information was given to whom. It looks like there are too little clue tokens, but apparently there are just enough of them to make discarding cards a necessity.

Kooperatinis žaidimas, kuriame matai visų žaidėjų kortas, išskyrus savo. Įdomus būdas išvengti viską valdančio žaidėjo. Vienas iš svarbiausių aspektų - atmintis ir nesusipainioti, apie kokias kortas, kam ir kas buvo pasakyta. Užuominų žetonų atrodo kiek mažoka, bet iš tiesų jų yra tiek, kad žaidėjai turėtų pakankamai preteksto išmetinėti korteles.

RATING: 7
Katy Perry - Fireworks
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game deserves a LOT of credit for being a "modern", designer game that can be accessed by many.  If I can play this with a group of old folks and show them something radically different from Phase10 or Uno - and they GET IT and think it's a fun and interesting game, and want to play it again - then this is possibly one of the most successful and important modern game designs.  It's a good family card game!

The only "flaw" of this game, if you want to call it that, is that the game seems prone to people insisting on cheating the game a bit with house rules to keep track of cards and put priority on certain cards, and it can suck the fun out with people who take it too seriously.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
one of the best cheap games you can buy, and its cooperative. I find the hidden information and the restricted communication very clever. And funny/cringy when a memory aspect is forgotten. A pure design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I first played this at a con, starting around midnight, after 14 hours of gaming. We played it three times. People passing our table expressed no interest, and even some disdain. Then six months later it wins the SdJ gets a huge print run and is sold out everywhere. I can imagine playing this with a wide range of people, in a wide range of situations, and playing it every once in a while for decades. It's not my favorite game but it has a permanent place in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.15
It's not much for table talk, but I like it so far.  It's one of my wife's new favorites, although she wishes she could get away with more inflection: "This one's green...
but THIS ONE'S ALSO GREEEEEEN!!" ☜(ﾟヮﾟ☜) ))

1st multiplayer game we started to realize the power of telling person A things about their hand while ignoring Person A. Like Person A knows they have a 3. We might explain the next player down, Player B, that she has a green 4, skipping past A.  Player A knows that we all know that the only thing they know about their hand is one green card, and that there's a green 2 on the table, the person who goes next has a sort of go ahead to play a green 4, for which their are no easy spots, so should...they play their three? and hope it's green?  If we've all played out cards right, we've encouraged B in such a way that it makes A playing that green card a super, super good idea.  Let's do it!

I love this game and it will always be in my collection.

RATING: 8.5
A strange cooperative game where you have a hand of cards that you cannot look at.  You see everyone else's cards and they see yours.  You then have to figure out the best ways to give clues (a limited resource) to each other and try to play sequential sets by color on the table.  Hard to complete, but we did it once!  :-)

RATING: 7
Good portable quick family game.  I call this game "group solitaire". Everyone works together to try to build up five stacks of cards in order (1-5) by suit. Crazy thing is that each person cannot see what cards they have in their hand. Therein lies the rub!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
We purchased the deluxe tile version of this game.  I don't recall us ever disliking a game more than this one.  It has a very heavy memory element which we both despise so it's my own fault I guess for not having researched it better.  Someone had described it as a better cooperative Code 777, but I like that game, or really any game at all more than Hanabi.  Past the memory element the rest of the gameplay is just dull.  And it does feel a bit broken if no one should happen to draw a starting '1' tile/card which seemed too common in our two player games. I love deduction games but why not play one that is more thematic than just placing numbers? So many better cooperative games as well and yes if you want the figure out what u have game get Code 777 instead.  For two players get Fugitive. 

BEWARE THE DELUXE VERSION of this game.  It has a very very strong toxic smell to the tiles that made both of us nautious and didn't go away.  Didn't help our opinion as we couldn't be rid of that odor fast enough!

RECOMMENDED INSTEAD:  Code 777, Fugitive.

RATING: 7
Hanabi is difficult to comment on. Like most cooperative games it is more of a puzzle than an actual game. But unlike those other cooperative games, which pit you against a set of rules designed to act as your opponent, Hanabi gives you a very simple goal and has you competing against your own memory, communication and observation skills. I've only played it twice, and found it to be really addictive (and I typically don't like cooperative games). As a quick game for experienced gamers or as a fun family game, I think Hanabi is a winner.

RATING: N/A
No of players: 3
Surprisingly interesting concept. 

After initial confusion based on how players hold their cards (others see your cards, but you don't), complete game starts slowly to reveal (in all its glory)

Trying to guess what you have in hand, how it can help others and how you can help others by giving them information about cards they have are fantastically mixed in this highly deductive (and addictive) co-operative game.

Spiel des Jahres 2013 – well deserved.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An innovative cooperative game where players must truly cooperate to win. 

Players have the simple task of playing cards of matching colors in the correct numerical order. The twist is that no player can look at their own cards, the cards that they are tasked with playing correctly. So they have to decide what to play and when to play it based on clues from the other players. The type of clues that can be given have certain restrictions and the quantity of clues available to the team is restricted so clues must be given and received very efficiently to get the maximum score. 

The game is fun and just the right challenge level to keep you coming back for more. The group gets a 'score' based on how many of the cards were successfully played which, combined with the quick play time and interesting/tough choices, makes for an addictive challenge that keeps you coming back for more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It is a 8 with physical copy, less entertaining online


It is a fun social game. Playing without the so-called 'convention' is much funner, although getting to 25 points is almost impossible without the 'convention', but i would really much preferred it that way

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Clever dynamic where you have to deduce things about your cards from what others tell you. The clues seem abundant in the beginning, but quickly become scarce and you often want to throttle your partners for giving unnecessary clues or not doing the move they're "supposed" to do. You're often blind to your own role and instead focus on how you can help others. If you and your partners are good about not giving more information than allowed (really any extra information beyond the clues is too much information), this is a highly fun, deductive game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this game, you are dealt a hand of cards, but instead of not showing people your hand, you face your hand out so you dont know what you have. In the game you give each other clues to figure out what cards you are holding to build a fireworks display (basically going 1,2,3,4,5 in order of each color) 

Very fun and much tougher than you think.

RATING: 10
Love it. A coop game that doesn't degenerate into one player telling everyone what to do. It also requires that you model *why* a player would make a certain play based on the information you both know and the information they know that you don't in a way really helps with more complex competitive strategy games.
It's quite simple, so after lots of plays with the same group might get a little boring. I'm really hoping to find a game that builds on the "can't see your own hand" mechanic with a little more depth!

RATING: 9
A really addicting co-op that requires deduction based on the amount of clues given. Definitely more of a challenge as the number of players increase. Also, the game becomes really easy or really frustrating based on playing styles, i.e., when I play with players who I have taught how to play or who play with the same strategy with me, the game is incredibly easy, yet when players have developed their own strategy to play, it becomes more frustrating than normal play. Overall, I've begun to stop teaching other players certain strategies in attempt to allow them to discover those strategies on their own, which makes the game more rewarding/fun to me.

RATING: 8

-> updated 9/2013: yep, rating goes up 7 -> 8. This is THAT good. There is a chance, that it goes even higher...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Hanabi—named for the Japanese word for "fireworks"—is a cooperative game in which players try to create the perfect fireworks show by placing the cards on the table in the right order. 

The card deck consists of five different colors of cards, numbered 1–5 in each color. For each color, the players try to place a row in the correct order from 1–5. Sounds easy, right? Well, not quite, as in this game you hold your cards so that they're visible only to other players. To assist other players in playing a card, you must give them hints regarding the numbers or the colors of their cards. Players must act as a team to avoid errors and to finish the fireworks display before they run out of cards.

RATING: 6
This is a neat little coop game that requires full teamwork. I love the fact that you don't see your hand of cards and you have to give each other hints as to what colour or what numbered cards others have. It's challenging in a sense that the complete set is hard to accomplish because there's only a set number of cards and not all cards come by at the right time.

I don't exactly find it too much fun, except for the fact that this game has a unique mechanism, it feels a bit lack luster other than the giggles and faces we made from illegally trying to hint when and what other should put what card in their hands.

Recommend if you have not play this.

RATING: 6
[u]Comments:[/u]
Hanabi is a neat little card game that requires a group that can communicate well together and a decent amount of luck in card draws to complete the game successfully. It really helps if you have a player who has played the game a few times to offer tips. But really there isn't enough to this game to even make it a gateway game that I would enjoy playing more than once a year. At times it can be extremely frustrating, and i don't play games to feel frustrated.

RATING: 7.4
My wife's current favorite. A very tight, accessible little game that everyone seems to enjoy. I like it too, but as I get more experienced with the strategy its becoming harder not to want to tell the less experienced people how to play. 

The game really is different with each group you play it with, and there's a learning curve as you teach each new group. I guess I'm getting a little burned out on playing with new players almost every time, as the basics are only exciting the first few times you play it. Still, it's a great little game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In general, I don't really care for hidden role games, and most deduction games leave me flat as well. But this game, oh man. I can see this as one of those games where you introduce it to a bunch of new people, they play it, and then immediately demand to play it again. It's a cooperative game where everyone can see your cards except you. There are five suits with a distribution of 1-1-1-2-2-3-3-4-4-5, and you as a group are trying to complete a run of 1-2-3-4-5 in each suit. But the information you can give each other is limited, and you have to make some brutal choices. We played twice and got 13 points the first time, 14 the second time (highest possible is 25). There's nothing to the game, but it's tough, tense, and a lot of fun. (I have an Artscow version, will buy a real one ASAP.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.9
I have a difficult time, conceptually, with cooperative games, but Hanabi is better than most.  It's pretty straightforward and simple to learn, but once learned, there's a lot of difficulty to it; I've only won once since I started playing.  It's small, portable, and perfect for two players, so it's a good vacation or bar game.

The design is pretty but it's not spectacular; but it doesn't have to be.  The ingenuity of the design and the gameplay is enough to carry this one.  It's got good replay value and the rules are easy to remember.  You might say it's...nice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hanabi as a cooperative game can be dry at times, but has a significant twist of not having information about your own cards. Players must work cooperatively to give hints about the contents of each others hands, but it's every player's responsibility to remember, deduce, and play the cards they have. An easy to learn and short logic game, there are few games like it and it's not hard to try it out on any given night.

RATING: 7.5
[microbadge=5792]

Probably one of the more unique coöp games I've ever seen.  Quarterbacking is done away with completely with a complete lack of knowledge about the cards you can play.  This isn't a strategy game at all, but instead a communication game (and to a lesser extent, a deduction game).  Light but not easy, it fills in a neat niche in the coöp genre.

RATING: 5
A great attempt at solving what I see as a big problem in the cooperative games: the problem that all the players play together, and you don't make your own decisions. Here in Hanabi, you do make your own decisions, which is great. 
But the game itself is quite abstract, and "cold". 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Awesome cooperative card game.  As a group, you're creating fireworks solitaire-style in the center, five cards in order in each of 5 colors (or with a sixth wild color in the more challenging variants).  I think the reason I actually like this fully coop game versus every other one I don't is because everyone has /some/ information, but not all the same parts, and are limited in how and when you can share it.  You play with your hand facing away from you, the only cards you can see are everyone else's.

It's a great opener game, VERY challenging when played right, definitely a thinker, and it can get more challenging with the variants I haven't tried yet.

Certainly only good for a few plays with any one group, though, and then I found it get boring quick.  Also, sadly, seemed to just frustrate my mother and sister, so don't know if I just wasn't teaching it well, or if this type of logic game just doesn't work for some people.

Bought at CotC 2013 from a FLGS for a whole $9 well spent.  Traded on here for the Dominion Stash promo card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

25 min 2 a 5 (4) jugadores

RATING: 8
I love this game. It is challenging and forces the players to try and think from their partners' points of view, all while remembering what was learned previously and using deduction to make informed decisions. The biggest problem for me with this game was a lack of people to play it with - if you're at very different skills levels it can be frustrating for everyone.

RATING: 9
una pequeña joya, gran juego cooperativo y de deducción

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was skeptical of this game at first, but it has turned out to be a lot of fun. Many have tried and failed to create a co-op that can't be controlled by one player, and this is the closest thing I've seen to a success on that front. Because you don't know what cards you have, you don't always know whether someone is making an optimal move or not. This also makes the game frustrating and tense (in a fun way) when players are forced to make guesses or assumptions without full information, and with possible disastrous consequences. It's the sort of game where, upon finishing, you immediately want to play again. That's high praise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Die Spieler müssen die Karten nach Farben und Zahlen geordnet ausspielen. Man sieht jedoch nur die Karten seiner Mitspieler, nicht die eigenen!
Wer an der Reihe ist, muss sich für eine von drei Aktionen entscheiden. Entweder man gibt einem anderen Spieler einen Hinweis oder wirft eine Karte ab oder spielt eine Karte aus. Nimmt man den Hinweis, gibt man einem anderen Spieler einen Farb- oder einen Zahlenhinweis und dreht ein Hinweisplättchen um. Wirft man eine Karte ab, so darf man ein benutztes Hinweisplättchen wieder auf die Vorderseite drehen. Wenn man die Karte ausspielt, kann man mit ihr das Feuerwerk in der Tischmitte weiter vorantreiben. Passt die Karte allerdings nicht, senden die Götter, erzürnt über dieses Missgeschick, einen Blitz.

RATING: 9
Rated for casual play. I dislike strict adherence to the communication rules. For example, allowing a player to ask for reminders is totally fine by me. I have taken part in a couple of bad Hanabi sessions. More than most games, it can be soured by a player who is not invested in it.

RATING: 6

Relies too much on playing with the same group over and over and coming up with a standard way of giving clues across each game. Others still enjoy it so I'll bust it out from time to time as an example of how different games can be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is a lot of fun.  It is interesting to see how different people try to help the deduction process along, but not everyone's thinking lines up.  Benefits from repeated plays.

---
Okay, I have played this game more than 100 times now and I am strongly considering moving it up to a 9. This is not a decision I take lightly, so I will probably wait a bit longer to decide, but this game is very good.  The process of building up useful conventions is very interesting and it is fascinating to watch new players as they go through the learning process.  The biggest downside to this game is that it does not work as well with a mixture of experience levels unless the experienced players are very aware of the difference going into the game.  

There are also a few major traps and mistakes that new players tend to make and have to be trained away from through thinking, example, and discussion.  

Still, a really good game.

---
After 130 plays, we have gotten enough people into the same groove to get a few 25s (I play with a diverse group where players cycle in and out).  I think it is about time to add the multicolor tiles...

---
2014 - 354 plays, mostly w/ full multicolor set.  Still playing.  Rating moved from 8 to 9.

300+ plays, 2-5 players

RATING: 9
7.5 - Feb 2015 - 4 Plays:  It's a good game and it's fairly quick.  I'd like to try it with just 2 players to see how that goes.  I'm not sure about the longevity of the game, but it's short enough that I don't foresee myself getting rid of it.

8.5 - May 2015 - 15 Plays:  This game has really opened up after playing it a couple of times online.  When everyone is on the same page and paying attention, this game really does become quite good.  I've only tried 6th color once and haven't yet tried multicolor, but I'm looking forward to it.

9.0 - Nov 2015 - 32 Plays:  This game is at it's best with a group that can handle the 6th color.  The feeling of scoring 30 points is amazing.  Unfortunately, this game really suffers when played with people of mixed skill levels, especially if people don't understand just how much you have to pay attention.

RATING: 6
On the fence about trading away.  However, the game barely takes up any shelf space.  If play this game with standard conventions regarding how you hold the cards and why you would normally choose certain cards, the game has more direction and strategy but there are sometimes no real decisions to be made (the choice is obvious).  If you do not play using conventions such as "if I haven't told you what that card is it's probably not important", the game becomes brutally difficult and bit random.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Holy shit, this game is amazing. A deck of cards, a handful of tokens, and a short set of rules produces a delicious level of tension and a game like none I've played before.

The hook -- you never see your own cards, holding them backwards -- was enough to pique my interest, but it's more than just a gimmick. The game builds up layers of communication, including communicating by not communicating, and combines them with memory, taking chances, assessing your fellow players, and a lot of thinking in a way that's wholly unique.

I can see how playing with the same group would produce a meta unique to your group. We developed some conventions for how to share information, and what not sharing it meant, just inside of one game. And I love that the game calls out that you can flex that aspect of it -- what would be called cheating in most games -- to suit your group.

This is a motherfucking gem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Limited Edition. 


There is a lot of game in this small package. If I could describe this game by using 3 words, I would say: tight, tense and thrilling. Only 1 play so far (as a 2 player), but I know this one will hit the table frequently. 

3/31/13: This game hits its sweet spot at 4 players IMO. Just don't play with more than 5! Way too chaotic!

Update 8/3/14: I played this twice last night with my wife. It's still phenomenal! My wife was literally begging me to play a third game in a row. We upgraded to the deluxe version, which I highly recommend. In fact, because I like the upgraded components so much, I'm raising my rating from a 9 to a 9.5.

Update 9/27/14: Played this game last night with 3 new people (4 player game). It was probably not the ideal group for this game. Everyone playing was highly intelligent. However, we all saw the game though a different lens. Everyone wanted to "chain" clues as much as possible, but we quite often disagreed on how to get there. Still, the game was A LOT of fun. Hanabi is group dependent, to be sure. That said, not everyone has to see eye to eye. The more important factor is that everyone at the table is of a reasonably high intelligence level, understands the general concept of the game, and is willing to work together for the most part. A phenomenal game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A French game reprinted by a German company about a Japanese fireworks display -- translated into English.  What an interesting circuit.  The take-home point of this is that it's a game so good that it's *worth* going round-about to get it.

I ordered the game from GameSurplus.  I had never ordered from them before, but they were one of the few places which I could get this game from.  Along with my shipment, they made sure to print out the instructions for Hanabi for me; that little act really set them apart to me.  That they knew the game well enough to print and include them with the game was quite the pleasant surprise.

The game itself is fantastic too; it's so simple that you think "How could this *possibly* be hard?"  But it is; people forget what you've told them or don't realize why you've pointed out something about their hands.  Also, the limitation on hints is a brilliant mechanic.  Great game for a great price.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
4 /5 - Very Good

The beauty of Hanabi is how, unlike mosty co-ops, it forces players to actually co-operate with an absolute minimum of rules. Fun, frustrating and challenging, it's a great family game. For hobbysists, not so much maybe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.98
The best gateway co-op going.

The Goal: To sort 5 different suites of cards into piles numbered 1-5 with no gaps or repeated numbers.

The Problem: You can't look at your cards. Ever.

Player's Turn: Play a card, discard a card, or use one of the limited clue tokens and give a clue to another player. Clues are either they have card(s) with a specific number, "These two cards are fours," or color, "These three cards are red." If a player makes an illegal play, the players earn one strike. Three strikes and the game ends with a score of zero. Players can earn clue tokens back by discarding or completing a stack.

But is it fun? The games that separate themselves are the games with dynamic moments. Like a player showing their initial hand and reviling 3 green 1s. The two other players laughing and the person holding the cards going, "What?" Two clues later and everybody is laughing.

The moment when there is a stack of green cards with a 2 on top. You and another player have a green 3. Both know they have a green or a 3 and see the other players green 3. The one player discards his and you suddenly know you have a green 3 and play it.

Knowing only one thing about a single card out of the hand you have and deciding it is worth playing since if it was worth discarding you would have hoped the other players would have clued you in. You play it successfully.

Asking a person what they know about their hand, finding out they are wrong about two of them, you only have one clue to give, if that, and you can't correct them. There's only two copies of fours. Was one of the cards they had wrong a four? Yes, yes it was.

The ultimate fun one, there's no clues to give so you have to play, and you literally know nothing about any of your cards. And yes, this will happen often. Good luck.

Possible con: people who give out overly obvious clues.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

As to gameplay, I think that I agree with Tom Vasel that it's not a game, rather it's a pastime. An extremely enjoyable and entertaining one nevertheless.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Very original cooperative game. Because everyone only has partial information and people can only share information by use of paid hints, this game cleverly avoids the alpha gamer problem which is present in most cooperative games.

In turn, it is not easy to introduce new people to the game, as offering advice or pointing out strategies during a game automatically constitutes cheating. This can be solved by playing an introductory test game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I enjoyed this game a lot. It is very simple and elegant with a wonderful premise in the mechanics. It reminds me of a coop version of a team-based trick taking game (bridge, euchre, 500, etc.). It makes for a lot of really funny dramatic tension and banter when everyone at the table knows what someone should do except for them. I can definitely see this game becoming boring if the players take it too seriously, meta-game, or try to skirt the rules. But then again, a lot of coop games are ultimately played on the honor system because there's no one at the table who is going to force you to play "the right way." Great travel game with a tiny box and small footprint.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very clever and unique game, but has not been as much of a hit with me as others I game with.  I've played several games since everyone else seems to love it, and I can certainly appreciate the unique design.  The memorization element doesn't really excite me and figuring out the most efficient, clever sequence to give clues often feels a bit frustrating since you're hoping others follow your lead.  I'll enjoy playing this if it's requested, but don't see myself bringing this out too often within my own circles.

Update: After several plays this has grown on me a bit.  I still don't tend to bring it out much on my own, but there is some really fun strategy here when playing with a group of folks who know the game well.  The co-op puzzle of sharing good info at the right time is really enjoyable and fulfilling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players: 2, 3, 4, 5
Best: 4

Cooperative Deduction game, very simple but requiring a lot of solid communication to succeed.

RATING: 7.5
Filler cooperativo, familiar y divertido de cartas. 

Cabe en cualquier bolsillo, y es un vicio!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I saw someone refer to this as a game of "bandwidth", which to me rang true. The whole game is trying to stuff as much information as you can into your clues - which are restricted to either colour or numbers in terms of what you can say explicitly - but what they imply is something else entirely. Chaining clues, tacit understanding of what the order of the cards in hand means, trying not to cheat by winking heavily as you state your clue, or more likely - sighing as they misunderstand completely and ruin everything. I've found that the memory component can make this game a bit too much for some, and depending on the style of game you want to play (aka, focus on memory or the deduction aspect) you might want to allow people to remind others about clues. The grade of leniency towards intonation and emphasis you allow in your clues is also something that I suspect will vary for each group. Either way it's a fun and intriguing cooperative game, unlike anything else I'd tried before. It's very simple to teach and learn, and it enables a short but enjoyable time of silent communication.

A good game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1 play i liked it 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Cooperative deduction game of playing cards blindly from your hand based on clues from others.

Played as: 3,4 player

Pros: Highly interactive with lots of tough decisions due to needing to relay info while also playing to the level of the person recieving the clue. Simple rules but with scaling difficulty from tough to impossible.

Cons: Very hard not to taint the play with unintentional expression clues. The game can feel same-y and can become routine if played repetatively with the same people to the point where you're just waiting for the game when the luck of the draw falls in your favor.

Other: The memory element can be hit or miss. Sometimes it's funny to watch someone fret over which card is the one they thought it was, but it can also be maddening when someone seems to forget due reasons outside your control. I've played with the rainbow cards used to scale the difficulty only a couple times. They added a nice twist, and do add difficulty, but I don't think they ramp up the game notably on the enjoyment scale.

Best Use: A good filler/opener/closer with a splash of brain-burn.

RATING: 8
[b]after 7 plays[/b] I would rate this higher except it's very, very hard to get players to play by the actual rules. Some people say that you should let people play how they want to play, and I get it, but that also generally makes it a much easier and less interesting game for me. 

My opinion might change if I play it alot with my ladylove, who will play it as it should be played.

[b] after more than 100 plays[/b] My ladylove and I have now won against all the variations except the hardest one, which we're now working on. I like it much more played as a sort of legacy game with the same person, over and over, as you develop conventions. There's a really nice unfolding of collective understanding. Also someone gifted us the deluxe version, which makes a much bigger difference to the experience of play than I was predicting. Not having to hold cards and move them around in your hand makes every feel much more effortless. Rating is up to 8 now.

RATING: 5.5
Assuming this game is played in the spirit of the rules, not giving extra information with your clue via codes, intonation, etc., I still feel 95% of succeeding at this game is the shuffle. This doesn't seem the type of game that someone will become really good at; after a few plays, the best way to proceed with giving clues should become pretty obvious. The right cards being drawn at the right time will help more than anything. I like co-op games. I'm not against playing this one and I have had fun doing so, but I am stumped why this game is so popular.

RATING: 8.75
[b][url=https://boardgamegeek.com/video/57430/hanabi/hanabi-review-cardboard-vault]Hanabi Video Review[/url][/b]

Bought at Origins 2014

I usually hate cooperative games, but I love Hanabi.

It's a cooperative game of logical deduction with a unique mechanic (seeing everyone else's cards but not your own), a fun theme (building fireworks for a spectacular show) and the option to make it easier or harder with the addition of an extra set of rainbow fireworks.

Challenging, plays reasonably quickly, and very enjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Summed up by a friend of mine, who on his first play said, "I hate this game!  ...but I love this game!"

It's simple, yet it's a brain burner.  It's a co-op that removes the key problem with co-ops. (In Hanabi, an overbearing player doesn't know what their team mate's best move is).

I'm sure this game would rub some people up the wrong way, but I think it's clever, challenging, and funny.  Which is a great combo.

RATING: 8.4

But it needs some logical houserules to become better at it. It's a challenge but also a lot of fun.

RATING: 6
One for the head, but not for the heart, at least not for mine. 
What puts me off most is that it is a cooperative game, but communication is strictly limited. Shouldn't games in general a coop games in particular be about communication? The strict rules on this create a somewhat negative feel, and if you ease them off, the idea of the game gets ruined. Because of this, I very much prefer 'The Game' over this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
:r:eviewed:
[thread=1305138][/thread]

Pretty Immediate approval and excitement, even from the anti-gaming contingent (bit unkind). I personally wonder how long it will see play but in the abstract: this is a fantastic design and a [b]must own card game[/b].

First score 18 (-3 due to very mild cheating but only 1 life lost, due to the drink confusing me). 

Second game 19 (-2 due to an even milder bit of cheating, two lives lost due to a 50/50 and some misleading/misinterpreted advice). Was an even more enjoyable game. This really is a wonderful treat/trick to own.

Third Game 16 (-0.5 due to raise-eyebrowgate. Lost all three lives, twice due to unforced error; once due to one player having two yellow 2s)

Fourth game 19 (No cheating. Two lives down. Folks have ordered their own copy.)

A year later - took this game on holiday to the Highlands and it of course remained a source of magic, wonder and entertainment.

Another year later - wet holiday and played with much laughter with many :)

RATING: 9.5
The coop game par excellence. No alpha gamers, no pointless downtime -- everything every single player does impacts everybody else and must be paid attention to.

A deep psychological game disguised as a counting and memory game.

An essential, must-play game if you're in any way interested in game design.
