=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very clever game. I enjoy very few cooperative games, because either I feel I don't have any individuality or that the game tries to give it to me through forced machinations. In Hanabi, every player has a unique set of information and is critical to completion. I spend every turn wanting to push words into others' mouths but I cannot. It's a wonderful sort of tension that is quite enjoyable, collectively spinning plates and not wanting to be the first to dash them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First 2 plays with wife, we scored 17 pts both times. It's a tough game. Hard to imagine that we'll attain perfection, i.e. 25 pts.

Played with 4 and 5 players. Best score 22...with far too much player communication.

It's a hilarious game...
Player 1 - 'What do you know about your cards?' 
Player 2 - holding up two yellow cards - 'These two are definitely green'
Entire group bursts into uncontrollable laughter...but it's nervous laughter. Sure, the situation is funny, but deep down we know we're in trouble.

And that's the beauty of Hanabi.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hanabi is a cooperative game, meaning that all players are working together towards the same goal. The twist is that players do not know their own cards, and other players have to give them hints so that the cards are played in the proper order.

I have played many tense games of Hanabi. I have never done particularly well, but it has always been an interesting experience.

The crew of Shut Up & Sit Down repeatedly say that their favourite games allow for interesting decision making. Hanabi, in my opinion, allows for loads of interesting decisions, which make it a game worth playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Nem értem ennyi év után sem a SdJ díjat... Jó-jó, egyszer-egyszer elmegy, pasziánsz-fíling, de sokat belemagyaráznak, amit nem kellene.

Amúgy meg kifejezetten nehéz kirakni, bár az inkább előnye, mint hátránya.

A téma meg marhára nem jön át (mekkora baromság már ez a tűzijáték tematika?).

Azoknak érdemes kipróbálni, akik nem sok egyedi mechanizmust láttak még, mert az mondjuk van benne:
 - kooperatív pasziánsz
 - senki sem látja a saját kártyáját, csak a többiekét

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
Three plays of this one so far, all in one lunchtime session so it really works well for my lunchtime gaming group.  This fast-play co-op game has a rather fun ‘gimmick’ n that you don’t see your cards but all the other players can. That is, you hold your hand with the back facing you. As the game progresses, other players may give you clues as to what you have in your hand and you use your judgement (or hope to luck) that you have the card you think you do and play it accordingly.

The object is to get each of the five colours played on the table in ascending order from one to five, if you misplay a card it counts as one of your three ‘strikes’ before the game ends, if you achieve the objective you score a ‘perfect’ 25 points.  After that, you’re probably ready to add the wild cards which add to the difficulty factor. So far this plays pretty well and it can be both frustrating and amusing to see how your fellow player decide on what card to play or discard based on the limited information they have. Well worth looking at and one I will consider for purchase if the novelty of the ‘gimmick’ mechanism doesn’t wear off with a bit more play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun little puzzle to play with your friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Lowered rating from a 7 to a 5. I enjoyed it at first, but it got really stale for me after a few plays. I initially liked the group challenge of trying to build up a big enough vocabulary of unspoken cues so that we might get that elusive perfect game. But my enthusiasm for doing so has worn off quickly, to the point where I no longer care, and I have no desire to play it again. 

It's still a very clever game, but I've just come to the conclusion that (for me, at least) it has almost replay value beyond 4 or 5 plays. Beyond that point, you're either still just hoping to get lucky and get a perfect game, or you're trying to improve (as a group) by building up that aforementioned vocabulary of unspoken cues, implicit understandings of what the correct moves are in various situations, etc. I can see how some people would enjoy that sort of thing, but for me it starts to feel very dry and procedural, like we might as well be sitting in a conference room somewhere designing a flowchart for some insanely boring company policy manual. Not exactly what I'd call "fun".

RATING: 8.5
There is so much to this small card game - it is a surprisingly deep and difficult game.  I dragged my feet on buying it because I thought it would be simple or boring or odd to hold the cards backwards.  None of these things is true.  It is very easy to explain and very easy to start-up.  But after 2 - 3 turns around the table, things get very tricky and very tense - there's a real Russian Roulette feel to many of the choices.   Believe me, there is more than meets the eye in Hanabi.  At about $10, every gamer should own this.

-1 countdown to show and burning down fuse tokens should both create buildup and tension...but the way they're implemented doesn't really do that, as you can freely reverse and avoid them respectively 
-1 seems far too easy to systematically churn the entire deck - at which point max points is just a matter of luck. 
-1 very little replay-ability

Hanabi ist ein kooperatives Kartenspiel, bei dem alle Spieler versuchen, ein besonders schönes Feuerwerk zu entzünden. Der Cloud bei Hanabi: Die Spieler sehen ihre eigenen Karten nicht (!!), man hält sein Blatt quasi verkehrt herum, so dass man die Karten aller anderen Spieler sehen kann - nur seine eigenen eben nicht. So versucht man nun den Spielern durch bestimme Hinweise Tipps zu geben, welche Zahl in welcher Farbe er (womöglich) auf der Hand hält und passend anlegen kann. Auch Hanabi ist mal wieder ein flottes Familienspiel für Zwischendurch.

RATING: 9
This would be a 10/10 rating except for one thing: the truly terrible card design, with TWO pairs of suits barely distinguishable from each other (green/blue, white/yellow). And the "deluxe edition" instead of offering you better cards, inside.... offers tiles. Pretty tiles, but I want to play cards not dominoes FFS.

Anyway, other than that this is an awesome game if played with people who are logical and who play according to some basic conventions (around the order of discarding and adding cards to the hand). It's a painful game to play with people who ignore these considerations. But if everyone's on the same page, it's really beautiful to see people working together in intense concentration and near-silence, and when you induce a series of plays exactly as you'd planned them, it's incredibly satisfying. Can be kinda frustrating when you get a bad deck, though--e.g. with both 2s in a single suit near the bottom.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A co-op card game in which the players are trying to earn the highest score possible by playing cards to a series of piles in the correct numerical order. 

The trick here is that each player cannot see their cards in hand as they are held facing other players instead. (Think Code 777).

On a given turn the players can play a card or give a clue as to the cards held by another player. A clue though can only focus on a given colour within a team mates hand or a given value. 

It' a good game that will likely appeal to non-conflict gamers and those that like working together. The only issue is that players need to be fairly disciplined in following the rules regarding valid clues otherwise the whole thing can devolve into a farce of sorts with body language and intonation giving away more than is really allowed.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great fun game. Memory tester, how easy is it to forget 2 or 3 things?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hanabi is a gem of a game - five suits of cards numbered from one to five representing a firework display. All you and your fellow players have to do is place the cards on the table in the correct order, one to five in each colour. Simple, right? Well, not really, because the catch is that everybody can see your cards except you, there is a limited number of clues, and a person can only tell you about a colour or a number in your hand, never both...and they must include all cards of that colour or number in their clue. It should be easy, but is so much trickier than it sounds. You can play this with children and they will get it straight away. Play it with adults, maybe after something grown up to drink, and watch people go to pieces and curse their lack of short-term memory. You'll learn to fear every discard, and to rejoice in your rare high scores, but will you ever hit the perfect score of 25? If you do manage it, there's a sixth suit of fireworks in the box to throw into the mix...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is an interesting little game. The positives are the cooperative aspect, and the mechanics are unique. The cons would be the lacklustre ending to the game. The theme says that fireworks are going off but there is not really a great cathartic moment at the end to feel like anything was accomplished. As a puzzle that is worked on collectively, it is 10/10 but it is not quite a game.

RATING: 5
Hanabi is perhaps an excellent convention game (and I suspect its popularity mostly grew there). But with a group of regulars, especially who know each other well, implicit communication rules will quickly emerge and the game will be broken. On the opposite side, supposing you're white knights of rules abiding, shutting up for 20 minutes doesn't really bring joy to the table, which is on the contrary what such a light game should inspire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this Game. It was one of the very first games I bought, after I got into the hobby, and it remains one of my favorites to this day. 
Mechanically, it is a simple yet decently solid little puzzle of playing cards in the right order, and managing your hand of cards, with the twist of not being able to see what cards you have. Rather, you rely on the other players giving you clues - and herein lies the real meat of the game. Because in practice, this is a game about getting into your friends' mind(s), and figuring out exactly why they told you that these two cards were yellow at that exact moment? Or why noone has told you anything about your middle card in ages. Maybe it's an irrelevant card, that you can just discard? Or maybe they just haven't gotten around to it yet? 
THIS is what makes me love this game so much. Sitting down with a new constellation of players, explaining the premise, and working out how people communicate under Hanabi's constraints. Sitting down with my partner, and playing for hours on end, again and again, until we get a perfect score - talking at length between rounds of the frustrating and fascinating situations we've each had to deal with during the game. Or simply pulling out Hanabi with the group of Friends I originally experienced it with, and experience the familiar laughter, disbelief and mental gymnastics, as we each, with our own limited knowledge, try to help out each other, without screwing each other over in the process.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this cooperative card game, one is attempting to construct the best fireworks possible. The deck has 5 suits, with cards numbered from 1 to 5. There are three 1's, two of 2/3/4 and one 5 in each suit. Your hand size depends on the number of players, but you cannot ever look at your hand. You hold your hand outwards so your team members can see it. During your turn, you have three choices: 1) give information to another player about their hand, restricted to color or number of the card(s), using a timepiece, 2) discard a card to renew a time piece, 3) play a card blindly.  The goal of the game is to construct the suits in order from 1 to 5, scoring points for those constructed in order. The game ends when you either blow a fuse (playing cards blindly that don't fit) twice, or the deck runs out. 

This is a very good design and I can see why it won the Spiel de Jahres in 2013. You can have fun devising conventions you think will work. You can have fun laughing at people's mistakes. It's also addictive since you want to achieve perfection. I'm looking forward to trying to get 25 pts!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love the situations this puts you in. Games which manage to force you to make tough choices between a small number of options are always good and this one has the lovely effect of getting everyone fully involved while you take your turn because they know which choice is the right one and which is wrong.

I did have one game which was a bit 'meh' but that was just because it was a group that was metagaming so much that they gave all the info away ("That's a white card" *wink* *meaningful look at the white pile waiting for someone to play a 3*, etc.) so it just became a procession of putting down the right cards. I like it when it's played straight but I suppose it's nice that there's that flexibility if your group does want to make it easier.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.7

The parameters about the types of clues that can be given and how are unclear and it incentives you to bend the rules when they are not explicit. This is probably not one I would want to play again unless everyone else was playing.

CONS

LIKE TO SEE

RATING: 8
A fresh take on hand management, deduction, and cooperative gameplay. Simple, but elegantly so. Hours of fun and tension in the tiniest of boxes.

I will not be 'upgrading' to the Deluxe Edition as I feel the holding of the cards is part of the game's novelty, challenge, and, ultimately, its appeal. The conversion of the cards to mahjong-style tiles removes all that. Everyone has played cards, not everyone has played mahjong/dominoes, so the familiarity fades in the Deluxe Edition.

For some reason that I cannot fathom, none of my friends enjoy this game.

RATING: 8

I will not be 'upgrading' to the Deluxe Edition as I feel the holding of the cards is part of the game's novelty, challenge, and, ultimately, its appeal. RATING: 6.5
Gosia / Wiktor
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome co-op that completely eliminates the problem many co-ops have, which is one player playing the game for everyone!

In this game everyone has a hand of 4 cards, the rub is that you cannot look at your cards, only everyone else can!  You start the game by having 8 clue tokens and the game starts be people giving hints to others about their hands.  A hint counts as, these are all your 2's, or 3's, or 4's, or blues, or reds...you give either the #, or color, of all the cards that also share that attribute.  People can discard cards to gain more clue tokens, but watch it, there are only a certain number of cards that you need to complete the game with a decent score.

Lastly?, the goal of the game is to place down the 5 fireworks displays in consecutive order from 1-5.  Can you group handle it?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very intriguing mechanic of not being able to see your own cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

co-op, deduction, memory
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There is a co-op I enjoy after all. A game that tests the group's logic and memory skills. Simple but engaging.
-----
After a few plays I wonder if a group can get to the point where it plays perfectly or so close to perfectly that the game loses its [i]raison d'etre[/i]. I guess in that case, the rule is that every clue you give is also a shot.
-----
After 10+ plays, I found out that I've been playing it wrong this whole time... you are not supposed to get any clue tokens back for playing a card. This is embarrassing, not least considering the number of people I've taught this game to, but it has the wonderful side benefit of making the game an entirely new, even more wonderful experience.

[color=#117bc0][b]Probably rather play:[/b][/color] Mü

RATING: 6
Acho que o mais legal do Hanabi é sua característica anti-intuitiva de jogar cartas sem vê-las. O tema é legal: os jogadores são especialistas em fogos de artifício que devem se juntar para fazer o show mais harmônico possível. Ou seja, as cores devem vir num crescendo. O fogo errado na hora errada estraga tudo. Por isso, para saber o que jogar, você vai depender muito da dica dos outros, da sua capacidade de dedução e um bocado de memória. Mas a mecânica é simples, tornando muito palatável para jogar com parentes que não são jogadores habituais - e rir da confusão.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.4
The design is very smart, not because the hints you can offer, but because of what I call "metahints", the implicit information hideen in your hints (see an example [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/184429/item/4282675#item4282675]here[/url]).

It's very fun to devise a way to transmit as much information as possible with each hint, thanks to these "metahints". And this is the reason I think Hanabi's design is very clever. But the different situations you can find yourself in are limited, and once you know how to deal with them, Hanabi becomes automatic and it's not nearly as fun.

First impression [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/184429/item/4282675#item4282675]here[/url].

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun, light cooperative game with a good dose of memory.  Easy to teach and plays quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hanabi is a great cooperative deduction game. Players have 4 cards in their hands and they all together need to play numbers of 1-5 in five colors in order to win (well you score points for lesser attempts but ultimately you aim for getting all 5's on table). Easy task except you don't know what cards you have but you know which cards others have. On your turn you either a) play a card b) discard a card c) give a hint to a player. When giving hint you must name all cards with same color/number in somebody's hand. Since there is only a limited number of hints available (discarding gives them back) it is painfully good deduction experience. 

The first version (Hanabi & Ikebana) had bad card design. In poor lighting blue and black were too similar and this caused some errors in play way too easily. This would be a non-issue IF cards would differ also in graphical design but no, they are all the same except for colors. Why can't they publish a decent edition of this game? In tin box edition they fixed graphical design by having symbols also but square cards aren't the best possible shape or quality and also it has cludgy lid that won't really hold the game in without rubber band. Update: Abacus edition finally looks to be great edition out of this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice little cooperative game with rather unique mechanics and which plays relatively quickly. Getting full score (25 pts) seems to be more complicated that you may think.
Bonus: the game can be played as Ikebana too, which turns out to be a 2-in-1 game :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An actually rather light and lively collaborative game, Hanabi masterfully avoids the most common danger in its genre (becoming a multiplayer solitaire) by a stroke as simple as depriving a player of any knowledge about his/her cards: to lay out five fireworks on the table following a simple pattern players have to know from the other people on the table what cards they have. Nevertheless, the amount of information available is limited, and players might have to either discard potentially useful cards to be able to receive new hints or bluff and risk a penalty (three penalties end the game).

The rules are an absolute delight to read: the idea behind the game is clever and very concise. The gameplay itself lives up to them but doesn't offer then any new surprise - Hanabi is essentially what it looks, a game about recovering information under a tight, adjustable deadline. With two players it is definitely easier to play, since there are less possible hints and therefore less good hints to choose from: revealing information about a card might already communicate that the card in question should be played out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Semplice cooperativo senza traditori o simili. Il fulcro del gioco di carte (esiste una versione in stile Domino) sta nel far giocare ai propri compagni, nel momento opportuno, le prorpie carte. La particolarità è che tutti, all'infuori di chi ha le carte in mano, vedranno il valore delle stesse. Il gioco è decisamente astratto, l'obiettivo sarebbe quello di generare il più bel fuoco d'artificio della storia ma l'ambientazione si sento proprio poco. Per le sue caratteristiche il gioco richiede da parte di tutti una buona partecipazione e, anche se potrebbe apparire semplice, coordinarsi non sarà mai facile; ad ogni modo esistono varianti e carte speciali per rendere il gioco sempre più complesso e articolato. Per essere un filler/introduttivo mi sembra un ottimo e originale gioco.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
100+ plays. Now I've played this new edition, it all the same so it gets the same comment as the original. It's a tense co-op using just a pack of cards. As a team you're trying to build 1 pile of each colour from 1 up to 5 Solitaire style. There are extras of each number, except the 5s, so there's some give but not much. The tension comes because you can't see your own cards before you play them. You're reliant on other players spending turns informing you about details of your hand (ie these are 1's, or this is green). But you only get so many shots at this before people either have to play correctly to a pile (make 3 mistakes and it's game over) or discard a potentially needed card in order to replenish the supply of chips which allow the team to do a helper turn. The game elevates to you trying to provide / glean the maximum mount of information with the fewest possible hints. Which then builds the tension - when he said this was a 2, did he imply it was a playable 2 or a discardable 2. Given what else I see around the table, and what's on the 5 piles, I'm going to say it's ... playable. Arghhh!!! So you somehow need to build a series of conventions where the same hint means different things in different situations. The game is fun in a quiet, slow, stricken way and is aimed purely at fans of deduction games. I't gets replay if you enjoy the challenge of defining and then refining a set of protocols that consistently enable you a chance at a perfect score. The real downside is that there’s no room for the game chit-chat or shared emotion that are the usual drivers of co-operative games (this may be what makes it more appealing to non co-op lovers), as anything you do can be construed as providing clues above and beyond what you’re allowed to provide. It can be wrenching watching someone draw the wrong conclusion from hints given so far and reach for the wrong card; to keep a straight face and not groan out loud, or make a face, or cough or simply yell out "nooooooooooo". Regardless, or maybe because of, I'm looking forward to the evolving discovery process and seeing how nailable this is with more play with the same group of players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Cool 30 minute deduction co-op card game where players together build 5 runs of 5 without looking at their own cards. Need your brain with this one: Need to remember what info you know about your cards, and need to remember what info has been given to the other players. No Alpha player syndrome with this coop, it seems.

Good for 2 to 5 players. Rules include variants , which helps replayability, and adds complexity if players become really good..

Rumor has it that there's a Solo Play version out there involving a mirror and a blindfold, but I haven't tried it yet.

I, personally, am so bad at this game that, for me, "the only way to win is not to play."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
"About what I expected: A dry, mostly-silent session of solving a logic puzzle, using memory, card counting, clues-by-convention, and second-guessing. None of which I'm fond of. At least it's a co-op, which saves it from being terrible. Definitely shouldn't have won the SdJ."

What I like:
- Co-op. Portable. 

What I don't like:
- Not a fan of memory games
- Not a fan of limited-oommunication co-ops
- Not a fan of second-guessing ("I think he thinks I think...")
- Not a fan of card-counting
- Not a fan of "conventions" a la Bridge bidding systems
- Would be better at 20 minutes (the last game I played took 70)

This definitely shouldn't have won the SdJ. Kenner maybe, but not SdJ. I would put the weight around 2.2, substantially higher than BGG voters, due to the brain-burning depth.

[b]Rating History[/b]
• Original Rating: 8 on Aug 29, 2013 after 8 plays
• Bumped down to a 7 on June 12, 2014 after 12 plays. I don't have much desire to play this game right now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After playing this on-line I raise my rating from 4 to 7.

What I hate in coop games is that they work as a 1player game. No one takes full responsibility for sth. In Hanabi your moves matter. You can make great moves or mistakes. YOUR great moves and YOUR mistakes, without having someone telling you what to do. 

But the main problem with this board game is that you’ll have to be really concentrated, so you remember every clue given to you but also the clues given to your partners. If you make a joke and the players get detracted, everybody forgets everything and the game is ruined. Socializing is bad for this game. I thing that board games should promote socializing.

When playing on line, the clues stay permanently on your cards. That makes the game easier than it should, but at least it is fun, and there is still room for strategic moves.

When playing the real game I try to simulate the Arena feeling, by raising clued cards higher, ranking cards from older to newer and if needed remind players of clues (as if the clues were there permanently for everyone to see). Helps a lot!

P.S. 2 Players? Not for me. The first time I played was with 2 players and I didn't want to touch it again in my life. Thank God for board game Arena, for giving life to this game. If I was the publisher, I would exclude 2-p at all costs. So be warned

(Wife's Point of View: She likes memory games but as it is unplayable with 2-p, we don't get to play it a lot)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Easy game but most fun, this is a good party game . It's different from many party game that i played, in co-op style it's fun and real co-op .

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The perfect co-op game? For such a simple game, there is a surprisingly large amount to learn. When you begin, you begin trying to learn how to interpret clues. As you get better, you will start to introduce a number of 'unspoken' rules that will help you score better, but also make clue giving quite a bit challenging. Different numbers of players really affect the experience. 

As a FYI, this is a "serious" game believe it or not... it's not light at all. If you play with people who have frequent lapses in concentration you will actually get frustrated unlike other, 'less serious', co-op games. Play with a good group and this is fantastic experience like no other board game - definitely invest in the majong style tiles if you find a good crowd to play with. Really, really, really worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

the idea that you don't know your own cards is a nice twist.

inventory 2016-09-04

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very original co-op game. You hold cards in your hand, but you do not get to see them. The other players, who see them, can give you hints as to what they are and the goal is to get the cards down in order and by color. Your hints are limited and you can only make three mistakes. Getting all five sets in order is crazy. Be careful that your hint is not misinterpreted.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
~25 plays
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a fantastic filler card game as long as you don’t take it too seriously. It would be very easy to interpret the rules in a way that you all have to play in relative silence with straight faces that would never give the active player any clues but I have found that the game can cause hilarious outcomes when the players are trying to help each other, without giving too much away; giving the active player clues about the best thing to tell one of the other players is great fun and if they don’t understand your clues it can lead to an amazing amount of fun for a very simple and quick playing game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Cooperative card game with fireworks theme. Everyone can see your cards, but you can't. You can give other players clues about which cards they are holding. The object is to play cards in five suits in order, this represents performing a sequence of fireworks displays.

RATING: 7
I am not the biggest fan of cooperative games, but this one is an exception. I think it's because of the whole clue giving aspect, meaning that one person can't just lead the game. More importantly, I love that it's not "we all win or we all lose" as their is a simply gradient of point scoring. I understand that you could implement that in other coop games, but meh... It feels that the developers just want everyone to lose, and I am not a fan of that.

RATING: 6
This is a cooperative information game, where you're trying to give other players clues as to what plays they should make during their turn, but are restricted in what you can tell them.  The gimmick of this game is that you hold your hand of cards backwards, so that everyone else knows what you have, but you don't.  This is not really my kind of game anyway, but my real complaint is that, once people start playing with the same group multiple times, they inevitably develop ways of communicating information that skirts the restrictions of the rules (such as syllable emphasis or non-verbal clues).

(5+ plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

We would play Love Letter, Sushi Go! in between plays of Hanabi.

Bottom line: great game with the right crowd.

RATING: 7.5
Cooperative game, where all players have a number of cards that have to be played in the right order, to get points. The catch: you can't see your cards. Players have to give (limited) hints on numbers & colors and deduce their cards from these hints. The fun of the game is to start developing communication patterns with your group so that you can deduce the correct cards with the fewest hints.

RATING: N/A
Unusual co-operative game where you can see everyone else's cards but not your own. In your turn, you can either play a card, discard a card or reveal a specific piece of info about the cards in another player's hands (either indicating which cards are a particular number or which are a particular colour). As with some versions of bridge, 'conventions' about  where you place cards you plan to play and those you plan to discard draw a very thin line between strategy and cheating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Hanabi is my kind of cooperative game and my partner likes it quite a bit.  The rules and the stucture of the game play are very simple and easy to teach.  However, the game itself requires quite a bit of deductive and tactical thinking. I think it play fairly well with two, although better with more players (with two the turns can end up being somewhat uneven - one player gives clues, the other plays cards). This game ends up getting played quite a bit because it plays quickly, takes up little table space, and we always have a desire to beat our previous high score.  

Update: Wow, the wild cards make this challenging!

RATING: 8
$9

Goal Met :star::star::star::star::star: $1 or less per play

This is truly an unique co-op game that has an Indian poker feel to it. I did pretty poorly the first game, scoring 3 points before we blew the fuse. The second my girlfriend and I did pretty well, scoring 21 points. This is truly a game that tests your composure under stress and see if you can retain your memory of the cards that were in your hands. 

I thought I won't make a mistake playing a 2-player game with girlfriend but boy was I wrong about that. This game requires concentration, and under stress we tend to forget things! There is enough meat there to make this game an 8, where I would want to challenge myself and play with others. 

This is a solid game that scales up to 5 players. It comes with an extra suit to spice things up and up the difficulty a level. This game is well worth the price tag like Love Letter.

RATING: 8
Fun with familiar players, bad with bad players.

What annoys me about Hanabi is that the deck can make it impossible to achieve a perfect score. For example if the last three cards in the deck are red 1s, then the maximum possible score is 23, since plyaing a card force you to draw a card and the deck ends with the deck. There could be two possible solutions for this:
- The game doesn't when the deck ends, but when players run out of cards to play (or three misses).
- The deck could be quasi-randomly stacked in a way, which rules out impossible deck combinations.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've revisited this elegant design online and contrary to being a co-op it can engender a less than positive experience, obviously dependent on who you are playing with.

The main source of the negativity is the potential feeling of letting the team down, advice perceived as finger pointing etc. for it is easy to make a mistake: the simple clue giving often implies subtle hinting difficult to tune into until either experienced or intuit quickly and there is the issue of being able to recall what clues were given (card moving can assist here). 

(Surprisingly, visiting online play has revealed pre-game discussion of conventions of play and what certain clues mean, such as if not given clues for a while discard from right conveyor belt style, number clues means keep etc. I find this tactical advice (just short of saying what the card is) not only removes some of the tense uncertainty of card type and the deduction work, it is also counter productive because all the ritual rules makes for confusion and possibly prone to mistakes. It is far better to let the players learn what is productive clue giving and resource management). 

Also the design tightens up tableau placement as the game progresses (there is only one 5 in each colour) making correct plays even more important, so again a potential trigger of strong psychological and emotional repercussions. Sure it can make for stomach churning moments, but I wonder if co-ops with dice are the way to go to temper the feeling of letting down the team, as no-one can point the finger at a bad roll.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like all cooperative games, this one seems like it could get boring if one person takes control of everything, but I did enjoy playing it. I like the 'Indian Poker' mechanic.

RATING: 9
THIS is the Antoine Bauza card game that should be garnering the most attention (not that other one... bleh). Crisp, clean design. A deduction game in which the rules for clue giving actually work. I generally do not like cooperative games at all, but this is a cooperative game that I will actually request to play. Ideal length that is a perfect complement for its challenge level (ie, it doesn't overstay its welcome).

Next time someone in the group suggests 7 Wonders (bleh, bleh) I will counter with this gem.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I don't generally like co-operative games because they tend to feel like team solitaire and have the problem of one player taking over. But Hanabi is a marvel. It avoids the alpha player problem by strictly limiting the amount of information players can exchange; indeed that's the whole point of the game. Each player holds their hand of cards backwards, so that everyone except them can see them, and the team attempts to play all five suits out on to the table in ascending order. It's deliciously counterintuitive (at first players keep ruining the game by accidentally looking at their cards!) and admits some advanced tactics once players start trusting each other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My wife and I REALLY enjoy this as a two player game. It takes practice with the same group of players to get good (assuming you don't allow cheating with your voice inflections). The only problem is that my wife and I are good enough with each other now (we only play with the rainbow cards anymore) that it can be frustrating to play with other people.

RATING: N/A
1.71wt 2-5pl 25min COOP
BGG-R-270
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In Hanabi, you're trying to play five different color fireworks in consecutive order, but you cannot see your own hand, so you must spend clues to identify to other players what cards/tiles that share a color or number, and they then aim to play legal plays. Your goal is to score all five suits with all five numbers. You can technically lose, but winning is not so much the goal, but winning with a high score.

The game is pure co-op with basic logic puzzle stuff, and it's sorta interesting... but I find it... sorta boring. I'm not playing a game at an 80's arcade, I'm not really motivated by high scores. I appreciate what the game is, but there's something, maybe its deceptive simplicity, that makes if not stand out for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
[Abacusspiele Deluxe Edition] Abstract games are not my cup, but this is a pure genious mechanic: easy and deep. Hanabi is a brilliant co-op game, fast, simple and intelligent.

The deluxe version adds very much, mostly a beautiful 'mahjong' feeling to the game - also if very expensive.

RATING: 5
A cooperative deduction game. Have a 5 card suits - numbered 1-5 and are trying to play in order. The twist is that the player cannot see his own cards but only the ones the others have. You have to supply clues to the others of what to play or discard, you have a limited number of clues you can give before you must discard a card to get the ability to issue a clue back. 

Ok for what it is, but didn't get me too excited.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hanabi is one of my favorite games of all time. Extremely simple rules that lead to fairly deep deduction and a good amount of strategy.

Can be frustrating to play with new players, however, when they give terrible clues.  It can also be difficult to keep your mouth shut and avoid giving away more information than is fair.

Trick for people with bad memories: use the orientation of the cards in your hand to keep track of the information you have about each card.

RATING: 10
Masterful design. Antoine "the Koopa King" Bauza continues to show his ability to produce innovative and refined games that push the medium forward. This game might get old after a few plays, but you can play it with another group and it becomes fresh again. This solidifies Bauza as the designer with the greatest range of great games, none of which are clones of the others.

Tentative rating: 9/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The mechanic is brilliant, but the actual play is only so so. Theme is loosely tacked on and like most cooperative games it becomes a bit "solved" after only a few plays to where the decision making switches over from having to actual think about things to just making the motions. 

UPDATE (June2017): After continuing to play this more and more and developing conventions I like it more. The game evolves from being a bit of an autopilot to being a bit more deep when you're able to give clever clues within the convention structure you've set up with skilled players. I personally find this by far the most fun way to play the game and would give the game quite a lower rating if you play it the way many "purists" would want you to (with memory elements and stating no agreements may be set up, even commons sense ones). But if you set up a few common sense agreements like always drawing cards into one side of your hand and discarding from the other you're able to set up more clever plays that has made this game stand out a bit more for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very original gameplay, requiring very careful attention to saying the right thing and proper interpretation. I've only played 2 player so far so I'm looking forward to more tries.

RATING: 4
February 15, 2014: I really don't like co-operative games.

==============================


Only play with non-gamers; they tend to get more into the spirit of the game (which are the rules), that is, only giving out information that you're only allowed to give out.

This game is a bit low on the deduction and high on the tactics and guessing. That is one of the primary sources of tension, and why it's much more fun to play this with non-gamers.

UPDATE August 2012: Gave this to my aunt; I'm not sure whether or not to add it back into my collection.

RATING: 9

RATING: 5
I usually dislike cooperatives because I don't like other people telling me what to do on my turn. Hanabi mostly avoids this trap, which is good. It also has the benefit of scored wins, rather than a simple win/lose boolean result. Rules are very simple, play is quick. It's a little awkward to have to hold my cards all the time so that other people can see them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Cleverly inverted co-op card game. The theme is a little thin (if a game with these mechanisms is going to have a pasted-on theme, I think it a better one would have been codebreaking or bank robbers trying to break into a safe). It's fun, fast, and easy to take with you. It's hard not to give away extra hints to other players through facial expressions, but overall I like this fresh take on a cooperative game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hanabi is a very inexpensive cooperative card game that everyone seems to enjoy a lot.  The whole "show everyone your hand but don't look at it yourself" mechanic seems to pique folks curiosity about the game, and once they play it most really like it.

The game plays quickly and the cards are well made.  I think it's a great game for families; I do believe think it would be tough to play with children younger than 8 or so however as a bit of wrong info can royally hose your game.

Good game, good price, unique and light theme, nice vibrant colors on the cards (yet still colorblind friendly), quick playtime - perfect filler.

I know there is a tile version of the game which is probably nice, but personally the card version is my preference since its a fraction of the cost.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.85
Made our own deck.  Had a great time playing a 5P game.  We laughed and bonded over this game.....even though we had no idea what we were doing!  :)

Have played a few times as a 2P game which is also a fun way to play.

Recommended game, but you need the right group/mind-set.

At first we used no conventions....absolutely zero.  Now we play with one convention:  We only give clues about cards that can be played.  At first I thought this would be 'cheating' the game, but we've found it equally or even more rewarding than trying to play with no conventions at all.

The game worked fine with no (and I mean zero) rules/conventions, but now that we've added one convention, it still works well and gives us a better chance to do well....I've found it more rewarding with that one convention.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Description: Cooperative, mind boggling, deduction card game with limited communication options where players are collecting sets of fireworks in 5 different colors.
Weight: Medium to light.
Players: 2 to 5.

Impression: A genius game by Antoine Bauza. After a period of adaptation to the mechanics in which you can't and must not see your cards but only those of other players there is a period of learning how to optimize your clues and strategy. The game is very hard to win, but extremely rewording and it is best when is played with the same people so you can easily enter their mind. After a while you will be able to understand each other without even talking. I love playing this game with my sister. It's a kind of ritual. There is also a hard mode with rainbow colored fireworks but we aren't even close to trying that. Great game all together.

Likes: Whole deduction mechanic in which you see other player's cards and they see yours and you must find the best way to communicate without spending too much clue tokens (and there are 9 of them). Feeling of mutual understanding when you manage to score >20 points.

Dislikes: Because of limited communication rules the tends to be somewhat antisocial, and people often become very frustrated due to misunderstanding or forgetting previous information. It can even shake up the relationship.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game is a rub.  It could be fun with the PERFECT group.  Everyone in the group would have to be very smart and have a very good memory.  Very.

This is a game that I quickly found myself getting very annoyed with the players who weren't doing well.  I HATE games that make me not like the other players.  Maybe that's a personal flaw of mine.  My way of avoiding that kind of animosity: don't play these types of games.

RATING: 8
What a great surprise! This little card game is huge in fun. Although, this is a French game designed by famed 7 Wonders designer, Antoine Bauza, Hanabi is the Japanese word for "fireworks". 
My wife and I played this game first before introducing it to our gaming group family. My wife was skeptical at first about it simply because I told her it was a game about fireworks called Hanabi, which made her nose curl. After a slight confusion during the quick explanation of the rules, a few rounds into the game her skepticism turn to excitement. 
To both our surprise, the game seem very intense. The challenge of trying to acquire the best possible score of 25 will have you wanting to play again and again. 
Having played Hanabi several times since I have found it works as well as a two player game as it does a five player game. I highly recommend this unique card game to everyone. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It would be interesting to see how this plays out with more players.

RATING: 7.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This wasn't a game either my wife or I was considering to buy - I don't even like co-ops, and while she does, she mainly plays them with a friend of hers. Anyway, this friend recently bought this game for her as a birthday present - and I'm really glad she did, because I have much enjoyed our plays so far. It feels a bit Knizia-like in how the ridiculously simple rules (really you don't need to buy this game, you can play it with an ordinary deck of cards - with a few modifications - and any kind of tokens) lead to a completely unique game with some very interesting strategy. While I generally dislike co-ops, this one is unique, to my knowledge, in having the players all have access to different (but overlapping, at least with 3+ players) information, with the main point of the game being to devise an efficient method of communicating this information to each other. This allows the game to be nothing like the usual co-operative game where the players all play as effectively just one player against the game, something which to my knowledge has only previously been avoided by either playing in real time or by having a "traitor" mechanic, neither of which tend to be types of game which I enjoy.

I am a keen bridge player, and Hanabi actually reminds me quite a lot of that game, in the sense that much of the game is about communication, using just the means prescribed by the rules. In the case of Hanabi, it seems to be left to the group's discretion exactly what level of discussion is allowed - presumably the "correct" way is to play in silence except when giving information, but even then some "groupthink" will creep in. (Even in the first play, and definitely subsequently, we were discarding our oldest non-known-about cards, and informing each other which cards these were, which allowed us to prioritise which information to give first.) There are a huge amount of inferences to be made in this game - about why your fellow players chose to give the information they did, and when they did. It really helps to know how the other players think - which makes it a great game for regular play and discussion with a group you know well. And the game seems to be insanely hard (we have won just 1 of I think 5 or 6 3p games, even though we were probably exchanging more information than we should by conversation - and in our one 5p game we got nowhere near). No doubt the appeal will fade in time (I wrote these comments in November 2015, it's now the end of January 2016 and I'm not desperate to play again soon, although I still really like the game), but I've found this game really fascinating in a way which I didn't expect. It is well deserving of all the awards and buzz it's got.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Hanabi places a deductive spin on set-collection and has earned a reputation to be a mainstay among co-operative games. I can see why. There is not much new or profound things to be said about this game, and it has very little in the way of substantial faults--except perhaps that it is largely player-driven. This is a blessing and a curse. You will have those serious groups, making a strong attempt to memorize their cards and give rules-kosher, tactical, hints; just as much as you will have those less-serious groups rollicking with laughter at the ridiculously-obvious hints that are apparently not obvious enough. 

In either case, if the players aren't mentally invested in the "tone" of each game, it will play out to be rather lackluster. Still, Hanabi is an ingenious game which can serve to show non-gamers a glimpse into the possibilities of creative design in hobby tabletop games, and well-deserving of the SDJ.

(+) Original mechanisms
(+) Player-driven with high interaction and potential for fun/rewarding meta-gaming
(+) High-replayability value for the challenge of beating your previous score

(-) Can be frustrating with a poor group
(-) Co-op nature can lead to one poor player tanking the experience for everyone
(-) Metagaming can (unintentionally) make the game too easy, resulting in hollow-earned victories.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This game is spectacular.  Opened the brand new box and read the rules with three non-gamers.  There were looks of "this sounds too simple to be any fun". However, once we started we were all hooked. We ignored the concert in the park we were watching to play a game. Then, after the concert we played another round.  Then, the couple we played with asked to come over to play again the next day. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm not into coops, so not sure how to rate this as I'm not really in the target audience. Based on a 3-player game, I enjoyed it more than I expected to, perhaps partly because it's short and simple/elegant. The communicating only through formal information ("this and this are green" etc) reminds of communication with a Bridge partner, something which I find theoretically interesting but sort of off-putting in practice. I felt like I got to "play with"/experience that kind of formal narrow communication in Hanabi for a much lower time/effort price than if I were to get into Bridge.

I've since played and enjoyed it several more times. Not something I'd actively seek out, but it does seem more interesting than traditional coops (which could usually just be a solitaire game with a single player running everything - or an alpha player running the team) due to the limited communication channel. So that is cool.

RATING: 9
Truly unique little gem, Antoine Bauza's Magnum Opus. I am discovering layer after layer of strategy, subtle nuances begin to flourish with meaning. It is like "Inception" movie among board games.

RATING: N/A
My dad had difficulty discerning the color of the cards, especially the blue and green. He is not color blind, but the blue background of the card made it difficult to clearly identify the color. If the border of the card was also colored, it might be easier to identify them when giving a clue to the other player. 

I can see people enjoying this game, but my family and I have poor memory, making this game frustrating to play. You could use markers to keep track of clues, but at that point you might as well play with the cards face up.

RATING: 3.5
I've played this game several times now. I gues it's an ok game. Nice to play at a bar. But something about it just makes my skin crawl while playing it. Probably because it's another of those games where it's all about memory. There's a theme with a lot of the games I rate poorly. They want you to remember things. Like the game Memory. I'm not just awful at that game, I'm really awful. I can only remember like the last two cards I looked at. 

With Hanabi at least I can arrange the cards in my hand so that I know which ones I should know the value of. And I can also use my other hand under the table wit the number I'm supposed to remember. This game is really just group solitaire, which is fine, but why does it have to stress me out with the whole memory thing?

--Jan2015-- I've observed several games now of Hanabi.  And have asked to sit out on each occasion.  I find the questions the game asks don't resonate with me - nor do I enjoy the activities the game requests of its players.  I neither find it "play" nor "entertainment."  YMMV, naturally.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This can be a very tense and strategic game, however I have found that it is impossible for people to play by the spirit of the rules.

It is too easy, and too inviting, to try and give 'extra' information when playing the game "THIS is a two, and this is also a two". Or people say after a game "Well, if you noticed, I was always pointing first at the card I wanted you to play." It seems people are eager to come up with their own secret codes for how to defeat the game. This is a coop game, the only person you are cheating against is yourself.

Beyond just the obvious example above, I have noticed that you can gain so much extra information just by watching the expressions on other player's faces when you go to grab a card. You reach for the one of two cards that might apply and you can just see people starting to cringe, or look away from you.  Or conversely, you reach for one of two cards that might apply and someone sighs in  relief.

I recently played with an adult player who hates to lose games, and she was TERRIBLE about this. She kept trying to give everyone extra information either through extremely blatant facial expressions or by emphasizing how she was pointing at cards.

Some might say that is just part of the game, but at what point does it cross from 'part of the game' into giving extra information that defeats the core purpose of the game?

So... I could still be convinced to play this game, but I am never going to suggest we  play it during a game night.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Tamás

Ez a játék egy kommunikáción alapuló kooperatív játék ahol egy isteneknek és a népnek tetsző tűzijátékot kell létrehozni. 

A mechanika egyszerű. A pakli 5 színben lévő 1-5-ig tartó számsorból áll. Ezeket a lapokat kell kijátszani 1-től sorrendben. 

Az igazi nehézséget az adja, hogy a kezünkben lévő 4 vagy 5 lapot mindenki látja csak mi nem. Így a többi játékos segítségével kell meghatározni melyik lapot is akarjuk lerakni és javítani a tűzijátékunk minőségét. 
A tippeléssel vigyázni kell, mert 3 három hiba után az istenek esővel mossák el a parádénkat és egy árva füttyöt sem kapunk a mutatványért. 

A 25 lapból 20-at letudunk rakni akkor nagy tapsra számíthatunk.  

Az alapjátékban van nehezítési lehetőség egy 6 szín bevezetésével.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good cooperative deduction game. I'm not sure how much fun this would be as a social game without a bit of chat throughout the game - nothing to divulge anything too important, but a bit of "I can see a really good move, but I can't tell you what it is," really injects some fun into the proceedings.

There are choices aplenty and for a cooperative game it feels like you've got control of your own actions. After all, you always know something each of the players doesn't. Sometimes some risks are taken with discards, and you always hope your hints (revealing information) are interpreted correctly. It all adds a bit of tension and excitement. Rules are easy and it fills 45 minutes pleasantly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
In my work life I never enjoyed jobs where I had to rely too much on other people or jobs where other people had to rely too much on me.  I mean specifically "teamwork" type projects etc...  This game is that to me.  It makes me angry when someone says "why did you do that, it's illogical" or "that clue made no sense"...this is the only game I've ever quit in the middle.

I hate it. It is a 2 on my personal scale.  The design gets a 9, and if coops are your sort of thing (apparently they aren't mine) you'll love it.

But I hate it.  Actively.  Sorry ratings police.

Only in my collection because my family likes it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Antoine Bauza
機制特殊的小品合作遊戲
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent cooperative deduction game about putting on the perfect fireworks show. There are five suits, and in each suit there are three 1 cards, two each of 2-4, and one 5. Players try to cooperatively play cards in order. That is, you can't play a blue 2 before the blue 1 is played. The trick? YOU CAN'T SEE YOUR OWN HAND. That's right, you see everyone else's hand, just not your own.

Players have three options on their turn: play a card, discard, or give a clue. You start the game with 8 clue tokens which are required to give a clue, and you can get back spent clues by discarding. A clue is telling one player information about a specific number or suit. For example, "These two cards -- these are red." Or "you have one 5 and it's this one here on the end." There are also three error tokens, which you get if you play a card out of order. Three errors ends the game early. You can also lose by running out of time - when the deck goes empty, players get one more round and then the game ends.

Technically there is a score chart you go by, adding up all the points from successfully played cards, 25 being the best score, but most of the time we play to win a perfect game. So once a perfect game is impossible, we'll usually restart. But you play how you like. It takes genuine effort not to "cheat a little" in this game. For example, you're just dying to talk about why the card Leon just played was a bad call but to do so might clue Leon into his hand. Also, I find it fun to establish playing conventions sort of like Bridge. Depending on who you talk to, this can also be cheating. (I call it handicapping.) I play (and announce to all before the start) that I'll be adding new cards to my right and discarding cards from my left. So anyone can look what is my leftmost card and know that if I shouldn't discard it they'd better give me information soon.

Clue giving is an art, and half the fun of the game is analyzing after-the-fact what clues could improve. We play that clues should generally be "actionable." That is, if I tell you "this is a three" I'm telling you that it's a playable three, and is of the same suit as one of the played twos already out there. If I tell you these two are red, and the red 2 is out, it's telling you at least of of them is an important red 3 or higher. On your turn, you're allowed to ask other players "what do you know about your hand?" and if playing with new players it's not a bad house rule to correct them if they misremember information you know they were given. 

It's a simple game to learn and hard to master. I love games like this although I'm mediocre at them. Bring on the fireworks!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cool mechanism, but not my cup of tea.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 10
Hanabi is all-around an extremely clever game. It's a challenging puzzle with wonderfully elegant mechanics, and it has the potential to be really, really hilarious. You'll find yourself completely livid with another player for misinterpreting your clue, but you won't be able to express your anger until the game is over!

Every facet of this game is a strength. Cooperative games frequently have the problem of one player acting as a leader and bossing the other players around, but the limited communication in Hanabi makes that problem impossible to encounter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cooperative game. Objective is to play 1-2-3-4-5 in order in 5 suits (there are 3 1s, 1 5 and 2 of all other #s in each suit). You see everybody else's hand of 4-5 cards but not your own, and there are strict communication rules, so this game is immune to bossypants syndrome, and more like Space Alert, Wok Star etc.

3 options on your turn:

1. Play a card (and draw 1), If it's not a legal play, get a strike. 3 strikes and everybody loses.

2. Give information. Discard a clue token (start with 8) to point out to somebody all the cards he has of a particular suit or number.

3. Discard a card and gain a clue token. But look out if you discard the last copy of a card, preventing a suit from completion!

As the giver, you have to identify the riskiest player and guide him. Who you don't pick can also be telling. I think giving somebody a 1-card clue should also only be reserved for emergencies.

As the receiver, you have to figure out if the giver is telling you to play, keep or discard that card, and if what he specifically said about those cards says anything about the other cards in your hand.

Lots of other second-level and third-level info like in other deduction games.

A lot easier with a regular group, but I think the fun is to figure out the conventions in-game with experienced strangers, then apply them.

The Zendo concept applied beautifully to cooperative play. Shades of Tichu (teams), Pow Wow (don't see what you have) and interesting deductive reasoning are all in here.

4+2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 4.5
In one month going from 6.5 to 8 rating. 

It's deduction game meets co-op. But it's also a double think game and a game of trust, instead of "I think that you think that I know that you ..." it's more like "it's not what I tell you but why I tell you" and "if nobody told you anything else, that's all you need to know" (unless we just didn't have the time. Oops.). 

I need some more plays, but somehow it seems that 4 and more player might be more chaotic. Playing with 3 seemed best so far (you get a bigger hand). Will try some more. 

Played German edition, the original artwork was a couple of levels more beautiful. Will probably make my own copy (as Germany is far away and nobody is importing this). 

Why I like it: It's my replacement for Mastermind, but it's a group activity with psychology included. Good stuff.

RATING: 7
Played 1 4P game. Hanabi's a unique take on a co-operative filler game. Not knowing what is in one's own hand, but knowing what is all the other players' hands is unnerving as you're trying to deduce what is in your hand via verbal cues. A lot of trust has to be established in this game, in hopes that your partners are giving you clues for a good reason. There is a strong memory aspect to this game, so it's probably not a good idea to play this when players are tired or looking for something light to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Initial impressions: This game is a lot of fun, and it's the first cooperative game I've seen that uses this particular mechanic. It was a bit of a challenge to remember to not look at the cards when you draw them from the deck. It was also challenging to *not* find ways to give wildly more information than you were supposed to give.

I'm a bit disappointed that the symbols for the different colours were changed for the most recent version of the game. While the kanji used are beautiful, they are also really hard to describe, which means that the game is less playable if you have colour-blind players in your group. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2014: 8. Excellent, light-ish co-op game, fantastic for non-gamers!  Was a huge hit on my choir tour, people wanted to play again and again.  It was fun to make fireworks sounds whenever we got something right. :)

UPDATE: I take back my "non-gamer" comment.  I think you need a certain amount of "gamer" in you in order to understand the unconventional mechanics. I had a terrible experience trying to explain to my Dad that it's a co-op game and that you can't look at your cards.  There may be hope: my Dad *did* eventually understand that you can't change the order of your cards in Bohnanza, so maybe one day he'll get this one too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
#54 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2017)
#32 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2016)
#12 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

Hanabi totally blew my mind when I first played. I love cooperative games. I love games with a memory aspect. I absolutely relish uniqueness. Hanabi felt fresh and innovative. Unforunately, it doesn't hold up particularly well over time. You begin to develop certain methods when playing with the same people to where it begins to feel samey. When playing with new players, it's easy to become frustrated when they play in a way that you now know to be suboptimal. However, it's still a real joy to get to that point! And even still, I enjoy the occasional game. When I consider the fun and experiences I have had playing this $10 game over 80 times in person and many other times I couldn't track online, it deserves a lot of praise and accolades. I cannot stress enough that this is a game everyone should give a try!

Acquired: April 2013 - gift from Dan

Cooperative

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[2012-09-23]
A DriveThruReview-t készítő Joel Eddy játékai között bóklásztam, mikor megtaláltam a Hanabit, ami tőle 10-es osztályzatot kapott. Rögtön utána néztem mi is ez a kis játék. Nagy szerencsémre az 5 színből és 50 lapból álló játék játszható a Fiasko játék lapjaival így rögtön ki is tudtam próbálni. Hihetetlen ötlet a lapokat fordítva tartatni a játékosokkal és ezzel egy okos kooperatív játékot sikerült megalkotni. Megmondhatjuk egy színből vagy számból melyik lapok konkrétan melyikek egy játékos kezében egy token felhasználásával, amit szerezni egy lap eldobásával tudunk. Harmadik akcióként pedig a játék célját valósíthatjuk meg, tűzijátékot építhetünk, de ehhez helyes lapot kell leraknunk. Tehát tulajdonképpen egy kis memóriára és jó megérzésre van szükség a játékhoz. De ahogy Joel is mondta jól játszani nem könnyű és gondolkodásra készteti a játszókat. Nagyon ötletes, nagyon egyszerű jó kis játék a Hanabi, ami akár otthon is elkészíthető. Nem véletlen Joel jó osztályzata. A pontszám akár még emelkedhet is.

[2017-02-26]
Rengeteg parti van benne, mert játékosszámtól függően más a játék, a szivárvány lapok is más dimenziókat adnak a társashoz. Ettől függetlenül nem emelek a ponton.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hanabi is quite a unique cooperative game where you don't get to see the cards in your hand, only the cards the everyone else is holding. Using vague number and color hints, you attempt to deduce what cards you should play and what you can throw away. I really enjoy this game and I've always had a good time playing. I think the game scales well too. With 2 players, you have more control over the clues you give, and with 4 players, you have a wider range of cards to look at. I've never managed to get a perfect store, but each time we play, I always want to keep trying with the hopes of getting all 25 cards into their stacks. One day...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This friendly cooperative game is a nice change of pace from all the cut-throat hyper-competitive games that we sometimes play. With games like these, I may even start to like cooperative games in general one day.

RATING: 10
Brilliant little co-op that is a cross between Code 777 and Indian poker, in that you can see everyone else's cards but your own and are working as a team in order to get the cards down in order.

UPDATE: A group favorite (and one of mine). I'd love to get a copy of the deluxe edition with the tiles - they're very much worth it. I think what I like best is that everyone has to really do their own thing, so you really are working together as a team, and the weakest link really does pull you down. Also, the quest for a perfect score remains elusive, but it's nice to have a concrete number of how well you did to track your plays and see if you can't get more tiles the next time you play. The short playtime also is a nice bonus - it makes it a fun and worthwhile filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An unique and interesting game.  A co-op game that geniusly avoids "the overbearing leader" problem.  

The trick to playing well is to get people to understand more than just the basic thing you just said and at the same time, understanding what is in your own hand based on what others have said.  Deduction at its best.

There are genuine moments of stress and tension as you try to make decisions using only limited information - never has laying down a single card been so anxiety inducing!

edit - finally got a perfect 25!!!! that will probably never happen again :)

have not been logging my plays of this but it is probably in the 70's by now.  i love it.

RATING: 9
Addictive co-operative game. Players must assist each other in ordering 5 (or 6 with a variant) sets of coloured cards in ascending order from 1-5. The catch is that clues can only involve how many of a particular coloured card a player has or how many of a particular numbered card they have. Lots of fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
More plays:

Clever, but it's still a coop ... not for me! I'd rate it a 3 or 4, but it is still a good design so I'll only drop this to 5. 

----
First plays:
A very clever cooperative deduction game. Fun to play, if you like to think and have a group that can think along with you. You need to have some conventions, like putting your oldest cards on one end of your hand, or rotating cards you know about, in order to play well; of have a phenomenal memory, I suppose! You also have to be able to figure out why someone is telling you something at the moment they are telling you, or why no one has said anything at all. Is it because it's OK to discard everything, or to play everything? Think deep!

[b]--- Summary ---[/b]
There are 4 suits, each with 3 1s, 2 2s, 2 3s, 2 4s, and 1 5. Players each have a hand of 4 cards, facing away from themselves (like Code 777, you can see everyone else's hands but not your own). There are also several clue chips nearby, as well as 3 strike markers.

On your turn, either:
- discard a card: flip a used clue marker face up and draw a replacement card for your hand
- play a card: only legal plays are the next-highest number for each of the colors (so start with 1, then play 2, etc.); place the card in its column on the table, then draw a replacement card for your hand
- give a clue: flip a clue chip face down and tell a player about their cards. May either point out all the cards of a single color, or all cards of a single number.
If you make an error, either by discarding the last of a card that you need for a sequence or by playing a card that is not the next in a sequence, you get a strike; 3 strikes and everyone loses the game.

The game ends if you complete all sequences, get 3 strikes or draw the final card (in which case all players, including the one who drew that last card, get one final turn). Score VP based on how many cards you were able to play correctly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A nice relaxing yet surprisingly stressful game. The limited options of giving clues to other people and trying to come up with the right ones... requires a bit of training and strategy.

Got really surprised by how much fun this game was for what a small game with really simple rules. Great strategic short relaxing co-op. Like it so far.

Especially surprised everyone in our gaming group liked it. We usually play heavier games, but we love co-ops and this one is just so unique and enjoyable, I think this is a keeper.

Edit: After a lot more plays this weekend, we sort of figured out some strategies of giving clues, but it's still a challenging game. Raising the rating to 9.5, it's a very often played game due to it's short play time and whole lot of strategy going on. We usually play more silently, so we don't let out aditional clues, we just want to beat the game. But still, we're able to laugh during the play. Although sometimes the laugh is a desperate one. Like when a person is given clues so that he knows 4 out of 5 cards in his hand exactly and when you ask about his hand, he says he knows nothing. But the game is still a great fun and I see it being played for a long time.

Wonder how it will be when we figure out the base game and add the rainbow expansion. It's something to really look forward to when you enjoy it already as a base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When I first heard about this game I was very interested in it as a quick filler/strategic party game.  After playing it though I gotta say it underwhelmed me.  The ideas are pretty clever and it's not a bad game by any means but all-in-all it's just not super fun to me.

I will say that I'm interested in a truly honest game to see if that changes my opinion any, I think it will slightly.  Every game I've played so far has involved a good amount of cheating.  Whether it's players putting a lot of inflection or emphasis on certain words when they give clues or saying aloud what they've deduced is in their hands (thereby essentially telling other players what is in their hands).  Yet I have noticed the nuance in the strategy of the game that can exist when not playing the game so loosely and it does intrigue me.

Although I also feel once you've mastered that nuance it will probably get boring and it's not a deep enough game to garner any more out of it.

I'm coming around to this little game.  I still have yet to play a truly honest game, it may not even be possible.  But for a quick filler there is a decent amount of fun and right amount of thinky-ness where you can play with literally anybody.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game. It is frustrating but there is a bit of a meta game. For example, you don't always read about the cards you know, sometimes you read the person to get an idea what to play. I know it's a bit against the rules, but it really adds more depth. Also, as you play it with the same opponents, you set up little conventions, such as the order in which you discard or how you arrange your cards. It seems like it would be accessible for everyone, but I've played it with a few people who just didn't get it. I'd give it a 10 for the weight if that was the case.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Astonishingly good cooperative deduction game where players aim to, as a group, lay down sets of 1-5 in 5 colours. The trick is that cards are held facing outwards, and information able to be shared is limited to either "these cards are [colour]" or "these cards are [number]". It's an amazingly elegant, timeless design -- and it's great fun.

My rating would be higher if not for two problems: it's surprisingly hard to play without inadvertently cheating unless table-talk is absolutely suppressed (it's so easy to give away information with gasps of relief etc.), but if you're all sitting quiet and blank-faced then that's not a terribly social atmosphere. I also don't enjoy memory games and Hanabi does have a strong memory element unless you allow notes or reminders. It is quite good enough as a pure deduction game so I think it is better if the rules are bent to keep it that way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
Watch your friends point at a card in their hand, gleaming with confidence, calling it a yellow 3 when it's actually a white 4. Hilarity ensues. It's pretty easy to avoid "losing" entirely though so ultimately, the stakes don't feel as high as they could be.

RATING: 7
[Abacusspiele 2012 edition] I bought this so that I can preserve my original Hanabi & Ikebana copy.

This is a challenging puzzle games, even for adults.  Players need some tacit agreement to understand the hints being given.  And, players may need to discuss which card / colour to sacrifice in order to get more hints. Even though this is a cooperative game, it is also a social game.  And, it's funny if you have a team member spoils the game plan.

The illustration and token of this version is better than the first edition.

Rule difference: the German rules allow a player to say "You don't have blue cards", but the English rules from RnR games disallow it.  I prefer to allow giving a hint of no colour / number cards, i.e. the German rules.
