=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Original and fun co-operative card game. The object is to create runs of cards based on colour and number under the premise that they are fireworks in a display. The innovative part is that you hold your cards away from yourself so that only your fellow players can see what you are holding. Clues are then given based on how many cards of a certain colour a player is holding or how many cards of a certain number. From this information a player has to decide which of their cards to play in the hope that it will add to a run. The game is far trickier than it first appears and shouldn't be taken too seriously, especially when often it is impossible to complete the game perfectly because of too many higher value cards being drawn at the start of the game. I commend the originality of designer Antoine Bauza because 'Hanabi' is unlike any game of its type that I have played before.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Okay coop game, but lacks theme for me and what you can communicate is not clear enough sometimes in my group. Find the game definitely worth a try because it's different, but in the end it's not my thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Laura's Rank (4/15) – 3.5 out of 5. Pros: Easy to learn. Fairly quick. Suspenseful. High player interaction (obviously). Can be played anywhere. Cons: More guessing at times than strategy, so sometimes you have to take some risks instead of critically thinking (this might be a pro for me, actually, but could be a con for others). The theme is light, but that doesn't bother me too much either.

Ryan's Rank (4/15) – 3.5 out of 5. I like that this game is easy to learn and relatively quick to play, with a fair amount of angst built into it. However, for some reason the suspense can bother me at times because the theme is pasted on. Still, a good game that is super portable, understandable for newbies, and a good introduction into a light co-op game.

Overall Rank (4/15) – 7.0 out of 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A wonderful group deduction game that offers difficult decisions and a relatively short play time. It can be prone to luck of the draw/discard at times. The other great thing about the game is that it's highly interactive even though you hardly speak and try not give away any non-verbal clues. This and The Resistance are like opposite sides of the same coin.

The cards in both the AS and R&R versions are quite thin though the AS have more 'flick' to them, fit better in the box and have better graphic design (for colour-blind players) and more easily distinguishable colours (green/blue and white/yellow are confusing in R&R).  But if R&R is the only version available it's still worth the money.

8>9

Now with SdJ approval!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Got this on the cheap at Essen 2013. German version, but the game itself is language independent, and English rules are easy to come by.

[EDIT] Played this at a family gathering. Unusual game, fun to figure out what should happen. Thrives on 'unspoken' codes, as so many other cardgames (Bridge, 'Rikken' etc). 
This is both a boon and a downfall. A boon, as you can pull off really smart plays. A downfall, as if you don't get the sign, everyone (not only your teammate) will potentially berate you because of your suboptimal move.

Surprised it gets such high ratings, must be typical gamers fare. Mechanic is new and refreshing and that gives 0.5 extra and some replay value as well. Still, I can see this be traded away in the near future.

[OCT 2014] Math traded.

RATING: 7.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A fast co-op game that seems to solve many of the problems inherent in co-op games. That makes it a pretty unique and fun challenge.

There are genuine moments of stress and tension as you try to make decisions based on what seems to be imperfect information.

Update: Playing this a lot with the same groups (my family and also a few close gaming buddies) is massively rewarding, though we work hard not to develop codes or systems to cheat and play by fairly strict rules - in that you can ask a player what they know about their hand, but if they are incorrect you can only correct them by spending a clue to give them information again. I do still enjoy playing it with new players because it is wonderful to see a new player 'get it', especially when you've set up a move in advance and they suddenly work out why they've been given a clue previously.

Rating up from 7.1 to 8 and then up again to 9 (provided people aren't cheating). And finally, after 48 players, up to a perfect 10!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
#Players: 2-5
Time: 25 mins
Mechanic: Co-Op, Card Game, Hand Management

Fireworks have arrived for a show but they are all jumbled up. Assemble a breathtaking display by lining up the values of fireworks... without looking at your hand. Give hints to other players and attempt to work together to line up as many fireworks as you can before the deck runs out.

RATING: N/A
Hát nem tudom...Valahogy túl könnyű a játék. Lehet, hogy elrontottunk valamit, de így nem volt élvezetes. Hiába csak számot vagy színt lehet elárulni, szinte mindig elárulható a kettő együtt, hiszen ha lent van 3 2-es és valakinek azt mondom egyik lapjéra hogy az 2-es, akkor józan ésszel nézve is az a 2-es biztos olyan színű ami még nincs lent....És így nem igazán kihívás megcsinálni akár a 25 pontot. Sajna eléggé nem tetszett, így nem biztos hogy előkerül újra...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not so easy to build the rows because you only see the cards of the other players. 

Say someone what card he has is an action. There are only a limited number of this actions. You must clear this actions, but but to clear you discard a card. When you don`t know your cards you can discard a card that you need. You must manage this action, so all players can do something that is required.

That`s all fresh, but i have one problem with this game. If i know we don`t get the maximum amount of points, i lose my attention. When we don`t get 25 points we lose, when we lose who cares how many points we have.

The other problem is you can`t talk. But you can`t play in silence. When you say something apparently no important you can influence other player moves because you involuntarily will suggest something. 

Must play more to see if this is a big problem for me.

EDIT: With 2 players to random. If you don`t have low cards, you ca do nothing. With more players still intersting.

RATING: 9
Great little cooperative deduction game. Five or six suits (with some options on how to use the sixth suit). Each suit is three 1s(?), two 2-4, one 5. You see others' cards but not your own. Each turn you can try to play a card, using one of five(?) lives if it's unplayable; discard a card, gaining a hint token; or play a hint token to tell a player which of his cards are a particular number or suit/color. Then, you have to logic through why the player asked the question they did.

RATING: 4
Hanabi is an interesting twist on the co-op game, so that there's more to it than whether the deck was randomized favorably. Unfortunately a 2-hour session rather killed my enthusiasm for the game (nth-order logic for 18/25; for what it's worth I've hit 20+/25 with buzzed people who were just firing from the hip). There needs to be tight adherence to the limitations on what players are allowed to say; can you imagine Bridge if people were allowed to discuss convention construction mid auction?

I want to rate Hanabi higher, since it's so novel, but honestly these days I think I could find a better option in my collection. It might still have a place in my library as a good litmus test for overthinking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I enjoyed this much more than I thought I was going to. I'm not the biggest fan of co-op games, let alone co-op games that appear to be very light. Thankfully, Hanabi is more than the sum of its parts. Unlike co-opts that are heavy on theme, Hanabi is all about player interaction. It's more or less the abstract game of co-opts. Everyone at the table must work together to develop a means of communication. There isn't anything else there to keep your interest, and therefore Hanabi has to rely on the strengths of its design. Luckily, it performs admirable.

Knowing what everyone else is holding, and hoping that they will all interpret your clues correctly, is very tense. Selecting a card of my own to play, and hoping that I interpreted everyone else's clues correctly, is unbearable in a very enjoyable way. I'm hoping I don't screw up, and yet at the same time there is a certain devilish delight in watching other people struggle.

I suspect that playing the game with the same group will allow for the development of a system, which will ultimately make the game more dependent on the luck of the draw. It's also a game that is open to cheating, but who wants to play with people who would do that anyway -- especially in a co-opt. That all said, for such a straightforward card game, Hanabi delivers. It's not the most fun I've had playing a game, but it's a solid entry for a few hands in a row.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I want to like this game, because it encourages communication. But with all the table talk and conventions that unavoidably get adopted in the course of the game, I feel that it is impossible not to cheat in this game. Also suffers from a serious case of quarterbacking and public shaming, because everyone knows that a card is wrong except for the person playing it. Even when playing online, I have been asked to play with certain conventions. I feel that the game is broken, though the mechanism of not seeing your own cards is intriguing. I won't like to play it again at gatherings, because it requires too much memory and too much energy in mediation when unhappiness creeps in due to quarterbacking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really clever co-op card game with simple but challenging mechanics. You're trying to get a high score, not "beat the game," so it ends up being quite addictive as you keep trying to top yourselves. It's also just as good with two players as it is with a group. The compact size means it travels well, and the quick play time (which isn't dependent on number of players) makes it a great addition for the end of a night or to kill some time before dinner. I was not overly impressed with the quality of components, though, but it's so cheap it doesn't matter much. Also, if you're a stickler for by-the-books rules, you'll have a hard time with the ambiguity of what constitutes cheating and what doesn't in terms of allowed communication--you simply have to set that standard in your individual group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Hanabi is getting a lot of love from a lot of people, but it seems more of a clever, slightly above average game to me. And even more, I don't see it having high replayability - once I've seen this pony's trick a few times it loses some of its luster. All that said, Hanabi is fun with the right crowd and is a fine game ... just not the superior game its hype would lead you to believe.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
:thumbsup: The gameplay is unique and it requires a type of thinking and interaction that I haven't seen elsewhere.
:thumbsup: When we first started playing, my girlfriend and I found it hilarious how bad we are at communicating with each other.
:thumbsup: Gameplay example. You give your teammate an efficient but tricky clue, and you really hope that she thinks the way you think. But she doesn't trust her own understanding of your clue, thinking, "Would he really mean it this way, or am I just taking it way too far?" All the while you're sitting across from her thinking, "Yes, that's exactly what I meant! Come on, just DO IT!" And finally your teammate decides to play it safe, and in doing so does something stupid.
:thumbsup: The game is tiny, dirt cheap, and has good quality cards.
[b][color=green]------------------------------[/color][/b]
:?block: The game has a memory component, as you need to remember all the clues you were given. And when you forget a clue, which is very disappointing seeing how clues are very valuable, most likely you will just ask your teammates to give you this clue again for free. This is against the rules, but of course can be house-ruled.
[b][color=red]------------------------------[/color][/b]
:thumbsdown: Communication restrictions are the whole game in Hanabi. Yet, the rulebook encourages you to play the game the way you like and doesn't give a comprehensive list of what is and isn't allowed to say or do in order to create the intended gameplay experience. E.g., it doesn't specify if players are allowed to reorder their cards specifically to communicate to others what they are going to discard next if not given any clues not to.
:thumbsdown: In order to play the game your group must create and agree on a series of conventions (like the reordering one I described above), none of which are offered to you in the rulebook. This is the whole strategy in Hanabi: creating a meta game where players all play in a specific way to allow them to communicate the maximum amount of information sort of within the rules. Discussions between games are more important than how you play during a game, at least initially.
:thumbsdown: One of the problems with player conventions is how you're going to remember them if you revisit the game after an extended period of time. Or if you play with a new person, you'll need to explain the way you play so they can play on the same level with you, and this can be hard and non-intuitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
You have to think how the other person thinks. I also played this with 4 and 5 people. One game with the 5 group, we where cheating pretty bad by saying, "Your face is looking red, oh by the way you have a 2." It was so much fun though.

Although the rules prevent table talk, with four players there is still some discussion going. With two players, it is more a silent thinking game.

RATING: 4
For some reason Hanabi has never really hit me the way it has so many other people. I think it's okay, but it seems like once your metagame quickly gets to a certain point, games play out about the same way each time. The deluxe edition helps because you now don't have to hold cards in a certain way and you can more easily remind yourself about your tiles because you can orient them in more ways.

I think it's okay and I'll play it when asked, but it would never be my first choice.

Update: Now that Beyond Baker Street is out, there's no reason to ever play Hanabi. BBS copies Hanabi one for one, and then adds a few more improvements to it along with a much nicer presentation.

RATING: 7.5
I have nothing new to add to what has already been said.  It is a very cool take on co-op games and I understand why some people love it, particularly the fact that the uber-boss can't just tell everyone what to do. My different game groups never have that problem, so it is not a selling point for me.

I enjoy the game, but I believe the shine will wear off pretty quickly.  We will see if I am right, but even if I am it is a unique game and a terrific value.

Update: this game is curious in that one wants to discuss conventions to better communicate but even that feels like cheating. Would a bridge-like set of "bidding" conventions ruin the game? Probably. 




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 5
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 5
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 4
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 5


Overall - 5

RATING: 10

With new players just explaining the rules and playing the game is silly and it doesn't matter if we win or lose. Everyone just loves it for how unique the game is.

With experienced players who now have habits on how they discard or hold their cards and card counting it becomes a very intense game of trying to get a perfect 25 and high level thinking of what a clue meant in the context of the rest of the game state.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[thing=98778][/thing] is a fairly light cooperativa game in which the players work together to save a fireworks presentation. Just, you know, not really. The theme makes only a brief appearance in the rules and then is left to the side - don't be fooled: [thing=98778][/thing] is an abstract game, but it is easy to sell things with even a shameful pasted-on theme.

In a given turn the player has three options:
- play a card;
- discard a card;
- give an information.

This last one is what makes the game, because the player can't look the front of the cards they will have in hand. Therefore they will only know which ones they have because of the informations given by the others. The information can be about a color or a number - and is allowed (and necessary) to point the card(s) out. But every information given takes away a time token, and there are only eight of them. To bring time tokens back, is necessary to discard a card, however this can, of course, means that a row of colors won't be completed. The play a card is the most straightforward: choose a card and play it on the table, putting it in the proper row (color-wise and number-wise). If the card can't be added to any row or start any row, it is discarded and one of the wick tokens - if three of the wick tokens are discarded the game is over.

The game also ends if:
- the draw pile is empty;
- all the rows are completed.

[thing=98778][/thing] fights one of the most common problems related with cooperative games: the alpha player, simply because, when it is not the players turn, he/she just can't say anything regarding the game, not even facial or body tips. But is a silence table a happy table? Surprisingly, it is. First because we never stop talking, it just won't happen, but we don't interfere with the choices made by others. Second, we aren't, at least by now, good at it - and is fun when the player puts is hand in the forehead and says: "I don't remember which card is the two!" or when someone plays the wrong card.

I'm concern with replay value. I just can't say if the challenge of going from 21 to 22 or a few points more. Sure, until the perfect 25, I guess it will be easier to gather players. But the games aren't really feel different one from the other. Time will tell.

By now [thing=98778][/thing] made a good impression in everyone in my group that played it, even one or two that went to play with the mindset of not-like the game. And this is a major win for it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Yes, I'm giving a 5 to the "Spiel des Jahres 2013". To be honest, this is an ingenious little game; a bargain, no matter how much you pay for it. But how much fun it is really depends on who is playing it. Some will want to add house rules, others will quickly get mad if the players communicate too much. For me, it is missing a proper challenge - rewarding a collaborative team of players simply with points in the end is just ... unsatisfying. (See Pandemic for a collaborative game with plenty of challenges.)

RATING: 9
Probably the finest game there is for demonstrating the innovation in modern game design to the unfamiliar. The reversed hands thing is about the cleanest, most immediately striking, and most irresistible shorthand that this game is something different. 

On top of that, the game system at large has a flexibility built in which few do: you can offer or withhold clues of intonation and body language as the group desires.

A highlight of one particular family holiday was playing this each night with my parents and wife. No other modern game have my parents taken to like this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good:
-Co-operative
-Gateway game
-Deeper in strategy than it looks
-Easy to keep track of cards you can't miss play
-Card backs have a black corner which helps remember hints

Bad:
-Some players will forget what is in their hands
-Forgetting hints can really aggravate some players
-Players may blame other players for not giving a hint
-Theme
-Five players is pushing it
-Extremely slow players can make this game torture

Overall:
It's a great game that can be taught to anyone no matter their experience with board games.  If your group does not like to point fingers and pass blame, it's a must have.  If they do, just remind them that it's the team's fault for giving them too many hints, poor hints, or not asking them what they know about their hand often enough.  For some reason, this game seems to go over great in predominately female crowds.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 10
Great co-op game. Beautiful elimination of the alpha-gamer problem by making communication part of the mechanics. Creates great tension and mind-games as you try to guess what other players will do based on what they know you know they know etc, and requires you to make every action meaningful on multiple levels.

Great with 2 players and great with 5, and has plenty of ways to house-rule it to be more or less difficult. My current (as of this writing) favorite pure co-op game, next to Ghost Stories.

RATING: 7
I bought this one because it is cooperative and had many great reviews. I find it to be a tedious exercise in memory. The reversed cards is a clever spin, but I simply can't remember the makeup of my hand from one turn to the next. And I found the instructions a bit unclear regarding the nature and quantity of information allowed to be shared in clues.
With a select group of highly focused individuals, this could be a fun challenge.

10-06-2015 update... I have revisited Hanabi and have several recent plays. I approached it with a new attitude and am enjoying it more and more. I am raising my rating to 7.0.

RATING: 10
One of my favorite games to have learned, improved, improved some more, and then discussed strategy with my friends and drastically improved some more.  The best part is that those final improvements do not require any unspoken system of cheating, giving information without counting clues, or agreed upon code.  Instead it just required discussing the safest assumptions to make while playing and agreeing to give clues assuming others will behave logically.  If everyone is willing to trust that an awkward clue was given for a truly logical reason they can often puzzle out what much more information about their own hand from the information they can see around them.  This game can be played casually (alright), seriously (very good), or extremely hardcore (perfection itself to the right players who enjoy that kind of thing).

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Impressive game. On paper, I would never expect a concept like this to work, but it does and it works well.

Hanabi is a cooperative game that plays a bit like Solitaire or Hearts where you try to place cards on stacks in the right order. Each person has a hand of cards, and there's a deck to draw from. The really interesting part is you play with your hands backwards -- you can see everyone else's hands, but you cannot see your own. Yet you still play cards from that hand. The other players use up hints to get you to figure out which cards to play or discard.

Sounds simple, but this is a really intense psychological game that can be very stressful. When you give hints to someone, you want to convey as much information, and expose as many potential actions as possible. In order to figure this out, it's not just about what cards the player has in their hand: you also have to factor in their experience with the game, their personality traits, and really dig into their brain. Not only that, but they're going to do the same to *you* when receiving your hint. You can't do or give away any information except for the hint, and you should try to do your best pokerface. Brilliant game.

There's so many stipulations about playing this game, and that's what holds me back from giving it a higher rating. I saw footage of a Hanabi tournament, and I really don't understand how something like that could even exist, unless the players were in isolated rooms. Even something as small as an eye twitch can be enough to tip someone off. Still, for making such a bold concept work, this is really fantastic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Minimal gameplay, taken to the absolute, mind numbing limit. [gameid=129622], [gameid=153], [gameid=432], [gameid=56692], [gameid=770], [gameid=398], [gameid=125], [gameid=220], [gameid=125605]. Yes, these too are minimalist games, but they are fun to play. There's no game here, [i]at all[/i]. Game of Hedbanz, anyone? [gameid=7682] (blind)? What is the draw? I'd rather have every tooth pulled out of my head, than be forced to play this. Don't bogart that hookah...

RATING: 8
A game this small and simple can't possibly be this good, but it is.  This is incredibly simple, and wonderful fare for extended family get-togethers or other places where you don't have a group that has a lot of tolerance for rules.  The deduction here is crisp, it's very difficult to get a good score, and there's a wonderful group dynamic that keeps everybody involved.  The best simple game that has come out since [gameid=2842].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Hanabi is a co-op deduction game, where you're trying to build up the cards from 1 to 5 in each of five colours. The trick is, you can't see your own cards that you play. So the players give clues to each other.

For example, I might point to Bob's leftmost card and say "this card is Red". The next player might say to Bob "Your leftmost and rightmost cards are twos". Now Bob knows that his leftmost card is a Red 2, and if the Red 1 is already on the table, then he knows he can play it and we've scored a point.

The problem is remembering all the info you've been given, it's very easy to lose track. And there are a limited number of clues that can be given, so you often have to guess because you don't have enough info. Did Bob tell me "this card is a 3" because he wants me to play it, or because he wants me to discard it? If you throw away too many cards, you can get stuck in a colour, if we throw away both 2s, then the 3-5 cards can never be played, for example.

Short and fun, I could see bringing this out occasionally.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a very good co-op wich plays very different from other games that I have played. Getting the maximum will be very hard but we'll keep trying.

Each player takes 5 cards but holds them blindley. Only the other players can see them. Your goal is to create the biggest firework. There are 5 colors with numbers from 1-5. You have lay the correct card on the correct colour. You pick the cards with the advice you get from your co-players. But there are only 8 tokens for advice. 

So give advice (cost 1 token), play a card (and take a new one), discard a card (and regain 1 token). If you play a card and you're wrong, 1 thundertoken is turned over. At 3 you lose automatically.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm no fan of cooperative games, but this one has a unique feel that makes it feel less like a cooperative game, and more like you're playing against an invisible player.  It's a deduction game that blends some of the best parts of Code 777 (deducing the cards you have in front of you, which everyone else can see but you can't) and Sleuth (limiting the questions you can ask to deduce what you have), and it works remarkably well.  I can see this being a good filler game, and a good game for playing with families.

2 plays: 2 players
1 play: 4 players
5 plays: 5 players

RATING: 9
I gave Hanabi a 9 rating for it's price, replay ability, elegance, ease of getting to the table, and ease of teaching.  I have played this game about 20 times over the last six months, with many different groups.  The game plays in 10-25 minuets, depending on number of players and how many new players there are.  What this games does well is have a very low price, and a very easy way of getting to the table.  You may love a big, epic game, but this small box game will get far more plays for the price.

This game also makes a great gift for new board game players, and is perfect for vacations!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is FUN. Yes, even with just two players. It strikes the right balance between quick gameplay and "thinky-ness". The fact that you need to communicate with limited options adds a neat social component to it. The fact that you build together on a common goal that is laid out clearly on the table in front of you adds to the tension. The fact that this features basically a non-existing theme and really is just an abstract game is quickly forgotten thanks to all the difficult choices you have to make. Hanabi certainly falls into the category of addictive games that you will not play for one round only. The only reason that this is not a perfect 10 for me is that this game is not strong enough to fully carry itself, but depends on the company you play it with (you depend on the other player - and their memory).

After a few more plays down-graded to 8 due to the anti-climactic ending that can feel like a bit of a letdown.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I thought this would light and fun but find it tense. Tense and fun, very rewarding when you do make progress I'm excited to play this more. I do play with 'non-gamers' and I think it needs to be really understood that the top score is not the expected score, you don't 'lose' if you don't achieve this.

Have upgraded the score because the more I play the more I think this is a masterpiece. I'm not always keen to play it but I do think it is a fantastic design in terms of the simplicity but complexity of actual play. The way that complexity is does not feel to cerebral but feels very joyous because it is a shared experience. When played properly it is a real marvel of a game. If I had to recommend one game to someone who had never played games before and was unlikely to play again, I would recommend this because I think it is an experience everyone should enjoy at least once.

80 plays in and it just keeps giving.

Number of plays to reach Silver value: 5
Number of plays to reach Gold value: 10
Number of plays to reach Platinum value: 50

RATING: 8
Great concept - let the others describe your own cards to you and then try to memorize what they said about cards. The problem with the game is that it only really works with people that understand the value of the various types of information and how that changes from situation to situation. You should also be able to judge how well they understand the game concept to know how to act on their information.
The game really looses if people start to use a secret language since the amount of information conveyed becomes too big so the games gets unbalanced.

RATING: 6
2 - [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/5p/user/Vroenis]5 players[/url].
Teaching: +3 minutes.
Mastery: 15 - 25 minutes.
Card box.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geektag.php?tags=embassy_%26_outpost&username=Vroenis&action=usertags]Embassy_&_Outpost[/url]

Currently in my [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/survival_kit/user/Vroenis]survival kit[/url].

Co-op.
Blind hand of cards - unseen by player, seen by all other players!
Restricted communication.
Deduction/guessing/(gambling!)
Set construction/hilarious failure.

Whether or not this should have won Spiel des Jahres for 2013, I don't care. It's a simple, hilarious game for those that can celebrate each success and failure equally. Understandably, some folks won't like failing but you know, failure is a big thing in games, I think more people need to learn to appreciate it as per pretty much all co-op games.

Before I launch into a monologue on Chvátil, I'll just say that Hanabi is cheap, quick and a ton of fun. Play it at least once or twice!

RATING: 10
Easy to learn, but hard to win, Hanabi is one of the best collaborative games out there. 

To win, players should collect cards of the same color in order. The trick is that they can see other players cards, but not their own. To solve the puzzle, players have to share clues, but communication is extremely limited, so only teams in perfect harmony will succeed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A cooperative card game.
The card deck consists of five different colors of cards, numbered 1 to 5 in each color. For each color, the players try to place a row in the correct order from 1 to 5. Sounds easy, right? Well, not quite, as in this game you hold your cards so that they're visible only to other players. To assist other players in playing a card, you must give them hints regarding the numbers or the colors of their cards. Players must act as a team to avoid errors and win before they run out of cards.

RATING: 9
This is a great logic puzzle-type game that can get pretty deep with a very simple set of rules.  In my honest opinion, there are some BGGers who don't give this game enough credit.  I do not feel this game is "light" or a "filler".  It is a great challenge and very difficult.

Edit (April, 2015)-Although I still believe this game is not a filler game, I have now opened up to different ways to play this game.  If you have a group that would play this game in a light-hearted manner, being a little silly or bending the rules a bit (your fourth and FIFTH cards are blue...), then that is just dandy. This game works for serious players as well as very casual players.

RATING: 9

After this, I'm utterly convinced that some of my friends are psychic!

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hanabi is an abstract, number-based game of cooperative deduction and inference.  As terrible as that sounds, it's actually pretty good.

I don't know whether Hanabi has an infinite shelf life, but with 15 plays behind me I still find myself suggesting it to close friends and random strangers whenever I have a half hour to spare. 

As a big mark in its favor, Hanabi is unusual in that playing with people who are new to the game can be more fun than playing with old hats, as there's a genuine sense of satisfaction in indirectly helping novice teammates to deduce information, play and discard cards, and generate multi-step clues.  And invariably people want to play twice in a row to apply what they learned from their low-scoring first play.

So, for now, Hanabi presses all the right buttons.  It's sleek, clean, thoughtful, and inexpensive - and it takes only 5 minutes to explain and 20-30 minutes to play. Best of all, loudmouth players (like me) are forbidden from giving advice to their teammates during the game.

A win all around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Exceptional cooperative game. You do not know what cards you hold. You can see the other players cards. The mechanism for gaining information is very well designed. This is a thinkers game. A few plays are needed for most people to recognize when and what to do. It is still a challenge to experienced players. I like it.

RATING: 8.5
Hands down one of the best co-operative games I've ever played. You don't get to see your hand of cards, but you get to see everyone elses' hand. Give clues, play and discard to retrieve clue tokens. Simple, eloquent, and intense. I love it. I play this nearly every day on Board Game Arena. I am always up for a game of Hanabi. Wonderful game, if you haven't played it, you're doing yourself a disservice.

Artwork- 6/10
Mechanics- 9/10
Theme- 7/10
Fun- 8/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nate bought me a copy at Con of the North as a "Valentine's Day present"  Thanks Nate!!!

A co-op card game where you need to collectively play your cards in a certain order... but you can't look at the cards in your hand.  You give your teammates clues about what colors and numbers they have in their hand while they give you clues to decipher the best cards to play.  Play too many cards out of sequence and the game ends. No set win condition, playing to the highest total possible is enough of a goal to keep the game interesting.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
Inside the box are 60 cards, 8 clue tokens and 3 lightning tokens. Each player gets 4 cards (5 in a 2-player game) and hold them in their hands facing towards the other players. On a players turn he can do 1 out of 3 actions.

    Give a clue
    Discard a card
    Play a card

1.) When a player decides to give a clue, he turns over a clue token to the dark side, which means the clue is used. He can give two different kind of clues. First kind is to tell the one color of the cards. He can say that, that & that card is red. Or he can tell the number of the cards. This & this is a 3. Trick of this is, that if he decided to tell what cards are red, he has to tell of all the red cards. Same goes on which telling numbers. He has to tell where all of the 3’s are situated. When all 8 clue tokens (7 in a 2 player game) are on the dark side, a player may not give any clue.

2.) When a player decides to discard a card, he places a hand card faced up on the discard tile. He turns over a clue token to the light side (which will be available then again), and takes a new card.

3.) When a player thinks he has enough information he can play a card onto the table. If a cards fits a row, it can be played. If it doesn’t fit, lightning will strike and a lightning tokes is flipped over to the other side. Basically you will be trying to add the next consecutive number until all 5 stacks have a 5 on top.

The games ends when lightning stroked 3 times or the pile of cards is empty. Players add together the highest value of a card in each row. This will be their score. Goal of the game is to get 25 points, but this will be a very hard job to fulfill.

The better the memory of a player is, the easier it will be for him. Because of the clue tokens, the clues that can be given are very limited, and you always want to give more clues. Although it is a cooperative game, it will be very silent in the room, as nothing can and might be said if a clue isn’t given. The concept of the turned around cards is new to us, and very different.  It’s supposed to be a filler game, but after playing once, you want to play it again. And again. And again…
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
For being such a simple concept, this game is deceptively hard. In the 20 odd games that I've played, I've never 'beaten' it. There are extra cards to make the game harder, but I honestly don't think they're needed if you play the game by the spirit of the rules.

RATING: 7
One of the more interesting takes on co-operative gaming.  I think my only reason for not liking it more is that it is an abstract game, which i find doesn't lend itself to enticing me into playing often.  
Having said that, it's a challenge worth trying.  The game isn't really a *loose-able* game, so your only real challenge is to do better than previously.  And that can be interesting in between games trying to come up with a *fool-proof* way to do better.  
A good filler game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Probably the most amazing cooperative game ever. I have not played this original, but only the fan-made spinoff, but the basic principle is the same: You see everyone else's cards, but not your own, and the collective goal is to get out all cards in the right order. You can inform your teammate which of his card(s) are of a certain number or colour. This turns into a hilarious co-op work to get people to understand more than just the basic thing you just said. Amazing. Downright amazing. Truly and absolutely amazing.

RATING: 8
We played a lot of cards as a kid, and my mother always wanted to end the night with a few rounds of Indian Poker. It was a funny way to end a game night, and clearly memorable because some twenty-years later I can remember it. I was giddy when I first came across the grown-up version of her favorite game. Now, if only I could get her to stop cheating when we play ("These TWO cards are red." "This ONE is Green"). My only knock is that in average lighting some of the colors are hard to distinguish (Yellow/White), so we normally substitute the rainbow in as a regular suit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The cards are beautiful and the game play is fun, but it does leave you feeling drained by the end, which is not normal for such a card game. Holding the cards up is physically tiring and a pain in the wrist. I recommend getting card holders for this. Then, trying to remember what clues you've been given and what clues you need to give to other people is incredibly mentally taxing. This is the most thinky cooperative game I've played.

While I like thinky games, the taxing quality of this and basically themeless game play does not make it a popular hit at the table and it doesn't come out often.
